name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The next item is the debate with Polish Prime Minister Mateusz Morawiecki on the future of Europe (2018/2729(RSP)). We welcome you, Prime Minister. As you know, and as my fellow Members know, Parliament wants to be at the heart of the debate on the future of our continent and our Union. We are experiencing particularly difficult times: Europe must be changed, but it is a precious asset that we cannot renounce, because it has guaranteed us seventy years of peace, democracy and freedom. We want the European Parliament to be increasingly at the centre of the political debate, we want to be protagonists and we want the European Parliament to have the power of initiative like all parliaments in the world. In recent weeks too, we have made our voice heard on the subject of immigration, calling on the Council to adopt the reform of the right of asylum. This is one of the important issues for Parliament. It will now be important for us, during this debate, to listen to your ideas, your proposals and what the Polish Government intends to do to make a contribution to the construction of the Europe of the future. There are many proposals on the table: those of the European Parliament, those of the Commission and those of several Member States; that is why it is important to listen to what the Member States think: we want to confront each other, and this is a new method of confronting a face-to-face between the European Parliament and the leaders of national governments. Thank you for accepting our invitation. I would remind you that the debate today will end at 11.20 a.m., because then I will receive the President of Angola: for speeches, you can register with the usual system, sticking paper and pushing one of the buttons.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Prime Minister Polish. – Mr President Antonio Tajani, i would like to thank you for your excellent work. Dear Minister, I would like to thank you for your excellent work. Dear President Valdis Dombrovskis, i would like to thank you for your excellent work. Honourable Members, I would like to thank you for your excellent work. Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur, Mr Schwab Dear! It is an honour for me, as Prime Minister of the Government of the Republic of Poland, to be able to speak here in Strasbourg today, to be able Polish present this point of view on the most important challenges facing the European Union. It is also an honour to speak here in the European Parliament, which, of all the institutions of the European Union, most reflects the voice of its citizens expressed in democratic elections. The European Parliament is an important place for the Functioning of the Union not only as an institution with a huge influence on the shape of EU law, but also as a forum where decisions are discussed that will set the direction for European integration in the coming years. Poland is celebrating this year the 500th anniversary of the convening of the first Sejm and the centenary of the regaining of independence, when we were one of the first countries in the world to grant women full democratic rights. This shows how deeply the idea of parliamentarianism, democracy and the rule of law is rooted in Polish political culture. It is the national parliaments that are the expression of the sovereign's voice and a living symbol of democracy. The discussion on the future of Europe is one of the most important debates that we face, especially when we are celebrating the 100th anniversary of the end of World War I, from which the difficult history of 20th-century Europe began. It was after the cataclysm of two world wars and unimaginable crimes of genocide that the free nations of Europe made the historic decision more than 60 years ago to start integration, in order, despite our differences, to look for what unites us. Had it not been for the Iron Curtain and the tragic division of Europe after World War II, Poland would also have been the founder of the European communities in accordance with the will of the Polish government in exile. This division put Polish society outside the bracket of the first wave of European integration, but also outside the bracket of sustainable development. That is why today, even more so, as a full member of the Union, we want to be as active as possible in the search for a constructive agenda for our continent. Like every nation in Europe, we have our expectations for it, but we also have a lot to offer. It is impossible to understand the continuity and essence of Europe without acknowledging its Greek, Roman and, finally, Judeo-Christian roots. Without Christianity, European diversity would never have achieved a sense of universalism and unity in diversity, especially in this House. This motto of our Union is not just empty words. Our nations have been shaped for hundreds of years through their culture and institutions. Respect for these national identities is the foundation of trust in the Union. The constitutional pluralism enthused in Article 4 of the Treaty is a great value and every country in the Union has the right to shape its legal system in accordance with its traditions. For me, the European idea has always been a Polish state of affairs, both when, as a young boy, I participated in the anti-communist opposition, fighting for freedom and democracy, and when, as director of accession negotiations in the Committee for European Integration in the 1990s, I worked on Polish's entry into the Union. Today, despite almost thirty years since the fall of communism, we are still in the difficult process of sewing the European experience, the European memory. However, the differences that divide us must not obscure the common objective of the security of our citizens and economic development. Honourable Members, I would like to thank you for your excellent work. In recent years, the European Union has been grapple with existential crises: the banking crisis, the financial crisis, the euro zone crisis, the migration crisis, Brexit and Russia's aggressive policies. The five losing Community referendums in recent years, as well as the change in the political landscape in European countries, are all evidence that the European project needs a new opening. Some argue that the Union is always going through a crisis, that any change to the Treaties is the result of one solstice or another. However, our situation today seems to be unique, different from in the 1960s or 1980s or in the first decade of this century. This is because we are dealing not with a single crisis, but with multiple cumulative crises at the same time. The answer must therefore be based on the best possible understanding of the circumstances in which we find ourselves. We all see that many Europeans are no longer enthusiastic about integration. Some of them are openly opposed. We can be outraged at that. We can close our eyes and pretend it's just a margin. But that won't change the reality. This is not a margin. This is a real signal that we have made mistakes, and an opportunity to fix those mistakes. Instead of wringing our hands over dangerous populism, we should rather to consider why there has been such a situation that so many Europeans do not like the direction in which the Union has been going for years. The answer to this question has been given many times and in different ways, but I think the most pertinent is the one that has stood at the source of all the great changes in our history. People have the gene of freedom within them and they want to decide for themselves what life will be like for their families and their societies. When they see that they are losing this influence, that they have no real impact on the fate of Europe and the world, it is a natural reflex to oppose this situation. I think that in this House we are all more or less convinced that European integration is one of the best ideas in the history of not only Europe, but also the world. But if this belief is not shared by our citizens, there will simply be no further integration. Therefore, the further development of the Union must take into account their voice. In other words, in order for the European project to move forward, its democratic legitimacy must be strengthened. This can be called populism, but sooner or later one has to ask ourselves whether the answer to citizens' expectations is actually populism or rather the essence of democracy? Europe is currently experiencing a democratic awakening, which shows that we need to renew the social contract that created the great success of post-war integration. This contract was about restoring a sense of security and an economic policy that offers relative prosperity for all. Today, we must "annex" this contract by restoring a sense of security and hope that our children will live better than ourselves. Only this can restore confidence in the European project. So how do you respond to this democratic awakening? The answer is a community that adapts to the challenges of today without giving up its existing responsibilities to its citizens. In order to deal with all these challenges, we need to redefine the balance between national states and cooperation at European level. This is what the Union of Nations 2.0, de Gaulle's vision adapted to the challenges of the present day, should be all about. This is the vision of the Union that Poland wants to propose. As part of such intelligent adaptation, we propose to focus primarily on three aspects. The first is union 4.0, the European Union as the forefashing of the Fourth Industrial Revolution and a deepened common market. The second point is a secure union, that is, aware of the geopolitical challenges it faces and ready to respond to them with one solidarity vote. And the third point is the Citizens' Union, a socially sensitive union that supports its citizens against the power of global corporations, a union of solidarity. And now I will briefly discuss these three areas. I have no doubt that more cooperation is needed above all in terms of the challenges of the changing nature of the global economy. The Union should set itself ambitious targets and focus today on a bold budget and further economic integration within the internal market. Completion of the internal market, productivity gains can only be achieved by increasing competition within a fully integrated internal market. According to an analysis by the European Parliament, only in the last 14 years since the creation of the internal market has it contributed to gdp growth of ceteris paribus above the alleged increase of an additional €250 billion. We therefore need more common market, especially in services. The services sector accounts for around 70% of the Union's GDP and at the same time represents only 20-25% of intra-EU trade. The 2006 Services Directive needs a major revision in order to finally make the freedom to provide services a reality. But there will also really be no single single market without a further ambitious fight against inequality, without an active cohesion policy. This policy is not a unilateral, non-refundable aid to underdeveloped countries. Cohesion policy is, above all, an investment in the development of the common market, which brings enormous trade benefits, including to those who today are most demanding that it be reduced. According to EU and our calculations, around 70-75% of euro cents return from each euro to net payers in the form of orders and orders. Commissioner Oettinger recently spoke of similar proportions. This must be made clear: attempts to reduce cohesion policy are populism. And it does not matter whether it is anti-European populism or supposedly pro-European populism proclaimed under the EU flag. Cohesion policy, an ambitious fight against inequality, is a win-win situation for the founding countries of the Union and for all other members. This fight against inequalities can be achieved not only through cohesion policy transfers, but also by sealing our tax systems. The real fight against the VAT gap must be tackled and tax havens at European Union level must be tackled. Vat revenues are, after all, union's revenue. I would point out that the Commission's calculation shows that tax avoidance losses amount to up to EUR 200 billion per year in the Union, and vat fraud and losses amount to an additional EUR 150 billion per year. If it's not just this "big African elephant in the room" (the elephant in the room), Then I don't know what it would be. In Poland, we succeeded. We have dealt with tax refund criminals, fraudsters who have robbed our citizens. These people could afford the best law firms. They managed to delay proceedings for years, hide money, avoid accountability, flee from poor justice. This justice system was, moreover, extremely opathleable and opathliable for these criminals. The courts have been convicted of ridiculously low sentences, often suspended. And we've heard from everywhere that it has to be, that nothing can be done about it. And we just showed that we can. Thus, we have generated revenues for the European Union and also for Poland, the Polish society. It was only necessary to be determined, to define the goal we are aiming for, and then to act smoothly to achieve it. This is also our offer to Europe: effective, proven legal solutions. This is often discussed at the European Council. The state and society robbed by bandits, by the terrorist mafia, the state's unsuccessful justice apparatus was partly fictitious. We have been showing for two and a half years that an effective state can almost eradicate extreme poverty in children and young people. These are our very real social achievements. It is also essential that we work very closely within the European Union in the area of tax avoidance, including on so-called digital tax and tax havens. In the morning, I also spoke with President Tajani about the European Union's own revenue. Poland also supports this idea, which I know the majority of the European Parliament also supports, namely the European Union's own revenue. So it is also necessary to limit tax havens. These havens are not directed against one country or another. Their existence threatens our entire economy. It allows billions of euros to leak out of our tax systems every year so that this money does not go to our citizens. Just as we prosecute tax criminals who commit individual actions, together we must counter organised action that allows for systemic and sometimes even state dishonesty. The modern economy also requires a new approach to competition law. It seems reasonable that a European antitrust office should be set up at EU level, more tailored to the challenges of today's digital economy. There is also a need for new competition rules and perhaps even sectoral regulations adapted to the digital age. Haven't Google and Facebook, for example, become essential facilities today, like transmission infrastructure in the energy industry? None of us in this House, and above all none of our citizens, can imagine daily functioning without these tools. They are essential for functioning in a modern digital society and regulations must keep up with these changes. The new Investment Plan for Europe proposed by President Juncker has been a success. Economic growth has accelerated and today the European Fund for Strategic Investments has generated additional investment of €300 billion. This fund should not be disbanded in 2020, but should be transformed into an ambitious new tool. The need for further strategic investment today stems not from the need to recover from the crisis, but from the need to make Europe competitive. The European Investment Bank warns that the Union is suffering from a chronic lack of infrastructure investment. This expenditure is now the lowest in many years. The investment gap is more than €600 billion per year. Until we fill it, we will not be able to compete with other global powers. One such strategic goal is the European energy transition, which requires a combination of price competitiveness and geopolitical realism. So what does it take? Investment in innovation first and foremost. Europe should create the world's largest clean-tech fund and put more pressure on market-based mechanisms to increase the rationality of the energy transition for European companies and citizens. After all, competitive energy prices are crucial for the competitiveness of national economies. The path taken by the European Union towards a low-carbon economy, and perhaps even zero-emission economy, is certainly the right way to go. This is the way to a clean environment and a better health for our citizens. In Poland, we are well aware of the importance of these challenges, which is why this year we have taken a strong fight against smog and are introducing a package of solutions that will guarantee an improvement in air condition. However, when we set further reduction targets for the Union, we must remember that our countries are starting from completely different levels. Until the economic transformation in 1989, the Polish economy was based on heavy industry and coal energy. Nevertheless, Poland has made a huge effort to reduce CO2 emissions by as much as 30% in accordance with the Kyoto Protocol with our commitment to 5%. We have exceeded our target six times. Poland is ready and wants to participate in the European energy transition. However, it must be based on equal opportunities and take greater account of the differences between our economies and support the efforts of countries with different instruments. For years, Poland was not able to switch its energy to natural gas, as it could only source this raw material from one direction – from Russia. Thus, any attempt to increase the consumption of blue fuel would lead to a breach of our safety. However, all our efforts in Central Europe can be crossed out by Nordstream II, which, it must be made clear, is not an economic project, but a political project. The European Union does not need Nordstream II, which increases the risk of destabilising Central Europe and gives Russia very strong tools to influence not only the European economy, but also European politics.  So the industry of the future will decide the reality of the global economy. Artificial intelligence, machine learning, Big Data, industry 4.0 – these are the ways that can give a new impetus to our economy. As the internal combustion engine played a huge role in the industrialisation of the West, so thanks to European cooperation it was possible to build Airbus, which alongside Boeing is today a global leader in aircraft production. It's time for new joint technology projects. Poland wants to participate courageously in such projects. Today, electromobility can be such a 21st century reindustrialization vehicle. This development is already dynamic, but requires more substantial support from our countries. Today, only about 1.5% of cars in Europe are electric cars. If we really want to reduce CO2 emissions in our economy, we need to take a decisive step forward here. It is not science fiction that in 10 years' time, for example, about 25% or 30% of cars will be electric cars in the European Union. If we also want all these technologies of the future to develop, we must continue to build a Capital Markets Union, capital markets especially for small and medium-sized enterprises. Poland supports this direction of market development. The economic growth generated by the smart adaptation of the European economy will strengthen confidence in the European project. I mentioned earlier that the second point should be the pillar of European security. The second pillar, the second part of this contract, must be safety. Recent years have been a time of exceptional increase in geopolitical threats such as terrorism and Russian hybrid warfare in Ukraine and more, interference in the democratic process of Western countries and even direct attacks on the people of the Union. We all remember Salisbury or the destabilisation in Syria. Russia's aggression against Ukraine has shaken the security architecture of Central and Eastern Europe, but it has also been part of a larger plan to destabilise the West. A few years earlier, georgia was the target of a similar attack. This clearly shows that Russia's actions are not a coincidence, but part of a pre-established strategy. The only fault of these countries was the choice of the European economic and political model. This shows that the security of the Eastern Partnership of Europe is a matter for the union as a whole, to the same extent as the security of our southern neighbourhood. Peace and the stable development of our borders are in our best interests. The Union must therefore respond with all available means. But our security is also about building our defensive capabilities. This equates to our defence policy spending and our ability to maintain the transatlantic alliance. We have to take care of these relationships. Differences of opinion are natural, but it must be remembered that the strength of the West will always be our unity. Contentious issues need to be resolved in a spirit of partnership. After all, America also helped win Western democracies in World War I and II and stopped the Soviet Union from attacking western Europe. The global imbalances that our American partners are talking about are a fact and we need to resolve them at a global level. In this context, I am also pleased with the creation of the European Defence Fund and the entire PESCO programme, which will provide an additional transnational source of financing for investment in the defence industry. This is the way to strengthen our cooperation and the development of new technologies. One such challenge is cybersecurity. We already know very it is good that it plays a key role in the democratic process and that we may be vulnerable to attacks during elections and referendums. Today, no country in the European Union is safe from interfering in its internal affairs. Nor are our citizens safe, their bank accounts, and basically their entire digital identity is constantly exposed to cyber attacks. Together, we must make an effort to fight for security in cyberspace. Dear! Last week's European Council also showed that the Union is capable of realism and restoring the trust of its citizens who want safe and protected borders, as well as the right to influence decisions on migration policy. The Union is struggling with the influx of migrants and refugees from different sides and only through an intelligent and flexible approach to the migration challenge can it restore the sense of security of European citizens. Poland is a new home for more than 1.5 million Ukrainian citizens, including many who have fled their family homes due to Russian aggression. They are not registered with us as refugees, but simply because our procedures allow them to obtain a work permit much easier and build the well-being of themselves and their families, so that they also support our economy and the economy of the European Union. Demographic pressure from outside, especially from Africa and the Middle East, will only increase. That is why the European Union must commit to the stabilisation and development of these regions. Today, a new Marshall Plan for Africa is a necessity, just as it is necessary to combat the illegal smuggling of people into Europe. We support the creation of new funds for Africa, such as the European EU Emergency Trust Fund for Africa, but we propose even more. We propose the creation of a European Development Fund for Africa and Declare that Poland wants to participate more in such assistance – in giving such a fishing dish rather than fish – than would be the result of the proportion of our GDP. And it's not just a declaration. This is what we have done in the context of our participation in the European Resilience Initiative built by the European Investment Bank.  The European Union is the greatest achievement of post-war Europe. The strategy for success for the next decades is a strategy of a renewed European contract, including in terms of prosperity and security. That is why, now, a few words about the third point that I have said, namely the socially just Union of citizens. We must not forget one more fundamental principle on which our community is based – social justice. This principle, as the guiding principle of Polish state policy, is established – and already in its initial articles – by both the Polish Constitution and the Treaty on European Union. These are not just empty words. There can be no question of the development of our societies without fighting inequality, with exclusion, with poverty. It is also in order to combat these inequalities that it is so important that we pursue an ambitious social policy. What has been achieved in Poland over the last 2.5 years shows that paradigm shift is possible and that the implementation of a tailor-made development strategy is now delivering excellent results. Today, Poland has the lowest unemployment rate in history – less than 4% according to Eurostat. Public debt fell last year for the first time in 30 years. The budget deficit is shrinking and at the same time we are running the most ambitious social policy since the victory of Solidarity and the fall of communism. At the same time, we are cutting red tape for businesses and citizens, reducing taxes, but only for small and medium-sized businesses – not for the big ones – and rebuilding effective financial policies by fighting tax fraud mafias and by effectively sealing the fiscal system. Moreover, we have created the largest public innovation support system in Central Europe. Thus, the new democratic capitalism in Polish is innovation plus solidarity. Globalisation, together with the progressive liberalisation of world trade, has become a driver of economic development and, as a whole, certainly does not deserve to be condemned, but economic growth does not translate proportionally into an increase in middle-class incomes. The answer is therefore not protectionism. Investment in human capital is the right instrument to combat inequalities. Education today is the main determinant of future earnings. The need to invest in human capital is directly linked to the second challenge we face: automation and robotics. Of course, I do not want to call for a new 'ludism' in the 21st century edition and to block innovation – on the contrary – but the fear of this technological unemployment is and this problem must be solved. This technological advance will, of course, create demand for new professions, but they will have a different character than those in the past. In almost all cases, they will require high skills. These require adequate level of education. Moreover, as a result of robotisation, the importance of capital as a means of production increases immeasurably compared to the importance of work. As a result, income from capital is evenly distributed evenly than income from work. Worldwide, the share of wages in GDP has fallen by 5-10% since the 1980s, sometimes more. As Piketty shows, wealth is already concentrated and its concentration will increase as a result of further investments. Therefore, these digital technologies have led to the creation of a winner takes all distribution model. It consists in the fact that fewer beneficiaries take over a larger part of the profit. The digital age, the platform economy have created incredible potential for monopolization. The network effect has become the dominant factor, resulting in the emergence of global giants that have no competition. The need to tackle growing inequalities in the European Union is the strongest argument in the current debate on the European Union budget. I therefore stress: we recognise the importance of new policies and challenges, but their financing should not come at the expense of cohesion policy, which is the fundamental, Treaty and essence of the European Union. Dear! Polish example, over the last 2.5 years, shows that the right strategy can change social and economic reality. The European Union can once again become a symbol of the European dream. However, this will only happen if we make the right choice, when we overcome the disputes that divide us, and we will always remember that, despite these disputes, we also share a European identity. Recently, in this Parliament too, we have heard important words about European sovereignty. So! Europe should be an entity in the world of global business. Europe should be strong to better defend our interests. However, European sovereignty cannot mean building the Union at the expense of the strength of the Member States, because the power of a sovereign Europe comes from the strength of the Member States. Weak Member States, nations living in a sense of disregard for their opinions and interests, are a recipe for a Union that will not care about anyone, which is becoming a problem, not a solution to our problems. Poland will do everything to ensure that such a scenario is not implemented. European cooperation is an important dimension for all of us to build prosperity, solidarity and security. In the words of my great compatriot John Paul II, we can find what happened at the source of a united Europe. It was he who spoke of the two lungs of Europe and the fact that both these lungs, eastern and western, are equally important for the Old Continent. Dear! The European Union is still an open book. Each of us has at least one page to save. The Union is not a finite work. Walter Hallstein, the first head of the Commission of the European Economic Community, compared the then community to a living organism that was constantly evolving and evolving in 1963 under the title "Europe under construction". Following this trail, we should not give in to any form of determinism that would make us see only one future of the European Union, forcing us to simply transfer competences from the national level until a super state is created. The Union is a legal and international experiment that allows us to find solutions that have not yet been available within nation states. Discussion, cooperation, coordination and negotiation are the real DNA of the European project. And on the basis of such rules, their founding fathers De Gasperi, Adenauer, Schuman and Jean Monnet formed the foundations for economic communities. Therefore, we should not engage in a kind of genetic engineering that changes the essence of the Union, but should constantly seek new methods of cooperation that will guarantee the security and development of our countries and the well-being of our societies. European integration has never been an end in itself. After all, it is intended to ensure peace, prosperity, development, democracy and justice for the peoples of Europe. The European Community is on a cusp where it must listen again to the voice of its citizens. To conclude, I would like to stress that we must hear and understand the causes of the concern in this voice of citizens, and hear the hope that these citizens in Europe still have and from which they expect security, development, respect and solidarity. They want a Europe open to citizens, giving opportunities for development for all and solidarity with the weak, a Europe united in the face of common threats and challenges, respecting the will of the peoples. The European Parliament is the best institution to understand and express this voice for the benefit of the free peoples of Europe and for the good future of the European Union. Thank you very much. (Applause)

name: Valdis DOMBROVSKIS
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, speaking on behalf of President Juncker who cannot be here today, allow me to start by thanking Prime Minister Morawiecki for taking part in today’s debate on the future of our Union. It is an honour for me to be here. Poland is a country with which I have a close affinity and I say this partly because I have some Polish roots myself. My last name is, in fact, a Latvian version of ‘Dombrovski’, a name synonymous with your country, your history and even your national anthem, Mr Morawiecki. Throughout my life and career I have always been full of admiration for Poland and its people. As Prime Minister, I made it a point to deepen our partnership, which goes back long into history. People of my age in Latvia, and right across the Baltic Sea region, grew up inspired by Polish workers, students and intellectuals who had formed the Solidarnosc movement to fight for change. It is thanks to these values, to this courage and to the determination of your people that Poland took its rightful place at the heart of the European Union. Since then, Poland has given so much to Europe. Since we are in this Chamber, it is only right to mention Bronisław Geremek, a great Polish patriot who worked tirelessly for European integration. He was both an architect of Polish freedom and a builder of Europe. I also think of Marie Skłodowska Curie, who has lent her name to one of Europe’s most successful programmes for young researchers. I could mention many more examples to show how Poland has shaped our Union, and this is why it is so important for Europe to keep its solidarity pledge to Poland. Europe has shown its solidarity in many different ways. For instance, Poland was allocated EUR 86 billion in the current EU budget for European structural and investment funds – far more than any other country. This has helped to build, for example, 13 000 km of roads and allowed more than nine million people to gain access to high-speed internet. These investments are paying off. Poland’s economy has gone from strength to strength. The Polish success story is also built on the benefits of being part of the biggest single market in the world. Every day, Polish companies trade and work with businesses right across our Union. Since 2004, Polish exports have tripled, with 80% of exports going to other EU countries. Europe will keep supporting and showing solidarity in the future. In our proposals for the next long-term budget, Poland will continue to receive the most cohesion funding, even though the total amount will be somewhat reduced, to EUR 72.7 billion, which works out at EUR 270 per person per year – more than double the EU average of EUR 120. That investment will be focused in areas where there is the biggest potential for Poland, whether it be innovation, small and medium-sized businesses or renewable energies. At the same time, Europe must also continue to make good on its promise on security and prosperity. That is why we focusing our proposals for the new Multinational Financial Framework on areas where we can achieve more together, and which are also crucial to Poland’s future. For example, we want to spend 22 times as much on defence as we currently do, with EUR 13 billion allocated to the European Defence Fund, for which Poland has been a strong advocate. This strengthens our ability to act, avoids duplicate structures and saves taxpayers’ money. At the same time, we also want to invest in our future growth. We have proposed to increase our current investments in digitalisation and networks by a factor of nine, to EUR 12 billion. We are also strengthening our currency by firmly anchoring the euro area in the EU budget. We are holding discussions with all EU Member States, not just those which have already introduced the euro, on how best to strengthen our economic and monetary union. We are using new budgetary instruments to support all countries, including those Member States on the road towards euro membership. This will be done in a fully inclusive and transparent way and I look forward to working with Poland across all these areas. Honourable Members, as we look to our future, Poland’s place should be firmly at the heart of our Union. This was the choice made by almost 80% of Poles in the referendum almost exactly 15 years ago. On that day the Polish people made a free, clear and decisive choice. They chose peace and democracy and they chose the values and fundamental rights that define our Union, as they define the people of your great country, Mr Morawiecki. At the heart of that lies respect for the rule of law. The law is our best tool to defend our freedoms, to work for social justice, to settle differences peacefully and to protect the most vulnerable in our societies. The justice system is a guarantor of our democracy and our fundamental rights. It is also what binds our Union together. As Walter Hallstein used to say: ‘The European Union is, at its heart, a community of law’. That community is the foundation of everything we have achieved and everything we still have to do together. This is why, if there is a systemic threat to the rule of law, we cannot simply turn a blind eye; we cannot simply say it is purely a national issue. So, where the separation of powers is weakened in one country, or where the independence of the judiciary is challenged in another, it becomes a European issue which affects our whole community. (Applause) This is why, through the tireless work of Frans Timmermans, the Commission has worked closely with the Polish Government to address the concerns on a number of new laws which pose a systemic threat to the rule of law. Dialogue always comes first, and dialogue has shown that progress can be made. The Prime Minister and his Government have shown willingness to amend the laws on a number of issues, for instance on the retirement age of judges. On behalf of the Commission, I thank him for his effort and his cooperation. We always remain open to dialogue but, so far, it has not been enough. I hope that last week’s hearing will lead to further changes in Polish legislation, and that we will not see 40% of the Supreme Court judges replaced. (Applause) European will never turn its back on Poland or on the Polish people. The Commission will always stand up to support them, and our hands will always be outstretched to the Polish Government. Prime Minister, the Commission counts on your leadership to continue working with us and delivering the real changes needed. Poland has shown how strong its leadership can be in our Union and in the world. We will see this again in December, when Katowice hosts the United Nations Climate Conference – COP24 as it is known. It is more important than ever for Europe to lead from the front in the fight against climate change. We are doing that by focusing on green and sustainable investment. Through our capital markets union and sustainable financial action plan we want to unlock a systemic change in investment culture so that sustainability comes first. Here again, Poland has shown that there is a way. In 2016, Poland became the first sovereign to issue a green sovereign bond. Through this leadership and climate diplomacy, Poland is helping to send a message that the Paris Agreement is here to stay, and that Europe is here to lead. Katowice is itself an example of that: it is a region historically reliant on coal and heavy industry, which is turning itself into a leader in innovation, sustainable investment and new technologies. I can think of no better priority for the future of our Union than the health of our planet and the health of our economies. Poland must be at the heart of these efforts and must stay at the heart of our future. As Marie Skłodowska Curie said, ‘Nothing in life is to be feared, it is only to be understood.’ Now it is time to understand more, so we may fear less. This applies as much today as ever: it applies to Poland, Europe and our common future. (Applause)

name: Manfred WEBER
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, I would like to say to the Prime Minister that Europe is always about dialogue and that is why it is good to have him here to discuss the future of Europe with Poland. It was absolutely not Europe that brought democracy to Poland, but it was Poland that brought democracy to Europe with the first modern codified constitution in Europe in 1791. The principle of the separation of powers was included in this first constitution.  For these principles the Polish people stood really strong, even in dark times: the Second World War and during the oppression by the Soviet Union. John Paul II said in Warsaw, when standing in Victory Square in 1979, that there could be no just Europe without the independence of a democratic Poland marked on the map. More than 10 million people – a quarter of the population of Poland – were members of Solidarnosc. Together with Lech Wałęsa, they fought for freedom and democracy and they laid all the groundwork for a free and open, unified and democratic Europe. That is why we believe in a Poland that is based on the ideas of Lech Wałęsa and John Paul II. We admire what they did for Poland and for Europe.  (Applause) But today, Prime Minister, there are so many questions on the table from people all over Europe, and in your country where yesterday there were demonstrations on the streets. There are so many questions on the table: for example, the question why is state TV in Poland today more a propaganda TV and not a free, independent media anymore? Why does your Government dismiss churches because of their political opinion? You referred to Walter Hallstein. He would be very surprised to see that today nobody knows whether the President of the Supreme Court of Poland is still in office or not. We have uncertainty there. Nobody knows exactly what the situation is today.  Why did another Member State have to refer to the European Court of Justice on a court case, fearing that Polish citizens do not enjoy the right to a free and fair trial in your country? Why is this happening and why do peaceful protesters, like Władysław Frasyniuk, face imprisonment for carrying roses, while nationalists who attack peaceful protesters are not even facing trial? Those are the questions on the table.  (Applause) I think you missed an opportunity today to clarify these questions. Europe is together here. You missed an opportunity today to clarify these questions. The founder of the free and democratic Poland, Lech Wałęsa, said recently that in the 1980s there was no freedom without solidarity and today, he said, there is no freedom without the rule of law. The rule of law is in the very roots of Poland and in the hearts of the Polish people. Europe will not turn its back on the Polish people. If the Polish Government does not preserve the great Polish achievements, Europe will do so. There is another Poland. There is a Poland of the demonstrators, the people in Poland who went out onto the streets. There is a Poland which welcomes 18 million tourists, who enjoy the freedom of movement, tourists who admire Poland and the culture of your great country. There is a Poland which welcomes 4 000 NATO soldiers with the idea of protecting our European Union together. There is another Poland, and sometimes I wonder myself whether you speak here as a PiS Government or whether you speak here as a Polish Prime Minister? Do you really have this second Poland in mind? I also want to welcome some of these NGOs here on the Tribune. They were invited by Michał Boni, so my thanks to him for that. Having all this in mind, you talk about sovereignty. I want to ask you whether, when we talk about sovereignty and winning back sovereignty, is then the anti—EU atmosphere which has been created in Poland – in a way saying that Brussels is the new Moscow – is this really creating an atmosphere of sovereignty for Poland? When you talk about the content, and I completely agree with a few of the things – a Marshall Plan for Africa, and so on – and when you talk, for example, about taxation and about the initiatives you want to take on this, do you really think that your approach of an EU of the nations is really something which can work?  When you have the unanimous vote in the taxation field in mind, we see that in the Council a lot of initiatives – good initiatives – are blocked because there is always one single Member State blocking everything, on taxation and so on. Do you really think that such a Europe will work? I tell you that when you talk about the EU of 4.0, a new Europe, which listens to the citizens, there is already a Europe which is listening to the citizens and that is this Chamber, the European Parliament. We represent the citizens of the European Union.  (Applause)  We don’t need another Europe. I think our Europe is already working very well. Yesterday, the Bulgarian Presidency was present here. Boyko Borissov, a colleague of yours, was present and gave us an overview of what we have achieved together in the last six months in the interests of the citizens of the European Union. Again, in the Council meetings last week, we experienced that the nation states can no longer find a common ground to go further. That is why I strongly believe that the European Union, which was founded by Adenauer – you referred to this – and which is based on the institutions at European level, this Europe works, and the Europe of egoism and nationalism cannot deliver in the interests of the people of the European Union.  (Applause) Let me say a final word. I want to conclude with a personal remark. Prime Minister, because of your PiS governmental propaganda, I never took the floor here in this House when we spoke about Poland, because I was afraid that my German background could be misused to attack my friends in Poland and others who are fighting there for the rule of law and freedom; that it could be used as, ‘the Germans are telling us’. We have sometimes experienced this in Poland: ‘the Germans are telling us’. I was afraid to take the floor here, and I want to tell you that I am not speaking here as a German Member of the European Parliament. I am speaking here because 219 colleagues voted for me as group leader of this Group. I want to fight for the interests of the citizens of the European Union. That is what we have to do, not to decide between good and bad Europeans. Let’s discuss the future of this continent. Let’s stick together. Let’s not be divided anymore. That would be a great message if we were to hear this from a Polish Prime Minister.  (Applause)

name: Udo BULLMANN
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, I would like to start by saying to the Prime Minister, welcome to the European Parliament. Mr Prime Minister, you said that we started from different places in recent European history. Yes, this is true. You quoted Pope Jean Paul II: ‘the eastern lung, the western lung’. Yes, I can very much identify with this picture. I would add that we are still one body and we need both the eastern part and the western part. But the question on the table today is: what is the Polish contribution to the eastern lung functioning well?  Today, the President of the Constitutional Court in Poland, Judge Małgorzata Gersdorf, went back to work. I sent her the greetings of the European Parliament and I sent her the greetings of Europe, because she is obviously paying tribute to the Polish Constitution.  (Applause) She is obviously full of this democratic enlightenment you were talking about. Today, as yesterday, people in Warsaw have massively taken to the streets to express their right to freedom. They are obviously full of this freedom gene you were talking about. This is important. We want to see a healthy Poland contributing to this eastern lung, and we are waiting for you to give answers to the questions expressed by colleagues, expressed by the Commission, expressed especially by our friend Frans Timmermans, whom we fully support.  On a lot of issues you rightly raised questions where we can fully agree – the future of Europe; questions on industrial politics, on the future of cohesion, talking about cultural diversity, security politics, energy security – and rightly so. But why is it necessary to raise these questions and at the same time undermine the European values on which our new project of the European Union is based? You cannot do that at the same time as raising questions on the future and appealing to the unity of the West, which is a values-based unity, and at the same time hope that we can collaborate in the best interests of our citizens. No. Poland has to come back to the centre of the European Union and you have to contribute to our values and to their development in the best interests of our citizens.  Herr Premierminister! Lassen Sie mich dennoch auch an dieser Stelle etwas sagen als jemand, der ein deutscher Sozialdemokrat ist. Wie der Kollege Weber bin ich gewählt von den Freundinnen und Freunden hier in meiner sozialdemokratischen Fraktion als der Sprecher dieser sozialdemokratischen Fraktion, als der Vorsitzende. Sie haben keine Vorstellung davon, wie dicht die Zukunft der polnischen Gesellschaft, wie dicht die Zukunft der Bürgerinnen und Bürger Polens nicht nur uns deutschen Sozialdemokraten, sondern allen Kolleginnen und Kollegen in meiner Fraktion am Herzen liegt – den polnischen Freunden, den deutschen Freunden, aber auch allen anderen aus meiner Delegation. Wir wollen Polen in der Mitte Europas haben! Wir wollen, dass Sie Ihren Beitrag leisten, aber zerstören Sie nicht die demokratische Kultur in Ihrem Land, und kommen Sie zurück an den Tisch, um unsere Werte gemeinsam weiterzuentwickeln: die Rechte der Frau, die Rechte der Minderheiten, die Rechte der Menschen in Ihrer Gesellschaft! Dann werden wir Sie willkommen heißen als jemanden, der uns hilft, die Zukunft zu bauen. (Beifall)

name: Ryszard Antoni LEGUTKO
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, as you can see, or hear, this Chamber is hopelessly predictable. The title of your speech, Prime Minister, was ‘The Future of Europe’ but apparently no one is interested in the future of Europe here. They are indulging in their favourite pastime, which is Poland-bashing. You could just as well have recited Shakespeare sonnets and you would have had exactly the same effect. You can see how it is difficult to get through with arguments, because there is a thick wall of lies, half-lies, half-truths, mystifications – like this ridiculous story about arresting a man for carrying roses. It just boggles the mind when you hear something like it. Every day we have to deal with such idiotic stories that are absolutely groundless. This also shows that this Chamber is, as I have said before, completely resistant to listening to arguments. You never hear counterarguments. You hear heckling, booing and mud-slinging. That’s the usual reaction. There is what I would call a very deep refusal to know, here in this Chamber. I can continue, making a more general point. You were talking, Prime Minister, about a democratic awakening in Europe. Yes, there is a democratic awakening. At the same time, there is an increasing number of people who say that the European Union is going in the wrong direction. It’s over 40% now – in some countries above 50%. I have come here and I have listened to self-indulgent and self-serving comments – ‘We are so good’, ‘We are so responsive to citizens’. So are all these people insane? Are they all being fooled by some demagogues? No! The reaction of these people is the final effect of what is being said and done here. This arrogance, this self-serving arrogance, is simply becoming more and more unacceptable. So, yes, when I hear about the separation of powers in Poland, the problem of the separation of powers, I think: ‘Come on!’ Here we have a Commissioner, a Commissioner who is representative of the executive body, and the Commissioner is telling the Polish Parliament and the Polish courts what to do with this and that law, or how this law should be changed. Is that an example of the separation of powers? It is a blatant violation of the separation of powers. (Reaction to off-mike comments by Mr Verhofstadt) You see! That’s debate, European Parliament style. I suggest, Mr President, that you start putting order in your own house. Yesterday, we were prevented from having an exhibition on Jósef Pilsudski, one of the founders of Polish independence. That is censorship – and not for the first time. There is a well-established practice of censorship in this Parliament and you seem to be quite serene about it. You do not really care because this censorship serves the interest of the majority. People are being punished here. Fortunately, recently the Court reversed the decision of the European Parliament. But that continues. So I suggest, before the finger-pointing at Poland starts, this House should be made more open, please, and a more receptive place for all points of view to be debated and considered. That is my request. I know it has no chance whatsoever, but I just had to say it. (Applause)

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Mr Legutko, since you called me into question in the Korwin-Mikke affair, I would like to remind you that I did not impose a sanction on the Member in question because he was Polish. As you know, I have never, ever done any favours to one group rather than another, to one Member rather than another. I have always treated all Members of this House in the same way: those who voted for me and those who did not vote for me. You said it was an attack on the Poles. I have penalised Mr Korwin-Mikke and I am of little interest to what the Court decides: take any action against me! I find it unacceptable for a Member of this House to say that a woman is a inferior being simply because she was born a woman! I'm never going to let that happen! I am not interested in the Court of Justice: I do not accept the judgment! I respect you, but I do not accept it! How can I not accept anyone say that he is a inferior being because he is Jewish, because he is Christian, because he has the skin of another color or because he is Polish! All human beings are equal, and I say this – because I know you are a Christian – as a practising Catholic Christian. So there is no polemical attitude towards the Poles and Poland.  I respect all Polish citizens. Korwin-Mikke was Polish. For me it could have been Italian, French, German, Luxembourgish: I would have had the same attitude. Since I heard that you said that there had been a negative attitude towards the Poles, I say absolutely no! For my part, there has never been any negative attitude towards the Poles. That must be clear! Please, let us move on with the debate. Please, Mr McWhat is the problem? Tell me...

name: Dobromir SOŚNIERZ
text: "I wanted to refer to these words as the successor of Janusz Korwin-Mikke. The Lord is responsible for breaking the law. You should resign. The law has been broken. Polish member has been wrongly persecuted here and it must not be the case that no one is responsible for this. They have to drop their heads here. You should resign. In public, you have broken the law demonstratively, and you are still insisting on it. It is not a question of whether you agree with my statement or not, but the Member has a mandate and has the right to say what he likes and to express his or her opinion. You are still mischievously twisting his words. You do not have the right to do so and, as President, you should remain neutral.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: I have always been neutral, Mr McKenna! If she likes to roll heads, I don't like rolling any heads. It is not my intention to drop any head: I claim what I have done as a person, as a human being: for me women are beings like everyone else and Mr Korwin-Mikke has said unacceptable things!

name: Guy VERHOFSTADT
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, as the Prime Minister can hear, this is a real Parliament. I have spoken about Poland in this plenary so many times that today I am going concentrate more on the future of the European Union. Yesterday, Mr Morawiecki, in a debate with your compatriot Donald Tusk, I said that more and more people are realising that, when we talk about the future of the European Union, a new world order is emerging. In this new world order, Europe is on its own more and more. Let’s recognise that. There is Putin, who is on a warpath; there is the Chinese leader who has nominated himself as emperor for life; and there is Trump, who is openly questioning the transatlantic relationship and, by doing so – let us recognise it, and I think you can also recognise it – is putting the security of the European continent at risk. That is the main reason – and although you didn’t go into that proposal, I think you can agree with it – why we need a European Defence Community, as soon as possible. And let there be no misunderstanding, Prime Minister, we need it not as a body to compete with NATO but as a European pillar of NATO, to strengthen NATO, and also to give Europeans the possibility of acting on their own. However, we should know that the European Defence Community means much more than being in favour of simply pooling a number of military budgets, a number of tanks or a number of aircraft. A European Defence Community is primarily about defending European territory and defending European interests with European lives. That means that a European defence community, as such, can only work on one condition, namely that we share the same European values, the same European democratic principles, the same rule of law, and the same rules of the game that are fundamental in our society. Only then can such a defence community work in the future and defend our interests. So the future of the European Union, Prime Minister – and this is my message to you – is more than an internal market, more than a single currency, and more even than the free movement of people. Let me put it very bluntly: it is a community of values, and I have to tell you openly that putting judges under political control plays no part in these values. You have to know that. (Applause) That is not a question of tradition, if I may say so. I like traditions, but it is not a question of tradition. It is a question of principles and of our common community. Prime Minister, do not misunderstand me: reform of the judiciary is certainly a legitimate goal, but forcing judges to retire and delivering them to the will and the whim of the governing majority can never be part of such a reform. Over the past three years, the Polish Government has systematically liquidated democratic checks and balances. It was not this Parliament but rather the Venice Commission which said, loudly and clearly, that your reforms – and I am now quoting the Venice Commission, of which Poland is a part – ‘bore a striking resemblance with the institutions which existed in the Soviet Union and its satellites’. I think that what they said sums it all up.  So, instead of what is happening now – rejecting two infringement procedures, ignoring the verdicts of the European Court of Justice – I use this occasion, Prime Minister, to appeal to you personally. You were a youngster who engaged with Solidarnosc. You were part of the team which directly negotiated the accession of Poland to the European Union. So I ask you personally: turn the wheel, and bring Poland back into the family of democratic nations, away from the illusion of so—called ‘illiberal states’, and bring Poland back into the centre of European politics again, instead of letting it linger at the fringes. This dream of an ‘Intermarium’, the 12 central and eastern European countries from the Baltic to the Black Sea working together, is a mirage. It is an illusion. Even, Germany, Prime Minister, is a small nation today, although many Germans may not recognise it. In a world of empires – Russia, China – it is only together that we can do it, and I have to tell you it is a big mistake to think we can divide our Union into regional clusters. To conclude, I believe that division in Europe – as is now to some extent the case, let’s be honest – is welcomed by only one man, one autocrat, Vladimir Putin. Poland knows better than any other country what the fate of our continent is if the Tsar of Russia or the Comrade in the Soviet Union is running the game in Europe. Don’t play it. (Applause)

name: Ska KELLER
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, I would like to thank the Prime Minister for joining in this debate on the future of Europe. I want to stress that the Verts/ALE Group and I share the criticism on the rule of law that you have heard from almost all the Groups. You can see that Parliament is pretty united on that issue and I don’t think it’s going to change. You might say you do not care what other people think about you. But I think you should care. It has been mentioned by the Commissioner already how important Poland is in Europe, and also how important Europe is for Poland, Poland being one of the biggest Member States in the EU. Polish people have a very positive image of the EU and actually trust European institutions more than they trust the Polish Government. The EU contribution to Poland’s economy, in terms of many euros going every year to farmers, organisations and businesses, has been mentioned. Many Polish citizens work elsewhere in the European Union. In fact, Poland has actually the highest number of migrants to other EU countries. You mentioned Brexit, Prime Minister, which will hit Poland hard, and you mentioned Russia. That’s why you should care. But also, we care. The whole of Europe has much to thank Poland for. Poland was the first country on our continent with a modern constitution. You practically invented the division of powers, and that is actually then a Polish tradition – the separation of powers. Poland also has a long tradition of civil movements for freedom and democracy, from resistance against the German occupation to the Solidarnosc movement, which was the first opposition movement to participate in free elections in a Soviet-bloc nation since the 1940s. That is a tradition to be proud of. It gave hope to so many people all over Europe. Poland could be a shining example of democracy and the rule of law, but your Government, Prime Minister, is taking Poland away from the path of democracy and civil rights. You undermine the independence of courts, you put judges into retirement, you put judges under increasing political pressure, and you put people into prison who you think are not following your ideas. You try to control political discourse and threaten the freedom of the media. The rule of law and democracy are crucial for the future of Poland and they are also crucial for the future of Europe. They are at the very heart of our Union. Therefore, as the European Union all together, we have to respond clearly and strongly to what is happening in Poland. We Greens fully support the Article 7 procedure and we are also very grateful to the Commission for starting an infringement procedure in order to stop the Supreme Court Act. People wanted to join the EU, and still want to be part of it, because they believe in the rule of law. They believe in democracy. They believe in good governance. People in Poland are protesting against the dismissal of judges; they are standing up for women’s rights. There are people marching against corruption in Europe. They carry the blue flag of the European Union because they believe that the European Union is the body that can help and support them, the body that will stand up for them. We are proud of the people taking to the streets to stand up for their rights, their democracy and their rule of law. Those people are Poland too. Furthermore, they are Europe too. We need to support them because the rule of law and democracy really is the cornerstone of the European promise in Poland, as elsewhere in Europe, and it is something that we, as MEPs, have to deliver on. It is the promise of the EU and we have to deliver on that. That is why we, as Greens, and also we in the whole Parliament, will never give up on these issues – especially since you keep adding new ones, like changing the law for the European Parliament elections, making it practically impossible for any smaller parties to enter the European Union. The future of Europe really is in your hands, too, as is the future of the planet, in Katowice: unfortunately you did not even mention in your speech the very important conference taking place there. You could actually bring something to that, namely the idea that the transition for climate protection also needs to be fair, that social rights need to be protected as well. Why don’t you bring that to the table? Then you could really be a forerunner on climate change, aiming to protect all of our planet, in Katowice and beyond. You would even find allies in this House. On many issues, such as Brexit, the rights of Polish workers abroad, even Nord Stream, and social cohesion, you would find many allies. But if you want cooperation, Prime Minister, then you have to stick to the basic rules of this Community, a Community that so many of your compatriots have worked so hard to build and to join: and that means the rule of law and democracy. You will have to deliver on that.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, Mr Morawiecki, from your speech it would seem that you are living a reality and your country is living a very different one.  In this House we have adopted by a large majority several Resolutions that warn them of the flagrant breach of Article 2 of the Founding Treaty, because their ultra-conservative, xenophobic and sexist government is adopting reforms that annihilate democracy and freedoms in their country. Amnesty International reminds us that his government remains committed to controlling the judiciary, the right of assembly, the functioning of NGOs, freedom of the media, sexual and reproductive rights or the right to asylum.  You are generating the breeding ground for social conflict, which you then try to tackle with the same recipe: a law against freedom of assembly, which is leading hundreds of people to face criminal sanctions for participating in peaceful —yes, peaceful— meetings and defending human rights.  A new anti-abortion law was debated in Poland on Monday, which will further limit access to a legal and safe abortion: a project involving depriving women of medical care to have abortions, even in the event of severe foetal malformation, when official statistics show that 96% of legal abortions are performed for these reasons. Massive demonstrations during black fridays managed to park this reform in 2016 and, on Monday, women have once again demonstrated their strength and determination.  You can't keep playing with women's lives, Mr Morawiecki: listen to them, though maybe the church bells won't let you hear.  And if we talk about the right to asylum, you refused to participate in the 2016 relocation plan; make summary refunds to Belarus which the European Court of Human Rights orders them to cease. Yesterday, the European Commission opened infringement proceedings for non-compliance with the Treaties and the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the Union for their reforms of the judiciary.  Is this what you want for your country, Mr. Prime Minister? Do you want to go down in history as the prime minister who ended the division of powers, with freedom of expression, with freedom of manifestation, with the rights of women, refugees and LGTBI people?  We live times of double standards, double truth and double accounting, said the writer Vázquez Montalbán. Poland is now a very clear example of this: the european institutions themselves, relentless against Greece for asking for a restructuring of its public debt, are allowing xenophobic governments to continue to cut democratic freedoms.  From this group we stand in solidarity with all those who fight in Poland for democratic, civil and sexual freedoms and call on the Commission to apply real and effective sanctions that contribute to a rectification of government authoritarianism, because we believe in one Europe — another Europe, yes — where, contrary to what happens today, economic policy can be discussed and freely debated, but the most basic human rights are unquestionable.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Mr Legutko, I probably did not quite understand the interpretation during your speech, but the substance as to the objectivity of my behaviour and parliament's behaviour is certain. If you were referring to the exhibition dedicated to General Piłsudski, which I also consider a hero, this exhibition was not authorized because the documentation arrived late, so it was not cancelled. As soon as the documentation arrives at the responsible Commissioner, Mr Syr. Bearder, the exhibition will be authorized because, I repeat, he is also a hero to me. So there is no punitive attitude towards Poland. On what I have said about Mr Mas's report, i.e. the question of what has been said, i.e. Korwin-Mikke, I apologise if you did not refer to it, but it concerns my position on the Korwin-Mikke affair, which remains what I said.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, I would like to welcome Mr Morawiecki to this debate on Europe. In order to understand the future, we need to look a bit at the past. From 1949 onwards, there were two models in Europe. On the western side of the Iron Curtain we had the model of the Anglo-Saxon USA western liberal democracy where peace was kept by NATO, and on the eastern side, where you had the misfortune to be, you had the communist tyranny model. Now the Germans lost the shooting war but they did not lose their ambitions.  Nazi Germany left us a legacy. Back in I think it was 1942 when the Germans thought that they were going to win the war, they wrote a plan for how they were going to govern their new empire, and it was called the ‘Europäische Wirtschaftsgemeinschaft’, the ‘European economic community’. They were going to have interest rates linked to the Reichsmark. They were going to have a common agricultural policy, a common industrial policy, a common policy for everything.  That plan resurfaced in 1957 as the European Economic Community, and Mr Dombrovskis naively mentioned Walter Hallstein, the first President of the European Commission, who was a lawyer who had happily worked for the Nazis. How have things progressed since? Of course, communism collapsed in the East, thank God, and your countries eventually asserted their freedom. In the West what happened? The Europäische Wirtschaftsgemeinschaft progressed into a plan for a United States of Europe.  Where is Europe heading? There are two Europes. There is the Europe that is part of the European Union and there is the Europe that isn’t. Let’s talk about all of it. Those parts of the European Union, where are they heading? They are heading towards a United States of Europe. We see increased integration in everything. We’ve heard about this defence community – I think that’s called an army, isn’t it Mr Verhofstadt, I believe in other countries – we see full economic, political and financial governance being aspired to. The European Union now governs almost every aspect of the citizen’s life. Mr Morawiecki, you mentioned the freedom gene. Well that is very strong in the British and that reasserted itself in 2016 in the vote to leave the European Union. The British people voted to reassert their freedom and their independence. Sadly, that project has not yet been realised. The British people chose freedom over domination in an undemocratic European Union.  Now Poland, you’ve been a member of the European Union for the last 14 years and it was entirely understandable why you joined, along with the other eastern European countries. After languishing under communist tyranny for decades, you needed the financial subsidies from the European Union and you wanted the opportunities for your younger people to be able to work abroad, earn money and improve their lives. All of those things are understandable.  But now things are looking up for Poland. Your economy is picking up and you have personally invited many Poles to come back from their migration abroad and rebuild your economy. But you have discovered that there’s a price to pay for European Union membership: the EU requires you to accept migrants in untold numbers, which would change your country and your culture beyond recognition, as indeed it has already in many parts of Europe.  Not surprisingly, you and your government are opposing that forced acceptance of irregular migrants and refugees, but you’ve been threatened by the EU. If you do not take the migrants then you cannot have the money, and you have found that when you have outside interference in your country from such as multi-billionaire George Soros, who seeks to interfere in your nation’s life, as he does in mine, then the EU tells you that you cannot oppose him. You have learned that if you sell your soul, eventually someone will come to claim it. You can have the rule of law, but you cannot have the rule of your own law. You can only have the rule of this—place law.  You will see in Poland, I believe, in the course of time that it was a wise decision that the British people made to leave. I would ask you that, as we came to your assistance in 1939, you in the Council come to our assistance. Please help us out with the utterly useless and incompetent Mrs May. Please help to facilitate our exit from the European Union in the Council, and return the favour that we did you in 1939. (Applause from certain quarters)

name: Stanisław ŻÓŁTEK
text: On behalf of the ENF Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Mr Morawiecki, i would like to thank you for your comments. When I analyse the last three years of the polish government and parliament, I am tormented by ambivalent feelings. On the one hand, I see that the current government is increasing taxes instead of reducing it. To win electoral votes, he does not hesitate to take one to buy the other. I see that it deprives Poles of personal freedom, giving countless special services increasing powers of surveillance and force. After all, laws such as the Anti-Terrorism Act or the Agricultural Land Act would have been called Bolsheviks 10 years ago. One allows without the consent of the court to eavesdrop on anyone, block bank accounts and websites. It allows, whenever the authority wants, to close everyone for a long time without the possibility of defense, even without giving a reason for embedding. The second prohibits the majority of citizens from selling and buying land without the consent of the authorities. Does it not refer to communist times the current obligation to enter in the register the data of anyone who bought even a minimum amount of gold? I also see that you want to Polish the battleground of the Americans and Russians. By the way, I do not understand this approach, to create an enemy from Russia instead of a friend in the East. Less so. Meanwhile, America is no longer the same as it was 30 years ago, and Russia is not the same. What else did you preach before the election.  But on the other hand, I know that the aim of this European Union is to crush all resistance to the power of the European Commission and to force the citizens of the Union to obey ruthlessly. Hence the bluntness of patriotism, because countries where there is patriotism are hard to enslave. Hence the struggle with family ties, because where there is parental love, the power of officials disappears there. Hence the fight against Christianity, because according to these future rulers of Europe, this is competition for the government of souls. Hence, agreeing to flood Europe with crowds of Muslim immigrants, because if people in Europe are afraid, it will be easier for them to take away their freedom and govern them. This is why this terror of political correctness, the promotion of homosexuality, medding in the internal affairs of other countries. That is why I am wholeheartedly in favour of your government and the Polish Parliament's actions, which are against the Union's plan. I therefore have an extremely important question for the Prime Minister. The European Commission has now prepared a directive on copyright in the digital market. This directive will forever close the mouths of internet users. It will close access to the world's internet. It will give enormous power to the European Commission. The directive will leave citizens of the European Union with only one source of knowledge about the world controlled by the European Commission and national governments – paper newspapers, television and several online portals. I ask the Prime Minister to make a clear statement, not a vague cliché like 'we want there to be as little freedom as possible', and so on. Specifically. If Articles 11 and 13 remain unchanged in this directive, will your Government support the directive in the Council or block it? I think there are many millions of people waiting for your speech.

name: Dobromir SOŚNIERZ
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by It was supposed to be a debate about the future of Europe, but from what I can see, no one but Mr Batten is sticking to the subject here. Everyone is engaged in a rather rude "bingeing" of the Polish government in the absence of any knowledge and competence to do so. An example of total dilettutation is Mr Verhofstadt, who speaks without any knowledge of it. But you have introduced us to such a Union. It was Law and Justice that urged Poles, deceived them, and they benefited greatly from European subsidies. It has introduced us to such a Union that it now still wants to write it into the Constitution even. You put us against a wall and let yourself crawl in front of EU MPs or bureaucrats. The vision of Europe is already decided. Germany and France want one country, one army, one budget, and we either sign up for it or we don't. These are the facts. We won't change anything here, so the sooner we understand it, the sooner we get out of this company, the better for us. You talked about the gene of freedom. People in Poland are now protesting not against the retirement age of judges, because no one in Poland is interested in what you think of the Greens. People are interested in the fate of the Internet Directive. Polish The Ministry of Foreign Affairs, for now, generally supports the direction – it has minor reservations there, but in general it supports the direction in which this directive is going, and if you really do not want you to burn your tongue when you say the words 'gene of freedom', then let you ask that Polish Members, including your party, do not vote here almost every time in favour of further EU directives that restrict freedom , only for them to vote against. Not to mention what is being done against freedom in our own backyard, because talking about the gene of freedom, if at the same time it is forbidden to trade on Sundays or sell agricultural land, is also probably a misunderstanding. And Mr Tajani, I wanted to say that I am not interested in what you accept and what you do not. My mandate to say what I want comes from my constituents, not from you, and you will not tell me what I am allowed to say here and what i am not.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: No one has ever said what you have to say: All I have said is that you cannot roll your heads, because I remember that only under the regimes of Stalin and Hitler did you roll your heads.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Prime Minister Polish. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Dear! Thank you very much here for your votes, thank you very much for this repeated reminder of Solidarity and the fact that Solidarity was so crucial for the overthrow of communism.
