Indeed, I was an activist of Solidarity and I can say that at that time, as a young boy, I experienced very different moments. For example, I do not know if you know that judges of martial law – judges in the 1980s – sentenced my comrades in arms to ten years in prison. A woman, my colleague from the underground – Ewa Kubasiewicz, and many others were sentenced to many years in prison. Some of my colleagues were murdered, many of them were in prison for a very long time. Did you know that these judges of martial law, some of them, those who delivered heinous sentences during martial law, are today in this Supreme Court, sometimes defended by you? Did you know that, Mr Bullmann? Did you know that? There are several judges of martial law who are still there today, so the mention of Solidarity must also include such a reflection that this post-communism has not been overcome with us and we are fighting this post-communism precisely through justice reform. Several people have also mentioned the European Defence Fund and its complementarity with NATO. Thank you very much here to Mr Verhofstadt, who has just developed this thread. Here I fully agree and this is very important for the future of Europe. I was very happy that, with the representative of a group that is theoretically quite far from us politically, including the extremely important dimension of security, complementarity of our activities in PESCO, in the EDF (European Defence Fund), in relation to NATO, we are talking about cohesion, about complementarity. We also look at it very similarly. I would just like to refer to the thought that Mr Verhofstadt also said – I think we are in Poland and in Central Europe badly received. The Tri-Sea Initiative is not intended to compete with the European Union. It is also a complementary initiative, because it is very difficult for many of our partners, friends from Western Europe, to understand our Polish Central European reality, because you were very lucky that you did not live fifty years in communism. You were lucky enough to be on the good side of the Iron Curtain. Unfortunately, life looked very different with us, and the transformation after 1989 assumed that the Communists had entered a new system with a properly dry foot. Therefore, we, looking at the different political dimensions, are trying to throw off this yoke of post-communism. The Tri-Sea is part of the European Union's support in the sense that we want to develop the North-South corridors. Today, Europe is much more built around the East-West corridors, while this potential – Scandinavia, Germany, Poland, Austria, Hungary, Bulgaria, czech republic, Slovakia, Romania and south to Greece – is much less exploited due to the lack of gas, energy, rail and road infrastructure. This is mainly the case with the Tri-Sea Initiative – I think it complements what Mr Verhofstadt said. At the same time, you also referred to the retirement age. Did you know that here – a few hundred metres from here – the European Court of Human Rights introduced in 1998 exactly the same early retirement rule for judges as we are now introducing? That rule was then fully accepted. Today we are doing exactly what we do in many other countries – we are not doing anything else. You also mentioned the Russian danger in a few voices. Thank you for these voices, because although we want to cooperate with Russia, it is not with aggressive Russia – not Russia, which is conquering more countries, which is attacking more countries that are attacking the countries of Europe – the whole of Europe, because that is what we have seen in recent statements by various countries, including western Europe, so pointing to these threats, Nord Stream II, we are not only relying on Eastern European or Central European solidarity, but we warn against threats , which may also exist in western Europe. In our opinion, this is extremely important. Mr Verhofstadt said that "judges are under political control." The judges are much more independent today than they were before, and I will show that to you. Well, when is the judge more independent? When can the president of the court order a judge? When can he choose a judge for a particular case? When can it move between chambers? No – then it has indirect pressure mechanisms. That was the situation before. Did you know that in earlier times one of the judges of the key district courts was ready for the Prime Minister's phone call? It was a journalistic provocation to pick a judge on the Prime Minister's phone in a particular case, and it was the case for the biggest fraud - amber gold's pyramid scheme. Whether you know that this judge was ready to do so then? Today it is impossible – we have strengthened judicial independence, we have strengthened objectivity. Not only that, Vice-President Timmermans acknowledges this. Mr Timmermans acknowledges that the ban on moving judges between chambers, which we have introduced since 1 January this year, also increases judicial independence, increases the objectivity of judgments, increases the fairness of these judgments. Dear Sir, before you speak, look a little deeper – I ask you very much – what is the truth, what is the reality of the rule of law, because judges are more independent today, and the tripartite power. I would also like to thank you very much for this reminder of the Constitution of 3 May, the first constitution on the European continent. This is indeed a big deal and the rights of the women that have just been mentioned here are also very respected with us. Poland is one of the first countries to introduce women's democratic rights in Europe. You also mentioned the media. Are there no free media, the vast majority of which – 80 to 90 percent – present a critical or highly critical view of the situation before power and in view of today's reality? Does this mean that the media is in any way threatened about their freedom? Ladies and gentlemen, the media in Poland are overwhelmingly critical of the government and we absolutely agree with that. We understand that this is the case, albeit very biased the other way around. If you looked at it up close, under the magnifying glass, you'd see it. Does the opposition have any restrictions on access to the media? Do journalists have any restrictions on the selection of topics? Nothing like this is the case, and before we came to power, we had an unprecedented raid by the special services on newspaper editors, including the requisitioning of materials in newspaper editorials. Did you know that? Did this High House say anything when the previous government did? I have the impression that the High House is biased in this regard by the fact that you may not like one government, one government, and others like it. Why didn't you look at what the Polish authorities were doing at the time? This is the reality: one of the leading newspapers, famous for its objectivity but critical of the power of the time, was taken away from the editorial team and granted, through indirect actions, to one of the oligarchs. That is, Poland has moved towards oligarchy in this regard, dear country. At the time, the media was actually almost 100 percent hijacked by one political option. Should freedom of the media be about this? Today, the limits of the judge's work are determined only by professionalism and conscience, but this was certainly not the case before. Our changes have led us to recover EUR 10 billion from the hands of the mafia. You should appreciate this – it is also money that belongs to the Budget of the European Union. Poland is a proud country. Please do not instruct us on such matters. We know very well how to manage our institutions, and because we have changed our approach to tax institutions, we have the best economic situation in 30 years – the lowest deficit, the lowest public debt, the lowest unemployment, one of the highest GDP growth, great economic success – and all this with huge support for our social programmes, huge solidarity support for these social groups. As for the eradication of poverty, we should all be proud of it. Did you know that our government has eliminated extreme child and youth poverty by almost 100 percent – poverty eradicated by 95 percent. No one was interested in it before. We have allocated this money plucked from the hands of the mafia for social purposes. At the same time, this supports our economy, which is something that you would also look at on this side of the political scene – socialists, greens and so on – would be very supportive. I encourage you to look at what our economic model looks like. Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank you for your excellent work Democracy in Poland has never been as alive as it is today. Civil rights are implemented without hindrance, the media are more diverse and pluralised than they used to be. You can say this with certainty – if you look at it, you will see that it is. We are a proud nation and we know best how much freedom costs. Here you have emphasised and thank you for that. We fought for our freedom and yours, we were the first to put a dam on German barbarism during the Second World War and thus save the continent from even greater genocide. We also do not forget our neighbours in the East. We are against closure, there has been less talk of this, but we are very supportive of the process of integration of the Balkans into the European Union, in order to complete as if the whole continent had been integrated. Strength is precisely diversity. We acknowledge our european heritage in its entirety. Our contribution to security is not only about spending highly on defence policy, it is also the Eastern Partnership. I call for us to understand our point of view better, to be able to respect each other. Think about how it is that a huge part of the media, 80-90 percent, is against us. A huge part of business, big corporations, western and home, is against us, a huge part of the European Parliament is probably against us too, and yet we still have such support in a country that far exceeds any support for another party. Maybe there is something deeper in our politics, solidarity on the one hand, and fair on the other hand, seeking to recover those taxes that (a word inable) in the days of our predecessors, also because of poor justice? Did you know that in the days of our predecessors, two judges – a judge of the Supreme Court and a judge of the Supreme Administrative Court – made an appointment with each other about the judgment? You didn't say anything at the time that it was unacceptable. Now to the Commission, Valdis is a friend of mine, with whom I have talked many times on a number of economic and macroeconomic issues, and we agree – monetary union, banking union, the financial crisis are topics that we have discussed many times and we speak virtually the same language in many fields. It is also worth highlighting what the European Commission is saying positive about us: this very positive type of economic growth, the high quality of economic growth with a decreasing deficit and increased tax efficiency. Thank you very much that President Dombrovskis said that we have done a lot for dialogue. I do not know if you have caught it, because we have actually focused on dialogue and have done a lot for dialogue. But I have to think out loud about whether the Commission is this honest broker, as you say, or whether it is this honest broker, because I expected that in a situation of such polarisation as it was in Poland – as it is in Poland, it is true – the Commission will be an honest broker. But I have doubts as to whether this is the case, because, despite the enormous efforts on our side to meet, to implement, for example, those measures which have been strongly suggested by the Commission as to the ordinary courts, and to make a promise that the application to the European Court of Justice will be withdrawn, this has not happened. And did you know that with us the National Council for the Judiciary was elected by a three-fifths majority? Show me a better democratic mandate, where the National Council for the Judiciary is elected by such a majority. From the outset, too, our government and I, as Prime Minister, have tried to have a dialogue with the Commission – I was looking for a compromise. Today I must say that we have come to a point where, having made some changes, we want to reform the justice system so that it is a better justice system for Poland, but also for the European Union as a whole, because weakness is best defined by the numerous shortcomings, imperfections that I have conveyed in our dialogue to President Timmermans and Mr Juncker – they know very well what we have here. Dear! Transatlantic relations were also mentioned here. They are very crucial and I would like to say two more words about them and, finally, about migrants. In the context of transatlantic relations, it is very important to restrained some of the anti-Americanism that is alive in Europe, and for this alliance between Europe and the United States to continue, because I find it difficult to imagine a more viable security guarantor – not only in eastern Europe vis-à-vis Russia, but also in the Middle East – than NATO and we are very supportive of the transatlantic alliance. But perhaps some of you will be surprised – I, too, am most in favour of strengthening Europe – the European Union – as an independent defence force. Only for this we would have to spend 3, maybe up to 4 percent of GDP on defence policy. Meanwhile, Poland is one of the few NATO countries to meet this goal, spending 2 percent. It was also only under our governments that we changed the methodology for calculating. Previously, it had not fulfilled that objective. It is also money taken away from tax criminals and VAT mafias, which we have set up to defend Europe. However, as long as there is no such spending on defence policy, this alliance with the United States is very important and it is not just an anti-American attitude. This is also an anti-European attitude taken by all those who want to subdue the transatlantic alliance. It is an attitude that pleases, as someone here said "tsar", Putin, only Russia enjoys. Let us not go down this path! Dear! Thank you also for stirring up the migration thread. We recognise that it is necessary to help migrants and refugees in their countries of origin as much as possible. I do not know if you know that Poland puts four times more to the funds than our weight in the EU's GDP – to funds such as the European Resilience Initiative or the European Fund for Africa. But it will declare more – we are ready to double this support to countries abroad if there is a similar contribution from other Member States, because it is important to protect the external borders, but also external support, also support through external hotspots – after all, this is an idea that we discussed at the last European Council. We support external hotspots as part of the refugee action, we believe that this must be done. But when it comes to migration, about accepting refugees, also point out that we are weakening some African countries or the Middle East in this way, because the brightest, most enterprising people often leave. By absorbing them into Europe, we are also weakening our ability to reform the economies of those countries, and yet we do not want that. Poland most supports the development of these countries there on the spot. Dear! To sum up this part of our discussion, thank you very much for the voices that have died here. Mr Verhofstadt, in particular, has raised a number of issues relating to the true future of Europe, because we want to play a very positive part in the future of Europe in the areas of defence, innovation and migration. However, it is not good if proud nations are istructed by others, because then there is indeed polarization and clinching, there is a short circuit. We therefore call, on the one hand, for this dialogue that we are conducting – unfortunately, here we have failed a little on the commission's basis. I ask you to compare to those orders of the Member States on the basis of which our reforms were introduced, because what we have done is nothing more than the introduction of solutions that actually exist in western Europe. I stress very strongly that Poland is today a country of economic success thanks to the new socio-economic model that we have adopted, by sealing the tax system and at the same time by opening up to new channels of cooperation, including in terms of innovation, trade, exports-imports, which is europe's strength, and that is what we want to offer Europe, to be a constructive Member State. I think that, contrary to appearances, contrary to the various estrities that are present today, in these coming times, when it occurs – all the time, because we see the earth tremble in the context of national elections – we want to help stabilise the situation, we do not want to be in a position of success with this European boat, because I very much believe that Europe has a future, has great value, but we must respect our national differences, our national experiences and our national successes.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: – Mr President, we cannot have a debate about the future of Europe without reaffirming our founding principles, and we need to reiterate that if the rule of law is under threat anywhere, then it is under threat everywhere.  Either we are a Union where the rule of law reigns or we are no union at all. Because whatever the EU looks like in the future, and whatever the scenario, you cannot be a fit and proper EU member and undermine the judiciary at the same time. Reform by all means but, Prime Minister, what is happening in Poland is not about reform; it is about control, it is about consolidating power by weakening the institutions designed to keep you in check. That is the way of the past.  To so many in Poland and across Europe, including my own country, Malta, the EU represents the fundamental belief, the unshakable certainty, that however different we are as nations and peoples, however much we argue about policy, we share the same core value system. So the Commission is right – absolutely right to take action. It is doing its job as it must everywhere there is a threat. The future of Europe and the future of Poland must be one and the same based on the rule of law.  Prime Minister, it is not too late. Come back from the brink. Come back to the heart of Europe, where Poland belongs. (Applause)

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: – Mr President, I wish to thank the Prime Minister for coming here. I have great respect for the Polish nation. Without Poland, Europe would be a torso. I appreciate your contribution to bringing down the Communist dictatorship without bloodshed. The roundtable is a Polish invention. Poland’s Constitution was a paramount example of the rule of law, and also, with reference to my country, Austria, we were able to learn from the developments in Poland after 1989. This is the reason why I’m concerned at the developments in Poland. What is happening today at the Polish Supreme Court and what you said in an interview with Deutsche Welle, when you assert, I quote: ‘The law is not the most important thing. Human life, security is more important.’  I would ask whether you really said that, and whether you actually want the rule of law in your country or not?

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Unfortunately, it has become apparent that colleagues here in this House, on this side of the Chamber, do not want to talk to us about the future of Europe. They want us to live in our country. Once again, I call for everyone to take care of their own country if we are talking about European standards and values, and then Europe will look different. I appeal here to a colleague from Malta. I just wanted to say that it seems to some in this House that they brought us freedom and democracy and that they should now be its guardians in Poland. But the situation is even worse, and that is why we should talk about the Union, because I sometimes have the impression that some people seem to think that some new form of division, some new curtain, would be needed, which is often the result of fear of our competitiveness and our growing subjectivity. There is an idea, often dressed in pro-European rhetoric, to reduce the Union and Europe itself to the size of a suboptimal monetary area. That is why I wanted to ask the Prime Minister how you see the role of the countries in our region in maintaining what was a great achievement in 1989 – the unity of Europe.

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: – Mr President, I would say to the Prime Minister: you do not listen to the European Parliament. You do not listen to the Venice Commission. You do not listen to the National Council for the Judiciary. You do not listen to NGOs. You do not listen to the people who are protesting in the street and who supported the Polish Supreme Court judge this morning. My question to you is: will you listen to the European Court of Justice when it rules? Do you acknowledge the authority of the European Court of Justice?

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Mr Verhofstadt, I am trying to get all those who have asked for the floor to speak. We already have little time, at 11.30 we have to close, if everyone wants to intervene by also providing an answer.... You will reply at the end of the debate.

name: Judith SARGENTINI
text: Mr Prime Minister, you seem to see this debate here as a lesson to a proud people, that is what you called it. I think we have already caught up with a misunderstanding there, because we are having a debate here with a head of government. A people is not a government, a nation is not a people and a political party is not a government. It is very important to keep all of them apart that if we address a government, we do not address a people or a state here. If that is how you see it, it makes sense that dissident voices get in your way, because you are the state, the nation, the people. You are going to make mistakes, because dissident voices are there to control us all, because we do not have the wisdom on our own, because a society functions better when we share criticism with each other. If you dismiss judges, if you do not allow judges to work independently, abuses are not addressed and corrections to errors are not carried out.

name: Barbara SPINELLI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Prime Minister, you know that this Parliament supports the Commission's decision to activate Article 7(1). There is a risk of serious violation of the rule of law: we say this not to the Polish people but to their government.  Concerns are not just about judicial independence: the European Charter of Rights is ignored in other areas, including the public media, the right to privacy, the right of assembly, and the protection of Caucasian refugees. I also ask you whether you will listen to society's fight against the Stop Abortion Act, which tightens up an already extremely restrictive law. These are the pillars of the Union 4.0: not a return to absolute national sovereignty or ethnically homogeneous sovereignty and, even and even religiously.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Welcome, Prime Minister of Poland. You mentioned earlier that the sovereignty of the European Union must not conflict with the sovereignty of nations. Is the proposal to abolish the principle of unanimity, which will, among other things, turn the European Union into a two- or even three-speed Union, in line with your position above? Your country and some other countries have closed their borders to protect themselves from the waves of illegal immigrants.  This position indicates your intention to change the countries of entry, especially Italy and even more So Greece, into vast camps of unfortunate people. And finally, because Turkey continues to drag illegal immigrants into Greece in waves and threatens the European Union that it will open the floodgates for the invasion of millions of illegal immigrants, if they do not obey its absurd demands, the countries of the European Union. What is your position on the measures to be taken by the European Union towards Turkey? Do you agree that he should take the sanctions he has also imposed on Russia?

name: Ana GOMES
text: – Mr President, as a Portuguese person who lived under totalitarian rule for part of her life, I should like to say to the Prime Minister that I feel a lot of sympathy and admiration for the Polish people and their liberation from totalitarian rule. But I can only share the concerns and the outrage of my colleagues who see the rule of law being put under attack by your Government, Prime Minister. The brave people of Poland have become divided as you have been making slurs against people who are critics of your position – such as some Members of our Parliament, like Róża Gräfin von Thun und Hohenstein, Danuta Maria Hübner and Barbara Kudrycka and other brave women, who have been slurred as anti-patriotic. I believe that the Polish people deserve much better. The Polish people are protesting vibrantly in the streets against the attacks on the rule of the law and basic human rights, in particular the rights of women, and I can only pay tribute to the head of the Supreme Court who went to work today – a brave, patriotic Polish woman.

name: Viviane REDING
text: – Mr President, in addressing the Prime Minister I would like to say to him that you, Mr Prime Minister, are leading a great nation and you are leading a great people and they deserve nothing more and nothing less than a government which respects the democratic institutions for the sake of its own citizens. So why on earth are you dismantling your independent justice? Why don’t you listen to the wise men and women of the Venice Commission, who expressed their deep concerns? Do you still respect the European Court of Justice? You have a responsibility for your country and for your people so, for God’s sake, don’t destroy the democratic basis on which your country is built, and give us back Poland as a reliable, constructive and influential member of the European family. You need it and we need it.  (Applause)

name: Elly SCHLEIN
text: – Mr President, I would say to the Prime Minister that we are very worried about the illiberal choices of his majority.  Three simple messages. This new electoral law that you’re trying to pass on the European election is a clear attempt to kill opposition parties by fixing the natural threshold at 15 to 20%. You are attacking the principle of proportionality and the principle of representation by depriving a lot of Polish citizens of their voices.  On women’s rights, women have a right over their own body. Please stop attacking abortion rights. We strongly support the Czarny protest.  On migration your attitude has been very childish, Prime Minister, because you are talking about cohesion policy – and we all agree about that – but you cannot pick and choose one form of solidarity and refuse the other one. You cannot want only the benefits of belonging to a great union without ever sharing the responsibility that comes with it. So you should support the Dublin Regulation reform that this Parliament adopted with a two—thirds majority.

name: Karol KARSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Dear! Prime Minister, i would like to thank you for your comments. When we talk about the rule of law, there should be some common standards. Mr Timmermans's work lacked that. In order that the voices that are in this House do not sound like hypocrisy, it must be noted, however, that Poland is a country with one of the highest rates of enforcement of judgments of the Court of Justice of the European Union. That it is in Poland that it is possible to demonstrate, and in other EU countries, for example, demonstrations are accelerated by the horse police, as in the country of origin of one of the loudest people speaking out here against Poland. There are countries where, unlike the Polish, there is actual censorship on the media, such as germany, where rapes against women have not been known from the German media for days. Ladies and women, standards have been adopted in Poland that work well in other EU countries. Why is it not claimed in Relation to Spain that the National Council for the Judiciary or the equivalent of such a body in Poland is being improperly elected, since we have precisely moved this model? Why is there no request for article 7 proceedings against Germany, where Supreme Court judges are elected by a committee composed in half of members of the Bundestag and from the Land Ministries of Justice?

name: Helmut SCHOLZ
text: Mr President, Prime Minister, I would like to thank the Prime Minister for his work Together with the Poles, Greeks, The French and others, we have the task of making life fairer, safer and better – collectively and not intergovernmentally. Hence the question to you: how do you intend to strengthen the Community method and not the appropriate haggling with regard to national selfishness in the Council? I have also listened carefully to your ideas about an EU 4.0. The question remains: if there is no binding commitment to common values and objectives, Europe based on solidarity will be left behind. I would have expected you to finally announce here today the withdrawal of Poland's opt-out from the Charter of Fundamental Rights. I would have expected Poland to recognise this EU Charter of Fundamental Rights at last. With this we can grow, overcome social divisions in societies, housing shortages, but above all hatred of dissidents and people living, against asylum seekers. As Rosa Luxemburg once said, unequivocally: individual freedom is a prerequisite for the freedom of all. Let us not forget that!

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: Mr President, Prime Minister, what crimes is Poland accused of? Crime of truth: Poland refuses to submit to the media and their false propaganda. Crime of justice: Poland rejects the mass immigration imposed by Germany for its economic growth. Sovereignty crime: Poland refuses to allow judges the sovereign power of the people, because justice is done in the name of the people.  In short, the EU accuses Poland of being Poland. To resist as it knows how to resist the opposition, to the oppression of the new European order, disorder for our peoples and our nations. The Union accuses it of preserving its identity by opposing the new worldist religion that is destructive of law, justice, individualistic, relativistic, nihilistic, religion opposed to God's right and therefore to human rights.  Poland will remain Poland. She was able to resist Nazi barbarism and communism. Long live Poland!

name: Róża THUN UND HOHENSTEIN
text: – Prime Minister, i would like to thank you for your excellent work. You presented our country, Poland, as a country of bandits, thieves, mafias and other criminal activities that allegedly characterised Poland until two years ago, when your party took power. But – not in our name – not on our behalf, polish citizens are shouting today, who gather thousands before polish courts. They are also in front of the European Parliament and here in the gallery. And here in this House, you listen to people who know very well how much we have achieved with the European Union in recent decades and how your party is destroying it. Members here also know, from recent European history, sometimes from their own tragic experiences, what the destruction of judicial independence can lead to. Prime Minister, i would like to thank you for your comments. You have shown many times that you know how to change the law in one night. Recently, it took you 9 hours 45 minutes to change the inglorious Holocaust law. You still have a chance. Roll back the Laws on the Supreme Court. No one will take this as a symptom of weakness. You have a chance not to write down the mosthyd letters in history.

name: Ramón JÁUREGUI ATONDO
text: – Mr President, Mr Prime Minister, six prime ministers from other countries have already passed through this Parliament. The common denominator of all of them, when talking about the future of Europe, is that we can only do together what we must do together. The idea that the European Union, going forward, needs to share great objectives and must be done together. My question, Mr Prime Minister, is whether you believe that the future of Europe — competitiveness, security, climate change, the fight against tax fraud — can only be done from a state, with that song that you have made to the nation, to the state; if you do not think it is more reasonable to face these great challenges precisely together, building the European Union of the future together. How is it possible to do so only with a chant to the nation and the state?

name: Gunnar HÖKMARK
text: – Mr President, I would like to say to the Prime Minister that for me as a Swede the emergence of Poland as a free and democratic country, with the economic reforms of the 1990s and the achievements in this decade, belongs to one of the most impressive things in European development. We got a new neighbour, a new friend and a new partner in the middle and the centre of European development.  And I would like to underline to you, Mr Prime Minister, that the debate here is not about Poland—bashing. We love Poland. We want Poland to be there but the European Union is a union of laws, and if you are undermining the rule of law you are undermining trust, and you are undermining our strength for the future. Can you promise that you will follow the verdicts of the Venice Commission, the European Court of Justice and all the legal institutions that we have together?  (Applause)

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: – Prime Minister, you have first referred to our Greco-Roman cultural roots and our Christian tradition. This is a historical reality that we are not questioning or discussing today. What we are discussing is whether the rule of law of the European Union, what has the common rules so that all European citizens coexist in a common future, whether this will also be fully respected by Poland.  What we are discussing is whether there can be a European parliamentary democracy without a European rule of law. I shall therefore also mention to you what my colleague Joseph referred to earlier. In a statement, you said that safety is above the law. Unfortunately, this reminds me of another new sultan you have nothing to do with, Erdogan.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: – Mr President, Prime Minister Morawiecki and Minister Szymański must be feeling like they have been thrown into a lion’s pit this morning. We were supposed to discuss the future of Europe here and instead we have had only more or less hysterical reactions against their government. President Tajani did say Europe must change and if he had listened today to the presentation of this Prime Minister he would have seen what kind of change we need.  We don’t need more Europe, we need more Member States and I would like to congratulate you, Mr Prime Minister, for that courage. I think what we do need indeed is a Europe of sovereign nations and I think the idea of a Europe of sovereign nations 2.0 is exactly what Charles de Gaulle wanted, and after Brexit we have only one country in Europe which has this kind of common sense in the government, and that is yours, Mr Prime Minister, and I thank you for it. (Applause)

name: Frank ENGEL
text: – Mr President, I would say to the Prime Minister: it’s fun to talk about European dreams and not participate in European solidarity, isn’t it? You say you would not want to take 6 000 refugees – that’s not a lot for a country of 40 million. You pretend to be a great country, you are a great country, and you would easily be able to accommodate them. Yet at the same time you talk to us about a Marshall Plan for Africa, when Poland is a country which has no development ministry, no development agency and invests 0.1% of its GNI in official development assistance. I don’t think it makes a lot of sense, then, to talk about the Marshall Plan for Africa.  But let’s talk about Poland for a minute. You said we should listen to citizens and to their concerns. I saw tens of thousands of Poles this morning freeing the way for the President of the Polish Supreme Court, Małgorzata Gersdorf, to be able to go back to work and fulfil her constitutional terms of office. It is your government that wants to deprive that courageous lady, and the people who were protecting her on her way to work, of their European endeavour, from being part of European normalcy. That is not a European dream, Prime Minister, that isn’t a dream for a country which deserves the right one.

name: Krystyna ŁYBACKA
text: – Prime Minister, i would like to thank you for your excellent work. You and I come from different political options, but for you and me Poland is our homeland, which is why I am protesting against the great news you made to Poland in the second part of your speech. Please do not devalue Polish the european acquis, simply because it was not your rule. Poland is a country of proud people who deserve to be told that they have worked honestly, have been successful. And now I will be speaking to the first part of your speech – I agree with you that we need more common market. However, you did not mention the single currency in a word. When do you think Poland will join the euro area and when will you start the debate on this issue?

name: Michael GAHLER
text: – Mr President, I would say to the Prime Minister that we seem to have some common positions. I support your position on Nord Stream2 and on Russia in general, on European security and defence, and your claim to engage more in Africa.  I supported the Solidarity movement in the ‘80s, when the Polish Communists denounced us as zgniły Zachód – ‘the rotten West’. Today when I read a translation of programmes on your public TV and radio, I’m getting the impression that we are already close to zgniły Zachód again when we insist on the rule of law and the separation of powers, when respect for your own constitution is demanded.  I wonder, can you explain to me how a simple law can overrule an explicit provision in the Constitution with regard to the duration of the mandate of a judge in the Supreme Court? On the future of Poland and Europe, state capture by a single party is not the future. Are you aware that the traumatised angry old men whom your government has faithfully followed to the 21st from the 19th century have a mindset that is far closer to that of Vladimir Putin than that of any modern European leader? Should that be the future, turn round and ....  (The President cut off the speaker).

name: Janusz ZEMKE
text: – Prime Minister, i would like to thank you for your excellent work. It is a fundamental principle of a rule of law that collective liability does not apply in that State. It must always be the case that both guilt and punishment are individual in nature, whereas in Poland legal acts are adopted which introduce collective liability. For example, people who served only one day until 1990 receive a much lower pension today. Well, I wanted to ask, in this regard, whether your Government will repeal these laws and whether your Government will withdraw from the Polish Sejm a proposal that is also intended to extend such restrictions to officers and soldiers?

name: Janusz ZEMKE
text: Prime Minister Polish. – Thank you very much for these voices, Ladies and Gentlemen. Let me start by commenting on the latter, because it is a very interesting aspect of defending the rule of law in one of the Members of Parliament, the High House, defending the high pensions of the special communist services, those services that murdered Polish heroes and who also murdered people I knew. This is precisely the difference between part of our opposition today and us, that we want to change those rules, and that is why we have reduced pensions for special communist service agents and raised pensions for Solidarity activists. That's the difference. And we are certainly not going to change that, Mr Euro- We're certainly not going to change that.  Dear! On values, we are on one side, but it is certainly not possible to dictate to the Member States the conditions of the rule of law. The systems are very different and the differences of these systems need to be taken into account. This is also why justice and home affairs are the exclusive competence of the Member States. This is not part of the acquis communautaire within the meaning of EU competence. I therefore answer this question as to whether Poland will respect the judgments of the Court: of course Poland respects the judgments of the Court. Today we have 50 judgments of the Court across the European Union that have not been implemented. Poland has no problem with this. But at the same time, it should be pointed out that there are EU competences, that is, transferred from the Member States to the whole Community, and there are national competences, national competences. And justice is definitely a national competence. Dear! The European Parliament rightly wants to be at the centre of the debate on the European Union, but many of you are unnecessarily reducing the dimension of this debate to matters that fall precisely within the competence of the Member States. We are therefore losing the opportunity to play a key role in the debate. And if we do not lose quite, then at least in part, because the key elements are precisely those that you and I have been talking about here, that is, the single market and the harmonisation of economic rules, where this makes sense above all else. I points to two areas in conclusion: the freedom to provide services, which can increase the competitiveness of the european Union as a whole, and support for small and medium-sized enterprises. Because the great ones are doing well, but there will be no support among the middle class. There will be no support for the idea of integration unless there is support among small and medium-sized enterprises. Mr Jáuregui Atondo asked rhetorically whether we should address issues such as sealing the VAT system and tax havens together or separately. Dear European, I am signing up to this with both hands. After the great successes that our government has achieved over two and a half years in sealing taxes, which has allowed us to eradicate child poverty and pursue a proud pro-social policy in order to take the next step, we must act together. Poland calls on every European Council, including the one held a week ago, to work together to win against terrorism, with terrorists, with VAT mafias, with tax criminals and with tax avoidance, that is, with tax havens. We are most in favour.  There were also voices broadly referring to the euro area. Here, ladies and gentlemen, many questions hang in the air. And economists from all sides are wondering whether the euro area solves problems or creates problems. We are waiting for different banking systems, different financial systems to deal with their problems, and we are trying, where we can, to help. But today – i just specialized in optimal currency areas – I can say: it makes sense to create a single currency between countries that are at a relative level of macro- and micro-economic convergence. Poland and Central Europe are catching up with Western Europe because after World War II we were left on the wrong side of the Iron Curtain. Dear! I will mention these three things once again in the summary. For the future Europe to be great and strong, we need Europe 4.0, that is, the European Union at the fore of the technological revolution, the industrial revolution, the digital revolution. We are working closely with the European Commission here. This is a very important part of the agenda and the future of the common market. Secondly, a safe Union. And thank you for all these voices here in so many places. I didn't expect us to say so unisono. And that is a very good sign both in the context of Nordstream II and the transatlantic agenda, in the fight against protectionism, but also in the common defence policy. This is a positive signal for me for the future. But there is also a third aspect: the Citizens' Union, a socially sensitive Union that supports its citizens and defends them against the power of global corporations. And this is the reflection: when, 100 years ago, the great corporations have mastered national markets, then we have created national antitrust institutions, antitrust offices. Today there are global monopolies and we do not have global antitrust offices. That is why Poland supports the digital tax that the French President has talked about and the fight against tax havens, and it is precisely the fight for a fair distribution of income that will cause the European middle class, which, after all, consists of the middle classes in the various nation states, to believe again in the idea of Europe, the idea of a great Europe, and the proud peoples of Europe will continue to be able to build this future of Europe in changed configurations, in a revised arrangement. I firmly believe this. Thank you very much for all these voices, including those critical. I think that some of you, at least some of you, have convinced you that we have the right to reform our tax systems, our justice system, our internal affairs. These are the competences of the Member States. In this way, we are strengthening one of the key Member States of the European Union and will be able to make an even better, stronger contribution to building a europe that is strong, innovative and solidarity-based. Thank you very much.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Thank you, Prime Minister, for taking part in this debate, which has been lively but certainly of great interest to us all. On the other hand, democratic confrontation is the salt of our democracy, so it is a good thing that there are debates like the one that has taken place today. Thank you again for accepting our invitation. The debate is closed. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Czesław HOC
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur, Mr Schwa I would like to recall the words I addressed to the EC Vice-President Frans Timmermans at the last meeting in the EP: 'Europo, remember! Poland and the European Union need each other." Poland has been co-creating the history of our continent for over a thousand years, and for many years it has also been doing so within the European Union, to which it belongs as a country. Poland has a measurable impact on Europe's security policy, both military and economic. As a country, we are part of NATO and operate actively in its structures, where, as one of the few Member States, we fulfil our financial commitments to common defence. Our efforts to ensure the security of the EU's eastern border are becoming particularly important at a time of growing migration crisis. Frontex has Polish headquarters in the Capital of Poland, which oversees the security of the Community's borders. Examples of fruitful cooperation could still be cited for a long time, but I would like to conclude my statement in this way: only joint action will ensure that we develop harmoniously, without discriminating against any member state because of other beliefs, values, or even voter decisions that do not fit into the great political coalitions that have taken place in Europe so far. Together we can do a lot, and together we become vulnerable to the many threats we face today.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: Writing. – As a Hungarian MEMBER, I am delighted to be debasing our common future with the Prime Minister of Poland today. When we talk about the future of Europe, we need to see one thing clearly. Without a strong Poland, we cannot talk about a strong European Union. We must therefore not have a low-level ideological debate today, rather than the subject given in the title. Instead of teaching lessons, we need dialogue. So let us ask the question: can we today, in the spirit of the Founding Fathers, once again give Europe a vision? Poland has its vision today. After all, anyone who has a national image and a family picture– that is, a vision of the future – can only have a real vision of Europe itself. The Visegrad countries, and the largest in it, poland, are also looking for answers to the problems of Europe as a whole. Even if, in many cases, we have untrue, arrogant lectures. That is what the Prime Minister's speech today was about. A friend is someone who understands your past, believes in your future, and accepts you for who you are.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The next item is the vote. (For the results and other details of the vote: see Minutes)

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, under Rule 59(4) I would like to propose that the draft legislative act be referred back to the committee responsible for interinstitutional negotiations in accordance with Rules 59a and 69c.

name: Jo LEINEN
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, after almost 40 years of direct elections to the European Parliament, today this is the first chance for this House to improve the conditions for participating in these elections. We are improving the conditions for millions of people by introducing a postal vote and by introducing the right to vote in a third country on election day. I might remind you that in Switzerland alone there are 1.4 million EU citizens who probably don’t go home to vote on election day. And there are many more provisions for more transparency and more democracy. This proposal requires a special legislative procedure: we needed unanimity in the Council – and you know how difficult it is to get unanimity in the Council – and today we need an absolute majority in this House. With my co-rapporteur, Danuta Hübner, after three years of hard work and negotiations, we got 28 Member States to reach consensus on this reform package. I would ask you not to miss the opportunity. We will have to wait a very long time to go back to this proposal again. Please use this opportunity to have a more open, more inclusive and fairer system for European elections. (Applause)

name: Gabriel MATO
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, on behalf of the co-applicants, and having spoken to the other groups in committee, in accordance with Article 59(4), we request that you put the matter back to the committee for a vote to start interinstitutional negotiations.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Colleagues, it is a pleasure to welcome the President of Angola, João Lourenço. Angola is an important country in Africa and strengthening ties with the African continent is a priority for the European Parliament. Since the African Union-European Union summit in Abidjan last November, we have advocated for a new revitalised partnership between our two continents, a partnership based on equal relations. The European Council conclusions adopted last week reflect this approach, calling for increased exchanges and contact with Africa. President Lourenço, in September 2017 you became Angola’s first new president in 38 years. Your election greatly contributed to the democratic process in the country. The reforms you have pushed for are contributing to revitalising Angola’s economy by attracting foreign investment, enhancing private-sector competitiveness, reducing dependence on the oil industry, corruption and inequality, and improving citizens’ rights. Structural changes, however, remain to be accomplished. Poverty and unemployment rank top of the list, as does the lack of diversification of the economy. The EU stands ready to support Angola in tackling these challenges. Through stronger economic diplomacy and by drawing up an investment plan for Africa, we can help you develop a manufacturing base via our transfer of technology and know-how, as well as improving social infrastructures. Trade is another area in which we can do more. In this respect, I invite Angola to join the Economic Partnership Agreement that exists between the EU and six countries of the region. Beyond the economy, Angola can play a strong role in the region. I welcome the efforts made and the openness towards refugees from the Democratic Republic of Congo. Migration is a common challenge on which we have to work together. President Lourenço, thank you for being here today. You now have the floor. (Applause)

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: President of the Republic of Angola. – Your Excellency, Mr Tajani, President of the European Parliament, Honourable Members of the European Parliament, distinguished guests, ladies and gentlemen, it is a great honour for me to be able to address the distinguished Members of this Parliament, one of the most respected spaces in promoting democracy and the fundamental rights of citizens in Europe and in the world. I thank you for the cordial welcome that has been reserved for me and the delegation that has accompanied me since our arrival in Strasbourg, which reflects the expression of the good relations of cooperation that exist between Angola and all the structures of the European Union. I would like to take advantage of this unique moment to express my desire for a permanent and frank dialogue with the European Parliament, based on mutual respect, so that our cooperation in all areas of common interest can be strengthened. In the same spirit, during my recent official visit to Belgium, I have already had the opportunity to address with the President of the European Council and with the head of European diplomacy some situations that concern our two continents. As you know, some of the problems experienced by Africa have direct repercussions in Europe and therefore deserve the careful attention of those responsible for countries and organisations on both continents. Your Excellency, ladies and gentlemen, Angola has experienced for decades a situation of armed conflict that has caused the death of thousands of people and the almost complete destruction of its infrastructure, a situation that would only end with the signing of the peace agreements on April 4, 2002. The achievement of peace and national reconciliation has led to the promoting a wide-ranging campaign of construction and reconstruction and the start of a new stage of reforms in all areas of political, economic and social life, with visible gains in the lives of citizens. Although this process has been heavily affected by the international economic-financial crisis and the lower price of oil on the international market, this did not prevent the normal functioning of democratic institutions, the exercise of justice and the affirmation of citizens' fundamental rights and freedoms.  Today, when the country is experiencing a natural phase of political transition, the Angolan executive remains committed to deepening the democratic process and improving the conditions that allow a favorable environment for the diversity of opinions, freedom of expression and, in general, respect for the fundamental rights of citizens. Since 2008, the Republic of Angola has held periodic, free, fair and transparent elections, held by different parties and coalitions of parties, with a view to legitimizing power, electing the President of the Republic, deputies to the National Assembly and the formation of the government executive.  We have a national assembly, with a total of 220 Deputies distributed between four political parties and a coalition of parties, according to the results of the August 2017 elections. Your Honor, ladies and gentlemen, before my investiture as President of the Republic on 26 September 2017, I have sought to implement policies that directly benefit the people, in consultation with all the political and social actors of the nation. The executive I direct has focused his attention on the implementation of macroeconomic stabilization and fiscal consolidation programmes, with a view to reducing the effects of inflation and normalising the foreign exchange market.  Although there is a decrease in the weight of the oil sector in the national economy, this reduction is not enough to overcome existing imbalances and is not yet reflected in the diversification of the economy and a structural change in state exports and revenues. In recent years, a great effort has been made for national reconstruction, and a great deal of resources have been invested in infrastructure and social works, even though there is insufficient to meet the needs of companies and populations with regard to energy, water, schools and hospitals, for example.  We therefore count on the European Union as an important partner that can help us overcome the constraints we still encounter to put the Angolan economy at the service of the development, progress and well-being of its people. Ladies and gentlemen, in the context of the moralisation of society, the creation of a better business environment and greater attention to foreign private investment, we have made a real crusade against corruption and impunity throughout society, with emphasis on so-called 'white collar crimes', the positive results of which we will soon begin to feel and benefit from. At the same time, a number of other measures have been adopted, such as the recent adoption by the Angolan Parliament of the new competition, which aims to prevent and penalise the actions of economic operators who do not comply with competition rules; the approval of the private investment law that has become more attractive to the investor in general and, in particular, to the foreign investor. There, where it was still possible, billion-dollar contracts were cancelled for the construction and management of important public infrastructure, such as the port of Barra do Dande, because the most elementary principles of transparency and competition were not respected. A call for tenders for new mobile phone licences and the privatization of Angola Telecom's capital was privatized in part. Studies take place for privatization in a transparent tender or on the stock exchange of some public companies from different sectors, including oil. A few days ago the council of ministers approved the new model of commercialization of diamonds that ends with the so-called preferred customers, in other words privileged, who had a monopoly of the business to the detriment of the producing companies and even the concessionaire itself, Endiama. We believe that, with this measure, we will soon see the return of large multinational companies in the sector, both of the producers and of trade and diamond cutting. In the same context of the moralization of society, combating corruption and impunity, criminal proceedings against those citizens who, presumably, will have harmed the state in hundreds of millions of US dollars, take place in the competent courts of justice. Let's wait for its outcome. It was also passed the law of repatriation of capital that aims to make the voluntary repatriation by its holders of the large financial resources, real fortunes, which a restricted group of Angolan citizens holds in tax havens or other banks around the world. It was our intention to give them the possibility to bring these resources voluntarily to the country and with them make investments in our economy, create wealth, create jobs, thus contributing to the strengthening of the national economy. This window that opened will be for an exact period of six months, which expires at the end of this year, after which the State will have all the freedom and legitimacy to use all the legal instruments at its disposal not only to locate and recover all these resources that are of the Angolan people but also to bring to the bars of justice their responsible. We have been signing bilateral visa-free agreements on ordinary passports and, in general, measures have been taken to facilitate and speed up the visa process for almost all countries, for investors, tourists or simply citizens who want to visit Angola for other reasons. Believe that Angola has become, in recent months, a country more open to the world and, therefore, more friend of investment, more open to tourism. Angola is open to foreign private investment virtually in all branches of the economy, agriculture and livestock, fisheries, hospitality and tourism, manufacturing and construction materials, the refining and distribution of oil and natural gas derivatives, the construction and operationalization of road, railway and port infrastructure, as well as the production, distribution and management of electricity and water. Ladies and gentlemen, with a view to solving the main social problems of citizens, such as access to clean water, electricity, collection and treatment of solid waste, public transport, school, primary health care and others, only possible in the framework of ever closer governance of the citizen, through bodies elected by them, are being prepared for 2020 the first municipal elections , to be carried out gradually, in order to progressively provide the various municipalities with financial, patrimonial and administrative autonomy. Your Excellency, ladies and gentlemen, Africa is today experiencing a climate of internal conflict, insecurity, economic and financial crisis, terrorism, hunger and poverty and, as a consequence, has known successive waves of emigration towards the nearest continent, the European continent.  This is a situation that embarrasses us all. It is sad and revolting to note that, about six centuries after the children of Africa were taken in degrading conditions on slave ships to the Americas where, as slaves, they contributed to the flowering of great economies, today the saga is repeated, albeit at a different juncture.  The children of Africa are going to Europe today as immigrants, some will say that on a voluntary basis, which is debatable. To be frank, they flee the armed conflicts, hunger and misery that plague some of our countries. They are fleeing unemployment and the lack of prospects for a better future. All we are responsible for this framework that many African countries are facing. It is in this conformity that we call on the European Union to establish with our continent a model of cooperation that, in the medium and long term, can contribute to reversing the current framework, which will help our countries to move from mere exporters of raw materials to producers of manufactured, industrialised products, as a guarantee of greater job supply and business opportunities for our citizens.  We believe that this will be in everyone's interest, that Africa and Europe only have to gain from an Africa capable of retaining its children on the continent, through a greater offer of employment and better living conditions overall. It is not a mere dream, but something that can become a reality if we always discuss it equally, without complexes of any kind, with realism and pragmatism. Ladies and gentlemen, in my capacity as acting president of the SADEC policy, defence and security cooperation body, we have been working on initiatives to support the efforts of SADEC, SIAC and CIRGL in the peaceful resolution of the problems affecting some countries in the region, with emphasis on the DRC, the Central African Republic, South Sudan. , Lesotho and, lately, also Madagascar. We work together with the sub-regional organizations cited and also with the African Union and the United Nations, always respecting the national sovereignty of each State, as well as the norms of international law. As regards cooperation between the European Union and the African continent, last year we held the fifth summit, at which issues of peace and security, good governance, democracy, human rights, migration and citizens' mobility, investment and trade, capacity building and job creation were discussed. The common African position is the need to change the paradigm of the model of cooperation established under the Cotonou Agreements between the European Union and the group of countries in Africa, the Caribbean and the Pacific. I will end by reiterating my thanks for the hospitality, cordial welcome and attention given by members.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Thank you, Mr President, as you will have noticed from the reaction of the House, your words are of great importance, because they underline how much more can be done in relations between Europe and Africa. The European Parliament wants to be a key player in this very important action in order to develop ever more positive relations between the two continents. As you pointed out, there are economic problems but also immigration problems, and I am convinced that these problems can only be solved by working together and focusing on the growth of the African continent. Thank you for accepting our invitation, you will be able to count on the support of this Parliament. (The sitting was suspended for a few moments)

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The sitting has resumed. Mr Lamberts, you have raised a point of order.

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: Mr President, thank you for giving me the floor by motion of order. I would like to point out that the plenary of Parliament has spoken on several occasions on how to reform the way in which Members allocate overhead. Indeed, this is a large sum, EUR 40 million per year, the level of control of which was not sufficient in relation to the sums committed, and therefore the plenary has decided several times on very specific ideas. However, the Bureau, which you chair, has decided to take important freedoms, and freedoms (let me finish) in relation to the majority position adopted by this plenary. Therefore, we ask you, as the person in charge of the Office, to reconsider, and if not, we ask the Conference of Presidents to address the problem.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Thank you very much, Mr Lamberts. I recommend a look at the vote on the 2019 budget. The Bureau has decided nothing more than what the house has decided there or which amendments were rejected there. (Applause)

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: We shall now proceed to the vote.

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: – Mr President, that last point of order was not a point of order and would not be permitted from anybody on this side of the House. I must ask you please to be objective in your rulings. (Applause)

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Mr Dartmouth, I would like to thank Mr Dartmouth for his The problem with people speaking out on a point of order has long been a thorn in my side. I spoke to the President this week. The President will send a letter to the rapporteur, who is re-considering the Rules of Procedure, Mr Corbett. That is what he promised me. We will shortly be trying to tackle this constant problem, which is also a nuisance for many. - Before the final vote:

name: Merja KYLLÖNEN
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, in accordance with Rule 59(4), I request that the matter be referred back to the Committee on Transport and Tourism.

name: Wim van de CAMP
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, in view of the outcome of this vote, I would also ask for this dossier to be referred back to the Transport Committee. Thank you very much.

name: Ismail ERTUG
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, for the same reason as with the two dossiers before; the outcome is totally contradictory, therefore I would like to ask for it to be referred back to the Transport Committee.

name: Julia REDA
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the In the first vote on the first Moraes report, at the time of the vote, 'Amendments 1 and 2' was on our voting machines, although it was obviously the final vote. I would therefore ask you to repeat the final vote because the display on the machines was incorrect.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Mrs Reda, I would like to thank Mrs Reda for her I did, in fact, call and put Amendments Nos 1 and 2 to the vote. And then I called for a roll-call vote. Therefore, it is impossible to have stood "1 and 2". And that was the final vote, Mrs Reda. And if you've done it wrong - that happens to each of us - then correct your vote in the aftermath.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: That concludes the vote.

name: Morten MESSERSCHMIDT
text: Mr President! We voted in favour of this report, even though Armenia has, of course, refused a partnership agreement with the European Union. And I can really understand the Armenians when you look at the way Turkey and the European Union act. For although we are currently sending one bandbull after another against Erdogan and his regime, it is still a fact that Turkey is a candidate country to join the European Union. In this light, with what we know and the way Turkey is acting in particular towards Armenia, I understand that the Armenians are trying to get into closer cooperation with this Union. And perhaps it's a bit of a hint with a trolley that it's time for the EU to reseal its policy towards Erdogan and Turkey. If we are really serious about the criticisms that we are making against Constantinople and the government, etc., then we also need to align the policy with it. And say that Turkey should not be a member of the European Union!

name: Morten MESSERSCHMIDT
text: Mr President! The crux of this vote was not really the final one, but the amendment that was tabled – No 1, which - unfortunately against our wishes - fell. It is recalled here that Turkey, which, as you know, would like to be a member of this Union, has not yet implemented the Zurich protocols, which very clearly give Turkey historical responsibility for the fearful genocide that took place against the Armenians. It is a complete mystery to me why this house will not strike something so completely fundamental and rightly. We are dealing with a country which - if not by revising its history - will not, of course, take on the historical responsibility that Turkey has in line with other European nations. If we mean something about having to influence just our neighbouring countries, then we also need to stand up to the historical facts towards Turkey and insist that the Zurich protocols be implemented.

name: Urszula KRUPA
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I voted against the document entitled 'Towards an EU external strategy to combat early and forced marriage', which, while recognised not only as child abuse and violence, but also as a violation of human rights by the UN, is also in breach of the principle of individual autonomy, not least because of the threat to the health and life of girls whose early pregnancy is very risky – not least because of coercive trauma , but also due to underdeveloped biological development. Although the document contains a minimum marriage age of eighteen, it promotes sexual and reproductive health, which is simply the right to abortion, which is a threat to the life and psychophysical health of every woman, much less young girls, as part of equality. On both issues, education and awareness are needed, because one evil cannot be combated by others.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Mr President, early and forced marriages are a trampling on human dignity and the right to freely decide on their marriage after reaching the age of age. It is certainly a consequence of traditions, of a certain culture, but also of the social situation.  The measure against these practices, which we cannot agree to, is, above all, education, changing the attitude of society as a whole to human rights, to human dignity. This can be helped by the European Union by supporting, educating these countries, and, of course, by enforcing the right legislation, laws and international law. However, I must point out that, even in the countries that have adopted the Istanbul Convention, which have ratified it, this right is not respected, so the Istanbul Convention is not a solution that can remedy this unacceptable practice.

name: Morten MESSERSCHMIDT
text: Mr President! I think it was a serious dilemma how, as an EU critic, one should deal with this report. On the one hand, there is no doubt that involuntary marriages, children who get married before they are of age, we are all against that. It's disgusting to see what's going on in certain parts of the world. On the other hand, yes, the question is: is this really something that the European Union has to deal with – and in fact all the details that the report lists? Is it really the EUROPEAN Union that has to ratify the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child? Is it the EUROPEAN Union that should have the authority to deal with issues of children's rights and marriages, etc.? I would like to say all that clearly to that. It belongs in the Member States. Nevertheless, we ended up voting in favour of this report because the matter is so important. But also because the report has no legislative significance. All these issues must be decided in the Member States, not by the European Union. We will ensure that this will continue to be the case in the future and that the European Union does not take the opportunity to take that competence. But the matter is important, and that is why we voted in favour.

name: Dobromir SOŚNIERZ
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I voted against. This report ignores all cultural differences, wants to impose only a legitimate vision on the whole world, is a manifestation of the pride of Europeans and of ignoring cultural differences. In Poland, marriage is allowed from the age of 16, and this has not bothered anyone until now. I do not know why we have been treated as Islamic countries, and marriages of sixteen-year-olds as child marriages, in addition, forced. But since you understand any marriage under the age of 18 as compulsory, even with parental consent, I understand that abortion for people under the age of 16 will also be considered forced abortion, and early-abortion contraception given to people under the age of 18 will also be banned as forced. This is chess and mat. You scored yourself a goal for your own goal.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I voted in favour of this report because early and forced child marriage is an aberrant form of violation of human rights which, transcending countries, religions and ethnicgroups, perpetuates the dynamics of gender inequalities and undermines the lives and futures of millions of girls and adolescents around the world.  For all this, I believe that the European Union must strongly condemn this form of violence, it must support policies for the empowerment of girls and, in its foreign policy and development cooperation, to urge its partners to comply with international legal conventions and instruments on the rights of the child to health, education and non-discrimination.

name: Miapetra KUMPULA-NATRI
text: – Mr President, the European Parliament has done a good job in its statement in banning forced and child marriage. It also mentions reproductive health and abortion as important. Although this is mainly the focus of external relations, it also calls on eu member states to condemn and end marriages for under-18s, i.e. children. Over the past twenty years, more than 1,000 child marriages have been committed in Finland, around 10–20 annually, and it is now exempted from the Ministry of Justice. Not everyone gets permission after the consultation and the parents' permission. Three years ago, the Ombudsman for Children and several others have appealed for Finland to make a clearer ban on legislation and now it has also been taken up by the Minister of Justice. I hope that we can also be clear about this at home and set an example for the EU countries. Additional measures should also be taken to ensure that girls do not find themed in the circumstances of marriage, even outside the official papers.

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we have worked actively and with great commitment on this proposal for the reform of European road transport put forward by the Commission. We have done so in order to solve the problems of the thousands of drivers who travel throughout Europe every day, very often in inhuman conditions and without respect for basic conditions of human dignity. We have done so in order to eliminate the problem of social dumping, which very often also results in a distortion of competition to the detriment of companies, especially Italian ones, which are forced to close down, because they cannot compete with eastern European companies under completely different fiscal and social conditions. On all three reports under discussion, we have put forward our proposals, which have in fact become the position of the EMPL Committee, which has accepted and adopted them. We therefore felt it was right and necessary to support these proposals to the end, not least because the TRAN Committee has misdesigned to overturn them and not to take them into account. In particular, we called for the problem of social dumping to be resolved, maintaining the status quo for weekly rest periods and ensuring that vehicles and drivers return home every two weeks, thus enabling drivers to see their families and loved ones again. We have called for a ban on rest in the cabin, so we have to eliminate the problem of so many drivers having to sleep for hours on board, on the road. We have called for posting to be applied to all hauliers engaged in cabotage and international transport operations. Finally, we have advocated limiting the phenomenon of irregular cabotage, including through better control instruments. With today's vote, Parliament has missed a great opportunity to solve the problems of road hauliers, demonstrating an absolute lack of common sense and once again confirming to the citizens of Europe that the interests of lobbies outweigh those of honest workers and decent people.

name: Rory PALMER
text: – Mr President, a few weeks ago, this Parliament adopted and supported a set of very progressive measures on the issue of the posting of workers, which constitutes a fundamental unfairness across our labour markets, leading to the exploitation of workers. For me, it’s always been a fundamental question of fairness that those protections should apply equally to transport workers as well, and it was that principle that guided my votes on the amendments and the report today. We need a level playing field of protection and fairness that will protect workers in the transport sector across Europe. That’s what the 26 000 haulage drivers in my region demand and ask for. Nothing less: a level playing field, a fairness and proper protection. As we now enter the next chapter on this issue, that should remain the objective of this Parliament.

name: Daniela AIUTO
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the proposals we made and accepted by the EMPL Committee aimed to create a better wage balance at European level and to apply the principle of 'same place, same pay'. The absence of common rules for posted drivers poses a serious problem in terms of social dumping and inequalities between workers in the European Union. That is why we have strongly supported the application of posting, including in cases of cabotage and international transport operations, taking into account the high mobility of this category of workers. Today's vote on posting represents a clear failure of this Europe, which is very attentive to markets and business linked to trade in goods but really not attentive to the social rights of workers.

name: Danuta JAZŁOWIECKA
