text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I voted in favour of the report on the posting of drivers because the amendment covering international transport by posting rules has only passed after ten days in the Member State concerned. I have called for international transport to be completely excluded from the principle of logging in, but I know that these ten days are also an opportunity for the transport sector to adapt in practice to the new rules. Of course, it is also important to calculate the hours that enter the working day – this is very crucial, but there was a chance for further compromise in the Council. Now the report goes back to the Committee on Transport. It remains to be hoped that the rational work on this report will continue to produce good results.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: – Mr President, there is a need for clear, fair and enforceable European rules on transport. The practice of administrative bullying of international transport companies in some Member States has already shown this. But these rules should primarily guarantee fair competition across the entire single market and not aim to protect only geographical vested interests. The inclusion of international transport under the remit of the Posted Workers Directive is indefensible on any logical, administrative, enforcement, political or economic grounds. The only way this would make sense is if the goal was to de facto eliminate peripheral countries from the European transport market at all costs, regardless of whether in the process, as we heard, SMEs create monopolies, decrease the competitiveness of our industries or increase the prices for our consumers. Cherry picking and selectively applying the basic rules of the single market under the cover of simplistic slogans is very wrong and is not the way forward in the context of the current wave of international populist protectionism.

name: Thomas MANN
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Without cross-border freight transport, no European company can compete in global terms. Cabotage is about transport companies delivering from one EU Member State to the other. Three trips over seven days are allowed here. The scheme must remain so that domestic suppliers are protected from social dumping. The Posting of Workers Directive must be applied, as must the payment of the minimum wage. Freight transport and passenger transport must not be mixed up. Passenger safety is paramount in the case of tourist bus transport. During driving and rest periods, it must be possible to make the 45-minute break flexible, to divide the daily rest time into stages. I am opposed to an extended driving period of 12 consecutive days, during which there is no rest day for bus drivers. It is in the interests of all citizens that drivers are not fatigued and that road safety remains. We voted against negative changes in driving and rest periods in the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs. It has been so controversial, Mr President, i am glad that the reports are being referred back to committee.

name: Miapetra KUMPULA-NATRI
text: – Mr President, first of all it is a whole. We have three legislative measures relating to the mobility package, and when one of them collapsed, it is better that everything as a whole is re-prepared for a vote in the Chamber. Personally, I see that it is precisely this first package, which also touches on the scope, that is, where the directive on posted drivers hits, that it would have been good to limit cabotage and the road transport sections of combined transport. It would have addressed the part where the most abuses and unfair competition of workers take place. It would therefore have been done clearly that, when transport under cabotage is carried out within a country, then, from the very first day, the driver would also have the rights of the country in which he carries out the work. It would also be important to have this in the Chamber after the committee is preparing this again.

name: Rory PALMER
text: – Mr President, our motorways are getting more and more busy with lorries and heavy goods vehicles. Internet shopping and consumerism are leading to more and more movement of goods across our countries. Heavy goods vehicles travelled a total of 16.6 billion miles on the UK’s roads and what I want to know as a fellow motorist is that the people driving those lorries are doing so safely, with adequate regulations and mechanisms in place to support that. This Parliament must always ensure that those working in the haulage industry – people driving 40 tonne lorries – are doing so with the highest levels of safety. So, for me, on voting on this report and all its amendments and as we move forward again into the next chapter on this issue, it’ll be safety first for drivers and safety first for all other road users as well.

name: Daniela AIUTO
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, our position on this report was to ban drivers' rest in the cab, to guarantee their return within two weeks and to maintain the status quo on weekly rest periods. The TRAN Committee has tried to water down this position and that is why we have opposed it, once again supporting the positions adopted in the EMPL Committee in this House. It is essential for us to guarantee dignity in the rights of all road hauliers and to put an end to what is true slavery, in which drivers do not see their families for weeks and are forced to live in deeply disadvantaged conditions. On this report, too, Parliament has missed an historic opportunity to improve the conditions of workers in wear and tear jobs who seriously affect the rights of the individual.

name: Miapetra KUMPULA-NATRI
text: – Mr President, although this too has returned to committee, I very much hope that there will also be support in this Chamber for a future basis, which must be an improvement on the current situation. No one wants to look honestly at a situation where we have nomad drivers driving around the streets of Europe and staying in their own cabin. This is not from anywhere today in European working conditions. Therefore, there would also have been improvements in driving times and rest periods. I understand that when you go on a business trip, you can have a couple of weeks, but the suggestion at the bottom that you can go home at the employer's expense at the end of the third week is already a good improvement on the current base and this legislation should be developed in that direction. In Finland, we have hoped for flexibility over long distances, and I would also understand it as positive for the employee. From my own region in the Vaasa region, when you go to visit the capital, it is a very important question whether you will be able to return during working hours on the same day. I'm sorry for the employee if you have to spend a free hour at home an hour before you get there.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: Mr President, we had been told of a great step forward for social Europe on road transport. In fact, for social Europe, we will have to go back because the votes have shown that there is a majority here in this European Parliament for social breakdown, for dumping, for ever more unfair competition and ever more liberalisation in the goods transport sector. Worse still, the votes showed a willingness to continue to break the rights of road workers. In fact, for social Europe, we will have to wait a little longer and I believe that under the current treaties, this is unfortunately impossible.

name: Daniela AIUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, irregular cabotage is one of the main problems affecting Italian road haulage companies. Unscrupulous companies in Eastern Europe are abusing existing rules by practising genuine unfair competition against our entrepreneurs, effectively destroying an entire national market. We have therefore proposed to impose the vehicle in the Member State of origin, to reduce the days available for cabotage, which must be understood as a simple occasional phenomenon linked to the return of means, to improve the control instruments, including through the GNSS technology available today. Therefore, with today's vote we express our disappointment at not wanting to include proposals to solve the problem, once again protecting some realities rather than others and penalising our country once again.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The next item is the statement by the President of the Eurogroup on the conclusion of the third economic adjustment programme for Greece (2018/2740(SDR)). I welcome Mário Centeno, President of the Eurogroup, who is coming to visit us for the first time.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: President of the Eurogroup. – Mr President, it is an honour to be here today with you and to join this discussion on Greece. Greece’s third programme is drawing to a successful close. The Greek people and all euro area citizens are finally able to turn the page. This is the right time to assess what Greece and the euro area countries have achieved together during the last eight years. It is also an opportunity to cast a glance at the near future. First and foremost, I would like to pay tribute to the Greek people. The positive results of the last programme are to their credit. (Applause) These should now have a lasting effect on growth and would not have been possible without the extraordinary sacrifices made by the Greek citizens, without the country’s tremendous efforts to rebalance and modernise its economy.  The Eurogroup has also contributed to the successful outcome. Over the years, Greece’s European partners have provided time and money. Time for Greece to redress its fundamentals; the time that every reform process requires. Over EUR 250 billion in loans when no one else was willing to lend. This was unprecedented solidarity that will benefit Greece for many decades. Today Greece is ready to stand on its own feet again and with the sound foundations for sustainable balance and inclusive growth.  The agreement reached at the June Eurogroup is key for Greece to achieve that goal. I will walk you through the details of the agreement, but before that, let me briefly mention where we have come from. I am well aware of today’s time constraints, so to borrow a reference from Greece’s history and cultural heritage, I promise to be more Spartan than Delphic. Greece has been on the agenda of the Eurogroup for the last eight years. Back in 2010, the country was facing formidable adjustment challenges which required a deep reform process. Public finances had to be put on a sound footing, competitiveness needed restoring, the economy had to be made more open and modernised and the negative spill—overs of all this to the financial sector needed to be addressed. These were long and difficult years. We all would have liked a few things to have gone differently. Yet today, Greece is set for a successful exit from the third ESM programme. 20 August 2018 is a date to mark in our calendar; a date to celebrate. During the programme, Greece adopted over 450 policy actions across a vast array of areas. Of course, implementation takes time, and we need to be resilient. Patience, though often in short supply, is critical but reforms are indeed paying off. Economic growth has been back in positive territory. Since last year, the economy grew by 1.4% in 2017, and is expected to increase 1.9% this year. The outlook – according to the latest forecasts – is bright and in line with the euro area average. The results have been particularly impressive on the fiscal side. Today, Greece’s budget is running a solid primary surplus, above 4% for two consecutive years, and has been made more sustainable through ambitious taxation and patient reforms. Importantly, the social safety net is being revamped to better protect vulnerable groups. The country’s competitiveness has been improving, with a positive effect on the labour market. That means faster job creation and falling unemployment. Greece’s business cycle is now more aligned with the euro area economy and this is great news. Against this positive backdrop, the financial sector is more and more resilient. All these are encouraging signs that will help Greece to regain investor confidence. It has already successfully raised funds from bond markets on several occasions. The income—passing agreement of euro area finance ministers of 22 June will improve market sentiment even further, as already seen on the secondary market. The recent agreement on debt relief is the last of several improvements in Greece’s lending terms since 2012. Thanks to these favourable landing conditions, Greece saves money every year. In 2017 alone, it saved EUR 12 billion in debt service payments, or 6.7% of the country’s GDP, according to the European civility mechanism estimates. These benefits represent no cost for the European tax payer; on the contrary, we all gain from a stable and growing economy across our common currency area. Back in 2012, private creditors did agree to take a hit to the tune of 53% on their holdings of Greek debt. This was a unique feature of the second assistance programme. Already in the ESM programme, we had agreed short term debt measures that reduced the debt to GDP ratio by 25% in 2016. In the last Eurogroup, we agreed to an even more substantial package of measures to make Greece’s debt sustainable. This includes an extension of the bulk of the loans by the European Financial Stability Facility (EFSF) and a deferral of interest by an additional ten years. In other words, until 2033, Greece will have less interest and have the motivation to burden its budget and this means more fiscal leeway to support its economy and its citizens. In addition to that reprofiling, the Eurogroup last month agreed to resume transferring to Greece the profits made by the euro system on its holdings of Greek government bonds. This will take the form of semi—annual payments in December and in June until 2022. These payments give a positive incentive for Greece to continue implementing reforms in the coming years. It is time to continue the process of reforms that is now fully owned by Greece. This process must prove resilient over forthcoming political and economic cycles, and we must never forget that. The final tranche of the European stability mechanism to Greece was another element of this package. We agreed that EUR 15 billion will be disbursed after the national parliaments in a number of Member States have had their say, and this can happen as soon as next week. Out of this amount of EUR 15 billion, EUR 9.5 billion will be dedicated to a cash buffer, which should also reassure investors as it will act as Greece’s fiscal backstop. The remaining EUR 5.5 billion will be disbursed in 2020 to a segregated account and should be used to cover Greece’s debt servicing needs. At the end of the programme, the overall size of the cash buffer in Greece will be EUR 24.1 billion, which is a very large amount that covers Greece’s financing needs for around 22 months after the exit from the programme on 20 August. This is a longer safety net than in any other country’s programme so far.  So, it is now up to Greece to build on the programme’s success and to consolidate its achievements. Greece should continue implementing responsible fiscal policies and growth—enacting reforms to improve the living conditions and the chances and prospects of its citizens. This is what Greece’s post—programme framework will be about. We all agree that for the next couple of years, the so—called enhanced surveillance by the European Commission will help Greece stay the course. Commissioner Moscovici will be able to tell you more about that in a minute. But let me be clear, being out of the programme means Greece being out of the programme. Greece should commit to the requirements to participate in the euro just like any other country in the euro, but in this safe framework the government has an obligation to provide policy options to its citizens and to debate them internally. That is indeed a good thing for democracy. I am confident that Greece will look at its policy options and be able to improve on existing reforms to promote stability and political compromise – stability to spur investment, compromise in the name of future generations. This will require action on several fronts: prudent fiscal policy based on primary surpluses and sound management of public finance, financial sector governance and handling of non—performing loans, an efficient and effective social safety net, flexible and open labour and product markets and – also very importantly – modern public administration, just to name a few. For this purpose the Greek Government presented a growth model which is based on the continuation of reforms. These will help Greece to continuously lift its productivity capacity and offer a solid anchor for confidence amongst foreign investors and Greek citizens. Market volatility some weeks ago has shown that Greece remains vulnerable to risks. New policy options should take this into account. It is very important that Greece continues to take ownership and implement its ambitious long—term growth strategy. I am encouraged to find that the Greek authorities see it that way too, and I welcome the policy commitments they have announced to the Eurogroup.  Confidence in Greece’s future is the key message I wanted to convey to you. I would now very much like to hear your views on this matter.

name: Pierre MOSCOVICI
text: Member of the Commission. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr President of the Eurogroup, dear Mario, it is a pleasure to be with you today, alongside the President of the Eurogroup, to present to you, in my turn, what the Eurogroup agreement, concluded on 21 June, means for the future of Greece on the morning of 22 June. After eight long, interminable years, Greece is finally preparing to return to the path of normality and autonomy. I spent two days in Athens yesterday and the day before yesterday, and I could see how powerful this aspiration for restored freedom was among the Greek authorities and, I am sure, among the Greek people as well.  This is a historic moment for this country and, as Mario Centeno said - that is the phrase I heard for two days in every mouth - "a page is turning" and we must take the measure of this moment. Not to regard it as an end in itself, not to regard it as a perfection, but to be aware of the very great importance of what is happening. It is also an important moment for the euro area, which has proved, through this crisis, its robustness and resilience, and today we can say, with the conclusion of the assistance programmes for Greece, that the economic crisis that has hit us so violently is indeed behind us and that the eurozone, like Greece, is emerging from it. , I think, stronger and with greater potential. We now have until August 20, and August 20 is the official date of the release of the program, to prepare together the transition and the future of the country in serenity. I am aware, as all of you here, that the last few years have been trying for the Greek people, and especially for the middle class and for the most vulnerable. I know that millions of Greeks have lived and are still living hard this long recession, successive reforms and austerity even though, as I had the opportunity to say yesterday in the Greek Parliament, make no mistake, it is not austerity that caused the crisis, it is because there was a crisis that measures and reforms were needed.  Everyone in Greece has gone through their own tragedy or tragedy, either by losing their jobs overnight, by seeing their pension go down, or by watching, helplessly, their children leave the country in pursuit of a better future they could not find at home. I hope you will believe me when I tell you that we are always thinking about the consequences of our decisions for the Greek people in the Eurogroup, where I have been sitting for more than six years now. The European Commission has always been an ally of citizens in defending their interests. Not the ally of this or that government, but the ally of the Greek people to oppose, as best as possible, the proponents of blind austerity, and above all to oppose all those who were willing to throw Greece out of the eurozone so as not to have to show a little solidarity towards a partner. During those six years, which I went through first as France's finance minister, then as European Commissioner, I remember two summers, those of 2012 and 2015, when we each time came close to the 'Grexit' which I am sure would have been a disaster, both for Greece and for the euro area. I am proud that we have managed to avoid this Grexit disaster scenario because, beyond the consequences I mentioned, it carried, in my opinion, a risk of an irretrievable fracture of Europe betraying its founding values.  For the Greek people, I also want to congratulate myself that we have been able to integrate a social dimension into this programme, in particular the third. It is certainly timid, to be confirmed and amplified, but we have managed to put in place: universal health coverage - almost two million Greeks now have full access to care, which was not the case before - and an income of social solidarity, from which more than 600,000 Greeks have already benefited. In the face of adversity, I want to say my admiration for the Greek people who have always maintained their European will, their willingness to remain in the euro area and for that I would like to pay tribute to you, European elected representatives, for their courage which has been very important during these years. As Mario Centeno said, in exchange for EUR 241 billion in loans from the Europeans, because we are still talking about this, Greece, as we know, has embarked on an unprecedented process of structural reforms. Never, it can be said, in the history of our Union has a country - and it must be said that it needed it - reformed as quickly and deeply as Greece. In the last three years alone, the Greeks have implemented 450 priority actions that have begun to profoundly transform the country. What has Greece achieved in deciding on reforms? In a word, a lot. I know this is a controversial subject and I could see how lively the debate was yesterday in Athens, but I will still give some concrete examples. First, Greece has embarked on a major tax reform. Income tax is now fairer, more efficient by broadening the tax base and lowering the minimum tax threshold. At the same time, a land registry, yes a land registry is finally being set up - it has been in existence in France for 200 years - which will facilitate the collection of taxes and what constitutes an effective mechanism to combat fraud or tax evasion and, finally, revenues are beginning to arrive in the Greek public treasury. We know that this was one of the endemic evils of the country. A major pension reform has been adopted and is being implemented. Not only does it restore the viability of the pension system, but it also introduces unified rules for all, which I believe will make the system fairer. To stabilise the Greek banking system, various tools have been put in place to improve the reduction of non-performing loans. We are not at the end, it is a problem that affects the whole of Europe, but the governance of the Hellenic Financial Stability Fund, as well as that of systemic banks, has been considerably strengthened.  Eight years later, these efforts, these reforms, these sacrifices are beginning to bear fruit. I will not put too much emphasis on the numbers, but Greece is well on the road to economic recovery. All indicators confirm this positive trend: stronger growth (1.4% in 2017, and a forecast of more than 2.3% in 2019), a very dramatic fiscal performance (remember that there is a surplus of 0.8% in 2017, while Greece in 2009 had a deficit of 15%, the largest in all of Europe!), a gradual reduction , although still too slow, unemployment (20% today, up from 27% a few years ago).  Progress is there but efforts must be continued, reforms must be completed so that the Greek people can benefit from the progress made and see their situation improve. This is the whole Agreement of the Eurogroup that Mario Centeno has just presented. I will not go into detail because he has just done so, but I want to emphasize the benefits of the agreement. Why is this a good deal? Quite simply, because the agreement reached on debt reduction lives up to our respective ambitions and Greece's needs. It provides Greece with sufficient leeway to continue to meet the many economic challenges it still faces, while providing - and this was important - a necessary guarantee to partners, investors and markets, who are waiting for Greece's return now. The elements contained in this agreement will first reduce the level of public debt considerably. We expect a fall below the symbolic 100% of GDP mark at the end of the process. The arrangements in the agreement will generate up to 1.2 billion euros each year. Very concretely, this means that Greece will not pay interest on its loans until 2033. This is fifteen years of respite to invest and to invest. This is the challenge for Greece, for the authorities of today and for those of tomorrow, to put growth at the heart of future political choices. It is also an additional fifteen years to try - and must do so - to build a better social future and create social justice for future generations. This must be one of the priorities, I believe, of the Greek governments to come, because, as I said, and we all know, the people are still suffering. Beyond that, the only one, and I say the only strategy for the sustainable and effective reduction of Greek debt, is growth.  That is the whole philosophy of the 22 June agreement: to give Greece a breath of fresh air so that it can return to growth in a sustainable way and put an end to the infernal spiral of debt. I call, of course, for the responsibility of the Greek authorities to transform the trial. It is a question of implementing the progress made in recent years, because there is still work to be done. However, it is the Greeks, who can pursue prudent and balanced policies, who will produce positive results for, once again, the Greek people and their middle class. But let me be clear, I insist on responsibility, I insist on freedom - and this is very important for Greece - but Greece will not do its job alone. Europe and the Commission will stand with the Greek people along the way.  Greece is now regaining its rightful place in the eurozone and the normalization of its status means that it will have to respect its rights and duties. Like any other Member State, Greece will have to follow the European budgetary obligations of the Growth Stability Pact and be a responsible partner in this monitoring process. It will have to present a draft budget for 2019 as part of the normal European Semester as part of the European Semester on 15 October. I was talking about it yesterday with Alexis Tsipras and Euclid Tsakalotos.  As the Greek crisis has been much longer than in any other country, as the debt remains much higher than in any country, we have chosen together to apply enhanced supervision at the end of the programme. We will ensure that the reforms that were agreed under the last programme are carried out in a good way. Firstly, because Greece has committed to it in return for an additional payment of 15 billion euros, but mainly because they are necessary for the modernization of the Greek economy and administration. I am thinking, for example, of the finalisation of the land registry for 2021. We will also remain particularly vigilant, with the European Stability Mechanism, to the debt reduction trajectory which still severely handicaps the Greek economy. But - and I will end with this - I want to emphasize one last point, namely enhanced surveillance. Contrary to what I heard in Athens yesterday, by some politicians, who should measure their words - because the policy does not allow everything, does not allow to go against the truth - no, enhanced surveillance is not a fourth programme, it provides a framework to support the completion and implementation of the reforms that are under way. It is in the context of the European Semester that the dialogue with Greece will now be established and I can assure you that the monitoring missions will not be there to be judges, prosecutors or professors, but rather wise and benevolent advisers so that we can succeed together. Yes, that is what we are talking about, and there is no question of a fourth program. To say otherwise is simply a lie. Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to express one last time my admiration for the Greek people, for their strength, for their dignity in these painful moments and for the confidence I have in the Greek authorities to pursue reforms in the coming years, otherwise the sacrifices and efforts made will have been in vain. I am sure that will not be the case, I think we have learned and that we will learn together from these eight painful years, from which we are once again coming out stronger.

name: Manolis KEFALOGIANNIS
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. Mr President, I am sorry, but I have to say this: we have entered the election period for good. The day before yesterday in Athens, Mr. Moscovici did not behave as European Union officials, he behaved more as the Socialist Party's candidate for the European Commission, claiming Mr. Juncker's position. I do not know why he has untenablely adopted the government's narrative of a clear exit from the memorandums, as he told us today.  Instead, Mr. Tsipras has pledged new onerous measures for years to come: cutting pensions from 2019, tax-free reduction from 2020, increase in insurance contributions to professionals and farmers, surplus of 3.5% by 2022 and 2.2% by 2060 – only OPEC countries, due to oil, can achieve such results – mortgages of state property for the next 25 billion years , and a super fund that will be in charge by 2115, still for 99 years. Mr President, in August the third unnecessary memorandum was completed, which cost the Greek people a great deal because of the wrong policy of Mr Tsipras's left-wing government. Now – and I disagree with Mr Moscovici – Greece is facing a fourth covert memorandum. Tell me, isn't it a memorandum when it includes measures of 5.1 billion euros for the next few years and raises the bill to 14.5 billion euros, almost 10% of Greece's Gross National Product? So there is no celebration, much more triumphalism. What is needed are reforms and investments in Greece. Only in this way will Greece emerge from its impasses and from the great, prolonged crisis it had throughout the 1910s.

name: Roberto GUALTIERI
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, I have to say that I find it a bit surreal that the representative of the party which brought the Greek deficit to 15% and Greece to bankruptcy, instead of apologising, attacks the Commission and does not recognise the important success of this programme. (Applause from certain quarters) But let me come back to the programme. The agreement reached by the Eurogroup on the conclusion of the third European Stability Mechanism (ESM) programme and the additional debt relief is a milestone in the process of returning Greece to sustainable growth and to autonomy. It is a great success for the Greek people, who can finally turn the page after many years of hardship and sacrifices, and for the whole of Europe, which, after many mistakes, has proved that it can ensure the integrity of the euro area. I would like to congratulate the Greek Government, the Greek people, the Eurogroup and its President, Commissioner Moscovici, the ESM and the European Central Bank for their positive engagement in this process. Let me also give a special mention to Declan Costello, who has done excellent work on the ground. Greece is now exiting the financial assistance programme with an impressive track record of reforms implemented and with an ambitious and socially balanced growth strategy that has to be pursued, and which we should all support with complementary policy actions at EU level in order to further Greek growth potential, employment and social cohesion. Together with the reforms, the significant debt relief – in particular with the cash buffer, the upfront deferral of European Financial Stability Facility (EFSF) interest and amortisation until 2033, and the binding commitment to additional measures if needed – now makes the Greek public debt sustainable. It should allow Greece to regain full access to financial markets. In this context, while it is important to continue ensuring fiscal sustainability, I regret that the IMF – the IMF, not the Commission – has imposed clearly unnecessary additional fiscal measures in relation to pensions and personal income tax for 2019-2020. This shows why it is important to reform the ESM and, while the outperformance of the primary balance would fortunately allow those measures to be fully offset with the tax and spending package, I think it would be wise to allow Greece to redefine the timing and the nature of such a relevant reallocation of resources. Finally, we have been closely monitoring the programme. We will do the same with the Enhanced Surveillance framework, ensuring its fairness and ensuring what has been clearly said: it is not a programme. Greece has entered the preventive arm of the Stability and Growth Pact, with all its flexibility provisions. (Applause)

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take back from the ECR Group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which Commissioner Moscovici said that we must not tell the untruth in politics, and that is why I would like to put an end to this unspeakable tinkering, which has emerged here both from the words of the Commissioner and from the words of the President of the Eurogroup. As far as this programme is concerned, it was a major failure. We have driven Greece into an economic disaster. We must make it quite clear that Greece's debt ratio was around 140% in relation to the debt ratio in 2010. Then Greece got a huge debt relief of 107 billion euros – far larger than Argentina's sovereign default, far larger than any sovereign default before. And today the debt level is higher – at 180%! Income in Greece has fallen by almost 25%. For years, the Greeks have been forgoing 25% of their income – not voluntarily, as the word waiver suggests, but forced by the adjustment measures that we have imposed on them. Government revenues in Greece have not increased. The entire adjustment of the government deficit has only come together on the expenditure side, because all sorts of government expenditure swelled. But the Greek state budget has not succeeded in generating more revenue! Non-performing loans in Greek banks have risen. Greek banks are shaky and unstable. The entire Greek economic system is based only on a good economic situation at the moment. That is why we have a mealike growth of 1.4%, while the Greek neighbours Bulgaria, Romania and Turkey have 4% or 7% real growth. Greece has the red lantern, including in terms of export growth. All neighbouring countries are growing more strongly in terms of their exports than Greece is doing. Greece is currently benefiting from a certain economic tailwind, but that is all! The moment the economy collapses, when we are once again going to have a recession, Greece will once again be in crisis from which we have not been able to save it, from which there is no way out, as long as Greece has to remain in the euro.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I would like to congratulate Greece on leaving the bailout regime after eight years. We all know that the reform process has been painful for many Greek citizens, but it is very good news that Greece can stand on its feet.  I would like to ask the Commission and the Greek government to continue the implementation of the approved legislation. Full  implementation of EU law will generate convergence in the quality of the interinstitutional framework with the best European countries. It is also the advice of the Liberal Group that the Greek government improve its application of EU law. Delayed payments regulation is a case where the Greek economy would have big dividends to avoid future generation of non-performing loans when the next crisis comes. Moreover, I have seen in the reports provided to the MEPs by the European Parliament that there are EUR 90 billion of unpaid taxes in Greece, so, Mr Centeno, which measures are in place in order to recover these astounding figures? Greek public debt could be lowered very substantially.  It would also be good to understand how revenues from income tax have been lower in 2017 than in 2016, even though the economy of the country is growing. And finally, I would like to call again for the Greek judiciary to drop all charges against Andreas Georgiou. He did his job well when he made public the real figures of Greece’s public debt and deficit 10 years ago. I hope that the path of reforms will continue to grow in the coming years.

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, eight years: it has been eight years since Greece was placed under financial assistance by the European Union. Officially, the country is now coming out of the assistance plan, growth is back, tourism is picking up, the trade balance is in balance, everything is fine, except that for us, these eight years seem like a scandalous mess. Greece's socialist and conservative parties have, for decades, allowed public deficits to slip, notably by failing to collect taxes from their privileged clientele. Nor have they tried to modernize the country's economy. Their responsibility for the disaster is overwhelming. But they were not alone, because if Greece was able to take on debt beyond reasonable, it is because banks, not just Greeks, far from it, have lent to Greece beyond reasonable. And it is ultimately the people of the country who find themselves paying the price for this double irresponsibility. From the outset, successive assistance plans were the sole objective of protecting the financial interests of creditors, i.e. those banks. Once again, European taxpayers have flown to their rescue. Worse, the remedy inflicted on the country is economic nonsense. Greece is expected to generate a substantial primary surplus in the coming decades, which even the International Monetary Fund considers totally impossible. This denial of reality by European creditors has very direct consequences. The Greek people are suffering, they are dying. The suicide rate has increased by 35% in the country since 2008, 20% of Greeks are in extreme poverty and more than 400,000 Greeks have left the country for lack of prospect. The desperation of the population is such that even the neo-Nazi far right has returned to Parliament. Meanwhile, the country's endemic ills - underinvestment, clientelism and fiscal laxity towards the richest - remain. So what should have been done? First, to make lenders bear their share of the responsibility by cancelling, as the IMF intended, a substantial portion of their receivables. Secondly, Mr Moscovici, not after eight years, conditioned European aid on a fair contribution from the richest and on the establishment of a tax administration worthy of the name. The European Union should have put its investment tools at the service of the country's energy transition in order to make Greece capable of being a net exporter of electricity from renewable sources. It could also have borne the costs of taking in refugees, which we know hosts more than its fair share. If nothing can erase the considerable human damage suffered by Greece, it is not too late for the European Union to change course and put justice and economic common sense back at the centre of the relationship that binds it to the cradle of democracy.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, what Mr Centeno and Mr Moscovici have announced to us today, on behalf of the Eurogroup and the Commission, confirms that Greece is taking a very positive step. We are entering a new period, more positive for my country. Those who have contributed to this positive step and fought for it, we are pleased but we are not celebrating. We are not celebrating because a large part of the Greek people have suffered greatly and still suffer from the painful consequences of bankruptcy and savage memorial measures. We're not celebrating because we still have a lot to do.  We are taking the country out of the memoranda, but we must take it out of the crisis once and for all and put it with confidence in the years and decades to come in an avenue of fair and sustainable development. And that means a faster reduction in unemployment, an increase in investment, a modernisation of the administration, to finally end the Land Registry in Greece, which previous governments have left unfinished for 200 years, to combat corruption and tax evasion more effectively. It means more freedom to leave the memoranda, but also more responsibility to keep public finances settled. And I am sorry to hear the "Athens Cassandres", those who are to blame for leaving my country with a deficit of 15.1% in 2009 – and now we have, in 2018, a surplus of 0.8% – to destroy and share.  The truth is that the political forces responsible for the bankruptcy and the memoranda in Greece feel sadness and anger and take on Centeno and Moscovici because it is this government, the Tsipras government, that takes Greece out of the memoranda and bankruptcy and puts it on a path of stable and sustainable development.

name: Marco VALLI
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, after eight years, Greece's macroeconomic adjustment programme has come to an end. However, I cannot understand how anyone finds reason to be complacent and even exult, because over and above those estimates which then prove systematically wrong and overestimated, the troika is in fact leaving a country torn apart, devastated, pulped and even humiliated after a very heavy programme of austerity, privatisation and, above all, wage devaluations. We are well aware that those EUR 270 billion loaned to Greece in exchange for spending cuts and these reforms, which are often useless for growth and harmful, have not been used to support the Greek people and to restore the Greek economy, but have served to pay previous debts to foreign creditors.  What you call the "Greece bailout program" was actually a giant masked bail-out of French and German private banks, heavily exposed to tens of billions of euros in Greek government bonds, to the taxpayers of eurozone countries as a whole, which in 2010 had no exposure to Greek sovereign debt. In other words, France and Germany used the Greek bail-out to spread to eurozone governments all the risks arising from the speculative system that had set up these two banking systems on Greece. Parliament should therefore tell the whole truth about the nature of this bailout and the dramatic state of the Greek economy. I ask what the sacrifices have been for if we have gone from a debt of 109% of GDP in 2008 to almost 180% in 2016 and that does not tend to return to this day. Greece has suffered probably the largest privatisation programme in history: airports, ports, railways, historic real estate, tourism, gas and water companies have all ended up in the hands of private companies, mainly Germans, but also Of China, Qatar and Russia. Yet since 2010 GDP has fallen by 25%, and so has household income. Real investment has fallen by 60% from pre-crisis levels and remains depressed. Since 2010, greek citizens' pensions have suffered 13 consecutive cuts, with a total loss of up to 70% of their value. And that is not the end of it, because within the programme that you have left to Greece, there are other cuts and other measures; unemployment is still over 20%, youth unemployment is over 50%. More than 35% of the Greek population is at risk of poverty. Finally, the population also continues to decline, both because of the fall in births and because of the brain drain. In just eight years, Greece has lost 450 000 citizens who have emigrated abroad.  This is the real photograph of Greece that you should give, and I ask you: are these the results of the European Union?

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ENF Group. Mr President, Commissioner, Mr Centeno, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his work and for the work he has With a capital buffer of 15 billion euros and a ten-year extension, the euro finance ministers have released Greece from the third bailout package. A total of €274 billion in aid has flowed to Greece since 2010. In return, painful reforms had to be implemented – as we have heard several times today – in order to get the country back on a growth path. However, a primary surplus of 3.5% and economic growth of 1.8% cannot hide the fact that unemployment in Greece is still above 20%, the brain drain of young people continues and the public debt is at a daring 178%. The tax burden in Greece today is as high as in Scandinavia, while public services are at Balkan level and incomes are lower than in emerging markets. Massive income and pension cuts, while raising taxes, have dramatically weakened the middle class. Against this background, there is a risk that the Tsipras government will withdraw reforms once the austerity regime comes to an end and the government can refinance itself on the capital market after 20 August. However, this will lead to higher spreads and also more expensive financing, which will continue to weaken competitiveness. And I would like to point out once again that the latest Global Competitiveness Report says that Athens is in the bottom of the rankings, particularly in the financial market development, labour market efficiency and macroeconomic environment. This is where we need to start with in order to restore competitiveness.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: Mr President, anyone who talks about the end of the memorandum in Greece, such as SYRIZA-ANEL, provokes the people with incredible lies. A memorandum of understanding was co-decided in the Eurogroup. This is the fair development in Eu-Union normality that promises industrialists and lenders that all memorandums will apply and new anti-popular measures will be added without end, with crumb salaries, collective agreements and industrial relations rubber, sacrifice in business profits, bloody surpluses for 40 years for debt and capital support, a check on social benefits and auction intensity.  It's a terrible government mockery. Not if, but when will the twenty-fourth statutory pension cut and tax-free reduction be implemented? Supervision not only of institutions, especially capital, is not abolished. It's permanent. The people should not be trapped in false dividing lines between supposedly progressing SYRIZA and maintaining New Democracy the other. The system has found and will find the next useful one for the continuation of the same barbarity, where everyone agrees. The people find their own way to abolish memoranda and recover losses, with organization and struggle, in association with the Communist Party of Greece.

name: Markus FERBER
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which On 22 June 2018, the Eurogroup set the course for the end of the third adjustment programme. This brings to an end a process that began eight years ago and, Mr Gualtieri, at that time, a party called PASOK, called PASOK, ruled, only as a side note. And we have had this aid programme for eight years. The course has certainly been set in the right direction, but I would like to warn against excessive euphoria. For one thing, the whole thing will only pay off if Greece maintains the path of fiscal reason and focus on competitiveness and continues along this path. On the other hand, there are still major problems in the banking sector. A very strong indicator of this is the fact that capital controls still exist. A country that wants to return to the capital market should no longer have capital controls. This is also where the legacy of the crisis is revealed, because at the beginning of the crisis, an extremely large amount of capital was transferred from Greece abroad. During our visit last week, we were informed that more than 50% of this capital has still not been returned to Greece. This, of course, still weakens the banks' deposit base. This weak deposit base, together with the still high stock of default-prone loans on the balance sheets of Greek banks, means that Greek companies are hardly able to refinance on reasonable terms. The ECB's favourable key interest rate simply does not appeal to Greek companies. Even well-positioned, solvent companies – as I could see for myself on the ground – still get loans at an interest rate of around 5%, which is significantly higher than the average for the European Union and the euro area. That is why it is crucial that the Greek banking regulator addresses the deficits in the Greek bank balance sheets, and banking supervision must also play its part in this.

name: Pervenche BERÈS
text: Mr President, Mr President of the Eurogroup, Commissioner, here we are after the conclusions of the Eurogroup on 21 June, which mark the end of a long period which has seen Greece undergo several programmes, over a long period and with great intensity. I think this is a moment to be welcomed. We were, with a delegation from Parliament, in Greece last week, and we can say that there, something has changed and, in this something that has changed, ideology may not be where we think it is. There is sometimes the impression, if not certainty, of a government perfectly in control of its ship, in responsibility, negotiating with international bodies and an opposition that continues to put oil on the fire, an opposition that prefers to see Greece have to take out a new line of credit, rather than accept an extension of maturity in Greece. On the European scene, an opposition that prefers to continue to think that it would be good to have a programme for Greece, not to trust this government, even though it has demonstrated, day after day, its ability to carry out reforms. So of course, not everything is perfect. In Greece, the issue of tax collection will have to remain a priority. It will not be necessary to redefine the conditions of taxation, but rather to continue the improvement of collection. Of course, we also need to learn from it. Greece will have to be helped to develop projects, to ensure that there is administrative capacity, to finance and to support national investment. Of course, Greece must also find a space for countercyclical fiscal policy, this is the space that the conclusions of 21 April allowed. But we also need to learn from the lessons, because we will not be able to start programs again in other countries as we did in Greece. I do not expect that to happen, but if that is to happen, we will have to be more careful about the social and economic cost of such recovery programmes.  And then, this crisis has never been a crisis only of Greece, it is also a crisis that says something about the functioning of the euro area, about the need to have a capacity to stabilize, an investment capacity. This is the whole debate on the future of the euro area, which we must once again put on the job.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, Mr Centeno, although you have tried to create a magical image, the Greek people know from their hard experience that the memoranda have failed. With the three memorandum loan packages, Greece received 240 billion euros. Where did the money go, Mr. Centeno? Where did the EUR 240 billion go, Mr Moscovici? Because if they had fallen into the Greek economy, the country would have taken off. They went to pay off the old loans, they went to save the foreign banks, as Mr Dijsselbloem adamantly confessed, in response to my question.  Thus, with the memoranda, Greece was transformed into a vast social cemetery, with armies of the poor and unemployed, with impoverished pensioners, with our young people migrating. With the eurogroup agreement of 21 June, there is a constant austerity and sell-off of public property by the Occupying Fund, which will operate for 99 years. Elusive primary surpluses are imposed, 3.5% by 2022, 2.2% by 2060. A pension reduction is required in 2019, a tax-free reduction in 2020. All this at a time when the lenders, instead of paying all the loan capital of EUR 86 billion, have encapsulated EUR 24 billion, which could be used, Mr Centeno, to recapitalise the insurance system, to solve the problem of red loans, to create jobs.  So be aware, Mr Centeno and Mr Moscovici, that the Greek people will not tolerate the memorial noose you have passed to them and will soon send you the message. You should know that.

name: Wolf KLINZ
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which I have been to Athens last week to personally see the state of affairs, the state of the country's economy. My initial optimism quickly gave way to sober scepticism after discussions with representatives of the government and Parliament. How can we also consider a country that had debts of 110% of gross national product at the beginning of the crisis and, after the so-called restructuring, 180%? The government expects the economy to develop positively over the next few years. This preview is based on assumptions that are very, very positive, unrealistic in my opinion. A very high primary surplus is expected to restore confidence in the country's debt sustainability. The credit rating agencies continue to give greece only the junk status. Moreover, the government believes that the environment remains positive, that interest rates remain low and that it can successfully implement measures in the pension cut sector – unfortunately – and the tax, all at a time when elections are about to be held again. We know from experience that measures are very difficult to implement in these times. Unlike Commissioner Moscovici, I believe that the Greek Government will very quickly knock back on the EU to obtain new bailouts, especially when the EUR 15 billion in cash it has now received from the bailout programme has been spent. Conclusion: We urgently need an insolvency order for euro area countries.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: Mr President, the statements by European officials, following the last meeting of the Eurogroup, present an embellished picture of the Greek economy, in order to create a success story of the memorandums of the last eight years. The reality, however, is that, while the Greek state has stopped producing deficits, Gross Domestic Product has stagnated over the past five years, since in the previous five years, from 2008 to 2013, it had experienced a terrible decline, by almost 25%.  The absence of growth means that the country's debt-to-GDP ratio can be improved in a real way, so that the problem of over-indebtedness is not solved, but is only transferred for the future, with successive extensions. If lenders want Greece to get back on its feet, they must reduce their long-term demands for primary surpluses to a level of no more than 1% of GDP per year, so as to stop the overtaxation that is killing growth.

name: Patrick O'FLYNN
text: – Mr President, reading the latest OECD summary of the Greek economy yields a very telling sentence: ‘Continuing high excess capacity will limit price and wage pressure’. What ‘high excess capacity’ really means is unemployment at 21%. In my country that would equate to more than six million people out of work, and yet this is Greece’s third adjustment programme.  Greek citizens will be forgiven for asking when the adjustment – now rebadged as enhanced surveillance – will be over because adjustment is, of course, another euphemism. It has meant mass unemployment, tax rises, collapsing public services, rock bottom wages, soaring child poverty and a huge rise in premature deaths. All because the high priests of European integration wish to keep Greece locked into a currency, the euro, that is totally unsuited to its economic needs. With Brexit, the trade war with Trump and the migration crisis, the state of the Greek economy has dropped down the pecking order of EU problems. That does not make it any prettier to watch.  The European Union should drop the idiotic idea driven by integrationist ideology that it is sensible to lock Greece and other southern members into a currency union with Germany. Economic activity in Greece, and in Italy too, is artificially depressed by an overvalued currency. As a result, human talent is wasted and human misery increased.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: Mr President, Mr Moscovici, with the end of the third economic adjustment programme in Greece, the time has come to take stock. And behind this pompous and technocratic term, there is a reality, that of the purge of fiscal austerity that Greece has been obliged to implement in return for debt relief. So the target has been achieved for your Commission and for the ECB, but at what cost? The will of the European Union was clear: the euro had to be saved at all costs in order to preserve the interests of the financial markets. Be honest, the aim of the European Union was not to save Greece and its people. The Greek economy has been depleted by privatisations, its model of social protection ravaged by budget cuts, in short, an entire generation has been sacrificed to ensure the viability of the euro area. Since 2010, wages have fallen by 35%, pensions by 45%, GDP by 27% and investment by 60%. In these circumstances, two conclusions are needed: the euro and austerity are inseparable, thus demonstrating the harmfulness of the single currency. As for Mr. Tsipras, he has gone from the revolutionary left to submission to the troika.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Mr President, President Centeno, Commissioner Moscovici, you have been very pleased with the completion of the third economic adjustment programme for Greece. Do you think the country will return to normality and prosperity, while unbearable economic measures have not yet been implemented and include an additional 18% cut in pensions already reduced by 45%-50% from 1/1/2019, a reduction in the tax-free allowance to around 5,000 thousand from 2020, an increase in the ENFIA and an increase in taxes and insurance contributions? While the other countries are obliged to accept two annual audits by the Commission and the ESM, four will be provided for Greece under enhanced surveillance and this is something that will continue until 75% of the debt amounting to 230 billion is repaid. Primary surpluses of 3.5% by 2022 and 2.2% by 2060. But in which country in the world have such surpluses been achieved?  Mr Centeno, you and the other representatives of the institutions, with the cooperation of an already substantially fallen government in Greece, have managed to commit my joy to a series of new measures, which are doomed to fail, as have the precedents you have idy had. The Greek people will not allow you to.

name: Dariusz ROSATI
text: – Mr President, Greece is about to complete successfully the latest European Stability Mechanism (ESM) assistance programme after more than eight years of strenuous efforts to stabilise public finances and overcome deep recession. More than EUR 240 billion has been disbursed by the euro area Member States to assist Greece since 2010, an impressive proof of European solidarity. Thanks to that, the Greek drama is coming to an end, hopefully, although many doubts have been expressed – including in this House – as to whether this will indeed be the positive scenario. However, as we see it today, the Greek economy is back on the path of growth and the fiscal primary balance turned into a solid surplus of 4% of GDP, which acts as a buffer and a protection against future shocks. At the same time, a number of important reforms have been implemented, including in the areas of the labour market, tax collection, sustainable pensions and bank restructuring. Let me congratulate our Greek friends on those remarkable achievements. However, one of the reasons for that was the decision by the Greek Government not to leave the euro area, despite many calls to the contrary. Today we heard voices claiming that it is because of euro area membership that the Greek economy has suffered so much, but I am of a different opinion. Had Greece decided to leave the euro area, the implications would have been truly catastrophic: even deeper recession, higher unemployment, hyperinflation, mass bankruptcies, the collapse of the banking sector and, of course, not a single euro of assistance from the euro area. However, while celebrating the completion of the ESM programme, we have to emphasise that a lot remains to be done. The Greek economy still remains very fragile. That is why I welcome the decision by the Eurogroup to provide further support to Greece, including three important measures: the abolition of the step—up interest rate, the transfer of Securities Markets Programme (SMP) profit to Greece and, finally, a further deferral of the European Financial Stability Facility (EFSF) repayments by 10 years. I wish our Greek friends good luck for the future.

name: Agnes JONGERIUS
text: Mr President, last week there was a relieved vote in Europe, as the third aid programme expires in August. But is it really right that we should fall into a jubilant mood? The signals seem to be green for Greece: unemployment is falling and the country does indeed have a budget surplus this year, but have the aid packages really helped?  Mr Moscovici pointed to the social measures in the third aid programme, but they were limited and youth unemployment is still sky-high at 42%. Greek debt is the highest in Europe and it will be hanging around the necks of the Greek people for years to go. You can see that the Greek hospitals are understaffed, that the equipment is out of date and that the purchasing power of the Greek population has fallen by a very large percentage.  Which brings me to my question. Wages have sometimes halved in recent years, partly because the system of sectoral collective bargaining has been broken down. Mr. Centeno, you also have experience with the Portuguese aid programme. You also both know that, even by the IMF, there is now a call for an increase in wages in Europe. So my question is: what lessons do you draw from the situation in Europe in which in Greece, but also in other programme countries, the trade unions have been sidelined, people no longer have bargaining power and ultimately are left with non-living wages? How do we prevent such a tragedy in the future?

name: Sander LOONES
text: Mr President, in the euro area, Greece was the wicket of the powder keg for a very long time. That fuse has now been removed thanks to tough, difficult reforms by Greece. Even thanks to the strong financial support of the other partners in the euro area, Greece is no longer an acute danger today. That is a good thing.  The fuse is out, but the powder keg is still there. That's going to have to be the next step. Get the fuse out, but now also get the powder out of that powder keg, so that the eurozone becomes more stable. Because let us not be mistaken: Greece, that was a manageable crisis. If a larger Member State were to get into trouble, we would see something else.  That is why some say there should be a eurozone budget: to absorb shocks. We know where this will lead: to permanent transfers, where northern European countries are plumbered and southern European countries are put into a kind of dependency economy. That's not the answer.  Let's choose the other solution. Let us strengthen responsibility, reintroduce and enforce the no-bail-out clause, opt for clear budgetary rules that we finally enforce. Please.

name: Nils TORVALDS
text: – Mr President, I have a thorough Hellenophilic upbringing because my father was a great admirer of antique Greece. One of his books was called At the Sources and was about places he went to in Greece. However, it doesn’t help to know that the Battle of Marathon took place 2 508 years ago if you aren’t able to run the marathon of economic recovery. In this respect I congratulate the Greek people for what they have achieved during recent years. But at the same time, I would like to remind the Members of the House of the debate we had about the Troika report, with Othmar Karas. If Greece had been forced to follow the bad advice we heard from the left and the right, the situation today would be even worse. So please, use the mirror sometimes: in future, look to yourself and see what you have said.

name: Sofia SAKORAFA
text: Mr President, for Germany to repay the owner's loan and compensation for the damage caused and Greece will return to normality. Because your normality is ferocious primary surpluses for another twenty years, i.e. constant poverty and impoverishment of the people. Enhanced supervision, i.e. strict Commission, i.e. the abolition, in practice, of democratic institutions. Lenders decide everything. Debt regulation, an accounting alchemy of embellishment, i.e. mockery in view of Italy's explosive danger. Reforms, i.e. a long sell-off of public wealth. Even the European Competition Commission, for example, considered the concession price of the National Airport to be humiliating.  This is the normality to which you boast that you have led Greece. In this normality he prides himself on leading Greece, after leaving the memoranda, its "Left" Prime Minister. This is the normality that you propose to the peoples of Europe. The fact that you can impose it today does not negate the tragic results it produces. It is so vulgarly repugnant that your normality is final, that I cannot as a citizen and as a politician but be opposite it, along with all those who resist it.

name: Jörg MEUTHEN
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for his work and for the way in which Hallelujah! Greece is saved! Again. And really the last time. Promised. The reality cannot be ignored by fog candles such as those announced here by Commissioner Moscovici. Greece is over-indebted at 180% of its gross domestic product. Greece's banks still have a huge mountain of non-performing loans. What is being sold here as a success is simply ridiculous! We have said from the outset that we do not want bail-outs because it sets the wrong incentives, because we do not want Germany and the Commission to govern Europe with carrots and sticks. States must be able to go bankrupt because they are sovereign and therefore themselves responsible, including in the eurozone. Eight years of crisis and not a bit of progress for a state insolvency regime. That will take revenge. Because the eurozone is broken. Anyone who is familiar with monetary policy knows this! Who can read bank balance sheets, too. That is why I say to you: do not celebrate. As soon as the euro crisis returns – and it will – we will discuss Greece again. And as soon as the end of the euro approaches, you will think, but not say: those of the Alternative for Germany, they were right at the time.

name: Georgios KYRTSOS
text: Mr President, I would like to use Mr Centeno's presence to raise questions of concern to the Greek public. Firstly, I would like to know why the French proposal linking the growth rate of the Greek economy to the level of the Greek State's interest obligations was abandoned. It was good because it reduced the pressure on the economy and the citizens. Secondly, I welcome the return of central banks' profits from greek bond purchases to 4 to 5 billion euros, but the amount is half of what was foreseen in the second memorandum programme and the difference of 4 to 5 billion euros is extremely valuable for the Greek economy. Thirdly, while the Greek government implemented and committed to implementing more measures than originally envisaged, Greece eventually received 24 billion euros less than the third loan programme envisaged. The difference is great and makes our lives difficult. For example, the Bank of Greece has estimated that 70% of red loans could be settled with 14 billion euros and thus make borrowers and the economy profit. Fourthly, the International Monetary Fund is not involved in financing Greek debt, sending its message to the markets. The Eurogroup, however, retains all the new pension reduction measures – which is why we are fighting politically – abolishing benefits, raising taxes – and this is a huge problem – that were linked to the presence of the International Monetary Fund.  This creates, in conjunction with the delay in the implementation of the prerequisites, a curious situation with us discussing the end of the programme and millions of Greek citizens preparing to foot the bill for the new measures and the timing of dozens of prerequisites. This creates a crisis of credibility, which is related to the European institutions, to the government and – I am not hiding it – to the political system in which it stars and the party to which I belong, because we are talking as if something extremely good is being done – there is progress, I recognise – but we seem to despise the problems of the average citizen.

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: – Mr President, Mario Centeno, this agreement on Greece to which the Eurogroup has reached, under its leadership, is good news not only for Greece but for the euro zone. There are no perfect deals, this one won't be either. Perhaps it goes too far in budgetary targets, falls short of what is needed in long-term debt sustainability measures. But the main thing is that this agreement puts an end to the financial assistance programme for Greece after eight long and difficult years, strengthens financial support to give confidence to the Greek economy and ultimately promotes a major restructuring of public debt that has had to overcome a lot of resistance. So the Greek people deserve our respect for the sacrifices they have made, the Greek Government deserves our recognition for having succeeded where the right has failed and you, as president of the Eurogroup, deserve our support for having reached this agreement for Greece and the euro zone.

name: Pirkko RUOHONEN-LERNER
text: – Mr President, in 2010, the Finnish Parliament discussed for the first time the economic crisis in Greece and the support packages planned for it. At the time, Finance Minister Katainen assured me that the government had taken the line that Greece should take care of its own affairs. This was not the case, however, as emergency loans were started to be tailored to Greece. Now, eight years later, Greece owes almost EUR 350 billion. Of this amount, EUR 260 billion has come from the euro countries and the International Monetary Fund. In exchange for loans, greeks have had to cut pensions, wages and the public sector as a whole, but much remains to be done, for example, in eradicating the shadow economy. Tourism in Greece is recovering and 32 million tourists are expected to enter the country this year. I hope they all know how to demand a receipt for every single transaction. This will allow them to contribute to Greece's economic growth and tax revenues. The aim, of course, is for Greece to repay all its debts.

name: Nikolaos CHOUNTIS
text: Mr President, in the name of debt, the three memoranda imposed on the Greek people the harshest austerity of all time in a time of peace. Not to save Greece from bankruptcy, of course, but, as mr Centeno and Mr Moscovici's predecessors, Mr Dijsselbloem and Mr Olli Rehn, have confessed, to save European banks and the euro. The results for Greece: debt increased, incomes fell, unemployment soared, Middle Ages conditions in the labour market.  The third memorandum was imposed with the neoliberal mutation of the SYRIZA government, while the Greek people in the 2015 referendum had rejected the barbarity of your policies. An official end does not mean an end to austerity and comitology. The Eurogroup agreement formalises every Greek government's submission to excessive surpluses, cuts in social spending, privatisations, the crushing of labour rights for at least the next 45 to 50 years.  On these economic and social ruins you celebrate and congratulate themselves and each other, Mr Centeno and Mr Moscovici, but the Greek people will not stop fighting for democracy, dignity and for the future of their children, fighting to escape the prison of the neoliberal and authoritarian eurozone and the European Union.

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we have also listened here and read in the media the triumphalist tone about Greece's farewell to the troika: but at least here we are telling ourselves the truth. What has Greece achieved? Nothing for debt relief: Germany does not want to, but it has obtained a 10-year postponement of the repayment of 110 billion of the old state-saving fund. And it can continue to repay another 15 billion loans with interest; other debt, then. Greece, therefore, is still under police station: it will undergo quarterly checks, so it will be decided whether to open the taps or impose other structural reforms. I would remind you that next January there will be cuts in pensions, the 15th cut in pensions, and the axe on health, education and, why not, we will also have the imposition of an increase in VAT, or a tax on the first home, in a while. Yet we have a short memory: have we already forgotten about children fainting in the classroom because they are hungry or families living in parks, why have the banks taken their homes away from them? Have we forgotten about the high suicide rate in Greece? We do not forget that! The troika is not over: austerity continues and this is not the solution for Greece or for those states that will continue to be in crisis. So if Tsipras wears his tie back, don't you think that instead the Greek people will continue to wear something that is much more like this (showing a noose)?

name: Othmar KARAS
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. There is a saying by Catherine of Siena, who said: "Not the beginning is rewarded, but only perseverance." We are actually facing a new beginning every day, and we can still say that we have persevered. I would therefore like to start by thanking and warmly congratulating the citizens of Greece and the politicians who were prepared to go through the renewal process with the EU. There is no country in the OECD that has carried out so many reforms in such a short space of time. This is not a matter of course. The fact that all 88 agreed pre-reforms and austerity measures were implemented in the last review, that economic growth has risen from minus 5.5% to 1.4%, that the general government budget has stabilised from a deficit of minus 11.2% to a surplus of around 1%, that the unemployment rate is falling markedly and that the reform of the tax system is proceeding, that was efforts; they are not self-evident. We in the European Union have also learned and had to learn a great deal. But we, too, are not yet finished with the lessons of these experiences. In my joint report with Pervenche Berés on the causes of the crises and the effects, many points have not yet been resolved. Many of the consequences have not yet been dealt with in the joint report with Liem Hoang Ngoc on the Troika. And we must make it clear that all the measures that we have quickly adopted intergovernmentally as emergency solutions must be brought into Community law. This includes an insolvency regulation for euro area countries.

name: Paul TANG
text: – Madam President, to stand on its own feet, that is what we want for Greece and the Greek people, allowing the Greek people and their politicians to make their own choices and their own mistakes. To be a real democracy again. But we are far from that situation. Firstly, a severe restriction in supply. The primary surplus needs to be 3.5% of GDP until 2022 and, after that, the Commission’s analysis shows that it could decline to 2.2% until 2060. This is without any precedent in the world. Related – and secondly – the sustainability of debt is far from assured. Is it a coincidence that a debt sustainability analysis has not been published? It is certainly not a coincidence that the IMF has raised severe doubts about the debt sustainability, and does not participate? Mistakes have been made by Greek politicians, but also by our banks and pension funds. We have a responsibility, but I would rather have seen us taking responsibility by a debt write-off, allowing the Greek people to stand on their own feet and to make their own choices and mistakes. Finally, Eurogroup should do more for Andreas Georgiou. The statistics and the methodology underpinning them have been verified by Eurostat, implying us as well. His fate is also our concern.

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Yesterday, something remarkable happened: the spokeswoman for the ECR Group, Ulrike Trebesius, said that Jean-Claude Juncker was standing up for the United States of Europe. As a result, Juncker has fallen over her, constantly telling lies, rejecting the nationalisation of the EU. What is Juncker advocating for? Let us take European Monetary Union as an example: he wants to make it shock-proof by setting up additional financial pots. That means more power for the Commission, centralisation and bureaucratisation. The relevant monetary commissioners, Pierre Moscovici and Valdis Dombrovskis, are simply reading what their officials have written to them! And the well-being of the citizens of Europe depends on such people without any expertise. Even today I feel like I am in a fairy tale hour. How many times have we been told that Greece has finally been bailed out, and then a new loan package had to be put together again. I am more sympathetic to Verhofstadt's United States of Europe than the Europe of incompetent Commissioners. In the United States of Europe, citizens can opt out of governments and policies, while Juncker's Europe means incapacitation of citizens.

name: Martin SCHIRDEWAN
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for her excellent report Firstly, the Left supports the industrial action of the interpreters here in the European Parliament. But now to the real issue: the end of the bailout programmes for Greece is imminent, and this is good news for Europe and for the Greeks, who look back on eight years of deprivation and painful cuts. But of the €274 billion of aid loans granted to Greece, 95% went directly into debt servicing – that is, €260 billion, which has been transferred directly by the Greek state, and above all to German and French banks.
