The Greek bailout is in fact a bailout programme for the struggling financial sector, and before these so-called bailout programmes began, Greece's public debt was 120%, but today, unfortunately, 180%, partly because of the brutal austerity and austerity programs. And the bailout of the banks has paid the Greek people. Pensions have been reduced by 60% over the last eight years under pressure from the Troika and by 25% in wages. The austerity policies of the Troika and the German government leave behind a largely destroyed welfare state and a still-weakening economy, while Greece has been forced to privatize public property. We must now do everything possible to improve the living conditions of the Greek people, and I wholeheartedly show this. We, as the left, will continue to fight for social progress and public investment in the EU.

name: David COBURN
text: – Madam President, I was watching a piece on television by that great Greek sage, Mr Varoufakis, where he discussed the European Central Bank stress testing the Greek banks. He said that the appearance – the appearance, I say – was given of them passing the stress tests, but in truth the stress tests had simply been made easier. If the ECB had applied the stress test they had used in 2015, three big Greek banks would have failed them, according to Mr Varoufakis.  This is another example of the European Union bending the rules to suit itself, despite claiming the EU is a rules-based or an inflexible organisation. Well we in Britain hear from Mr Barnier that everything will be a disaster if we are not in the single market, and that rules are rules, they cannot be varied. The EU seems to be thoroughly incapable of bending or adjusting the rules to suit Brexit in the case of Northern Ireland. Rather than provide reasonable accommodation, the EU prefers simply to use the tragedy of Northern Ireland as a battering ram to attack Great Britain for its democratic decision to leave the European Union.  It is our democratic right to leave the EU if we want to, and it is not the EU’s business to criticise. We must remember that rules were bent, if not completely rewritten, to allow Greece to enter the euro in the first place, which clearly from recent history should never have happened. The British prefer rules that reflect reality, not rules that ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, Mr President of the Eurogroup, Ladies and Gentlemen, the next Multiannual Financial Framework from 2021 to 2027, the next funds are crucial, they are essential to have a cohesive Europe, a competitive Europe, a secure Europe, but also to have a strong and stable euro area and the President of the Eurogroup has said nothing , has been non-existent.  It was important for us to know, for example, whether the President of the Eurogroup agrees with Parliament's proposal or the Commission's proposal for the next Multiannual Financial Framework and whether we agree, for example, with cuts in cohesion policy and its misstatement: a cut, for example, in the 45 % cohesion fund, which is for the poorest countries , those who have less than 90 % of gross national income per capita; agrees, for example, that richer Member States even have increases in cohesion policy and poorer Member States such as Portugal have 7% and others up to 24 % cuts; or, for example, it is agreed that in the common agricultural policy there should be a 15 % cut, with Portugal cutting direct payments by 10 % and 25 % in rural development.  These are the questions we want because the problems are avoided and it is also important, it is essential that we know what position the President of the Eurogroup has on budgetary capacity. Do you agree with the embryo that is proposed? Do you agree with the EUR 30 billion for a fund to stabilise investment? It also agrees with a national programme for structural reforms of 25 billion and the criteria.  We would like to hear from the President of the Eurogroup on this and we needed a strong and leading president and we hope that this will happen.

name: Jonás FERNÁNDEZ
text: – Madam President, I believe that we should be pleased that Greece can now emerge from the programmes it has undergone in recent years. I would like to congratulate the Greek people, as well as Mário Centeno, on their efforts in recent months.  But I would also like to recall Commissioner Moscovici's work in the first half of 2015, when the programme that is now being negotiated was being negotiated, because his efforts and the efforts of many Socialists in this House would have allowed even that third programme to have been better than the previous two. And, in any case, better than the previous two it has been the one that Greece has implemented in this time.  In any case, the agreement we are entering into leaves questions on the table, because forecasting debt sustainability by 2060 is obviously part of a forecasting exercise, but really with little firm economic basis.  We must therefore continue to be very mindd that Greece must address this debt reduction with strong support from the European partners, that we need to address this clear debt review and that, above all, we must emphasise the need to reform the euro area now, because we continue without deposit insurance , we continue without a good European stability mechanism, we still do not have an anti-cyclical fiscal instrument.  We are in a very, very precarious situation yet, and we have to do that in the coming months.

name: Eleni THEOCHAROUS
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I too express my thanks to the interpreters and my support for their problems which we seem to forget every day. As far as Greece is concerned, you have presented us with a "success story", with the country returning to the markets. You remind me of the "success story" of the Republic of Cyprus, whose economy is once again tragically shocked. Consider, therefore, how troubled and how troubled the Greek people are by the mistakes of their own people and the incorrect prescriptions of the memorandums, for which the Eurogroup, the International Monetary Fund and the European Union as a whole are responsible. To talk about "success story", we must give optimism back to the Greek people.  Therefore, do not tell us that Greece has been saved and that the lengthenings given will eliminate the debt of 300 million. Also, those who applaud today should be well aware that Greece will continue to be under supervision and under budgetary discipline, while national wealth has sold out. New planning with investment initiatives is therefore needed. The Greek people do not want a loan, Madam President, but a boost and incentives to save themselves and stand up again.

name: Maria SPYRAKI
text: Madam President, President Centeno, Commissioner Moscovici, debt regulation is welcome, although it has been delayed by three years. But this medium-term debt settlement is not enough to bring recovery to Greece. In the last three years Greece has seen the development train pass in front of it, but it has not boarded. Greece is pinned down. For Greece to recover it needs confidence, it needs foreign investment, it needs to improve the performance of the public sector, to remove restrictions on the movement of capital. We still have capital control, Mr Moscovici - Mr Weber reminded you - while we are celebrating. We must change the mix of tax policy that eliminates small and medium-sized and self-employed people, increase incomes. I repeat, Greece needs confidence and stability and this government, instead of generating the necessary confidence, is creating instability. The two partners clash in public, Greeks have been paying the bill for years and eight out of ten believe the country is not moving in the right direction.  The post-programme framework of the extended supervision decided on for Greece is clearly stricter than that of Portugal and that of Ireland, and Mr Tang of the Socialists reminded us that commitments to primary surpluses are unprecedented in the world. It is therefore necessary to avoid festive tones. We don't have to beautify reality. Greece needs another strong government, a government committed to its own reform programme that it will implement, a government that will bring stability now that Greece will now be confronted only with the markets and only with its performance.

name: Miltiadis KYRKOS
text: Madam President, Mr Moscovici, Mr President, three memoranda, that is to say three agreements between the Greek people and the European partners, are coming to an end in August. The Greek people have done their part, they have accepted huge reductions in wages, huge reductions in pensions, zero public investment, red health, they have suffered a 25% reduction in Gross National Product, which has not been done except for war, and the European partners have given 240 billion and know-how for too many reforms and now, at the end of the memorandum, which fortunately we are reaching , we see that these reforms, even if they were considered positive and implemented, many of them have only been legislated and certainly have not been implemented. Because otherwise, what is the exit from the memorandums, that is, a country in development, would have been and has not been done.  Because at the moment, we are seeing a cancer of large investments, we are seeing small and medium-sized enterprises not being able to access borrowing, we are seeing too many problems, we are seeing the country slump in the competitiveness index, what we had to gain from the memoranda. So the slogan 'wrong memoranda, wrong governments, wrong Europe' somewhere has support. But to be positive; it is the end of the memoranda and the end of illusions. Now, for the Greek political forces there are no fig leaves, there are no Europeans who define policies. It's our fault if we don't grow, it's our fault if we don't hit the incredible bureaucracy and the customer base. And for that, the removal of illusions, thank you.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Greece can only be released from the so-called bailout program because interest rates are zero. It is not the slightest problem to service an infinite amount of debt if the maturities are constantly extended and interest rates are zero. Because the investments of French and German banks had to be bailed out, Greece was not allowed to default in 2010, and today it has to push a huge mountain of debt ahead of it. Once market interest rates return, Greece has no chance of surviving. The so-called bailout has turned Greece into a vassal of the European Central Bank and the bailout fund. Furthermore, debt reduction is the only real solution. If this had happened as early as 2010, Greece would have defaulted at that time, if there had been an automatic debt cut, it would have been paid by private investors. Today it will have to be public money, and taxpayers will pay for it.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: – Madam President, Mr President of the Eurogroup, Commissioner, it is certainly an important milestone to end the Greek programme and, precisely in order to strengthen Greece's position, the euro zone had to be reformed and, unfortunately, the last Eurogroup summit was a great deal of deceit. When it comes to announce a plan to end the banking union, which has been announced before, even by its predecessors, the result is a disappointing result. It is also disappointing about budgetary capacity and, therefore, I would like you to give us at least an idea of what you think the future might be. In these six months there is a waiting time, at the crucial moment that was the end of the Greek programme in which we could move forward, the results are absolutely deceiting results.  That is why I would leave a question here which is related, moreover, to budgetary capacity and knowing that, for example, the Socialist Party Portuguese, to whose government it belongs, has advocated in all European elections the creation of a European tax, I wonder whether at the level of own revenues, the increase of which we clearly advocate, although not in the form of taxes , what is the position of the President of the Eurogroup and the Minister of Portuguese? Are you the Minister of Portuguese and President of the Eurogroup in favour of creating European taxes? Is that the formula you have to leverage budgetary capacity? So, in addition to clarifying a little more about what, in a propagandistic way, said was a great success and that everyone knows it was a very serious failure, we arrived in June 2018 without a roadmap for the reform of the euro zone. What I was asking is that you answer this question very clearly. Are you for or against the creation of European taxes? Are you or are you not in line with the Socialist party Portuguese?

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: Madam President, my support for the interpreters. Greece was only on the verge of leaving the eurozone in 2015. Some pushed her off the cliff, and Greek politicians as well as some European officials, including some Finance Ministers. And we know who they were. That's why today we have good news. We therefore owe the credit to both Commissioner Moscovici and the President of the Eurogroup, Centeno, but also to some who are not in this Chamber today. For example, in the face of those who pushed Greece off the cliff, this political group and its president shook hands with the Greek people. Apart from governments and ideologies, because we wanted to support the Greek people who suffered and paid huge costs. I close with one question: The conditions we see in Greece and Cyprus require the implementation of a pan-European deposit guarantee scheme.

name: Gunnar HÖKMARK
text: – Madam President, there is no other way to prosperity than through growth and competitiveness. As politicians, we cannot decide on the levels of prosperity, but we can create the preconditions. The main problem is that far too many have believed that you can decide on incomes and welfare. Far too many believed that if you spend more money than you have, in the end you will have more money than you had. That was the road map to austerity because if you spend more money than you have, in the end, you will have no money and you will have no one loaning you the money. What we see today is an achievement for the Greek people, who should be congratulated on that, but let’s remember that it is because of the implemented reforms regarding budgets and structures that we can see these developments. Budget reforms and structural reforms that were rejected by successive governments in Greece, not least the present government, which threw the country once again into a deeper crisis than it was in before, in the belief that you could spend yourself out of the crisis. In the future, it must be the main task of the Commission to ensure that the Stability and Growth Pact is respected. The way to deal with problems in the economy is about reforming and consolidating public spending. It must be learned that we can never achieve anything without ensuring that we have the competitiveness, the growth, the entrepreneurship and the investments that are needed for growth. They can only be created in the respective Member States. The responsibility always lies with the Member States, not with the EU, which financed them with loans, and not on the euro, which is a currency, but on the need for reforms. Let’s make this the big lesson from today: you can change direction, but you need to implement reforms.

name: Eva KAILI
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, thank you first of all for your efforts to rationalize this government in 2015, which cost, according to Commissioner Moscovici's reply, 20 billion before capital controls and much more afterwards. Illusions and wishful feelings, however, conflict with reality. Where did we see the pro-development reforms? In tax, justice, strengthening of independent authorities? The truly progressive leftists would demand the abolition of measures of social injustice and subjugation and would not celebrate a communication fraud and the dominance of the Schäuble logic that was eventually imposed. Extending the maturation of bonds between us makes it easier for this government and Merkel to be willing.  Repayment without a growth clause is a real assassination of the economy, and the 8 billion accounting surpluses, that is, constructed, come from the cessation of internal payments, austerity and tax evasion and, if we may, some colleagues, we do not accept the suggestions to remain silent and not to criticise measures that should have been taken and real pro-investment reforms. After all, I think the Greeks and the French and italians are well aware of this, after the results of our national elections, that we must convince the citizens with substance and without communicative fiestas. But, again, thanks for the support.

name: Theodor Dumitru STOLOJAN
text: – Madam President, we must undoubtedly congratulate all those who, over the years, have contributed to Greece's economic recovery, and at the same time we must stress that it is the Greek people who, ultimately, have borne the brunt of this recovery. And if we are talking about the fact that Greece is doing better today, we must learn from the lessons that Greece has learned over time - and also the European institutions involved in this process. Firstly, for any country with a large debt, there is no recovery but the reforms that need to be made and the understanding of creditors to give the time needed for these reforms to deliver the results. Secondly, in this recovery process, there must always be understanding, the necessary balance between the real capacity of that country doing the reforms and the service of public debt. From this point of view, we must recognise that Greece – if you remember that very warlike finance minister – also wasted time, because they did not understand to make the necessary reforms in time. On the other hand, however, the creditors did not understand that they had to grant financial relief in advance. Finally, many countries have had large fiscal deficits, but where fiscal deficits have been measured, hidden from the Greek people, someone has to pay.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: – Commissioner, Mr President of the Eurogroup, the Greek people have made an extraordinary adjustment effort. Now is the time for the European institutions to do their part. I am pleased to note that there is a positive attitude towards this and I greet you for that. As Portuguese, I am aware of what was the brutal impoverishment that was imposed on us and the price we paid for having a government that believed in the redemptive role of impoverishment. The difference between this strategy and the success of the partnership between the current Portuguese government and the European institutions cannot but be inspiring for the Greek case and for the future of European policies, in particular for the future of the euro area.  It is essential to strengthen budgetary capacity in favour of convergence. The greater the convergence in the euro area, the greater the stability and automatic stabilisation, without prejudice to the mechanisms necessary to ensure long-term stability. Growth and confidence are the key to success. Banking union, investment support programmes, increased own resources, strengthening the stability mechanism are examples of measures that give consistency to this path.  The successful end of a crisis is the best time to avoid the next one and I believe, Mr President of the Eurogroup, that he will do everything in the exercise of his mandate to make that happen.

name: Tom VANDENKENDELAERE
text: Mr President, the Greek economy is picking up, competitiveness has returned and exports are on the rise. The ship avoided the collision course and actually even got a little wind back in the sails. The signals are positive, but we're not there yet. The Greeks have weathered a huge storm. Europe must continue to guide them in order to sustainably anchor the growth rates that the country is now showing.  Economic growth, ladies and gentlemen, and I would like to stress this seriously, must also be inclusive growth. The Greeks have had to make huge cuts, including in their pensions and in their social security. Although there were few other options from a macroeconomic point of view, we really have to acknowledge that this has been a very difficult period for ordinary Greeks. The worst part, I think, is that it is the young people, the generation that has never been able to bear the benefits, who will have to bear the heaviest burden, even in the future. On the positive side, the Greek Government seems to have its budget in order, including a primary surplus. This should allow debt to evolve to a feasible level in the long term.  I believe that getting the Greek debt ratio under control is of paramount importance. Debt restructuring should not be taboo. The debate must be held on this subject, although this can never mean a complete remission. But just as importantly, in the long term, all the promises made are actually kept. Whoever comes to the helm in Athens next year, European finance ministers must continue to monitor the situation. Agreed structural reforms really need to be implemented. I am thinking specifically of the energy sector, the reforms of the administration and the approach to tax fraud. The situation in Greece is so special that enhanced supervision is currently the best option.  Finally, I would also like to emphasise one thing. It is certainly possible for a country to break out of a deep financial, economic crisis without massive devaluations of its currency. The Greek example is a big one for all those who have said otherwise.

name: Siegfried MUREŞAN
text: – Madam President, we are now discussing the conclusion of the third economic adjustment programme for Greece. It has been eight years, and 450 different reforms that were discussed between the Troika and Greece, and what are the conclusions that we can draw now at the end of the process? Firstly, we should do everything it takes to make sure that such a situation of crisis never ever occurs again in Greece or in any other Member State of the Union.  What do we have to do for this? Firstly, we have to make sure that our economies reform, that they become stronger, they remain competitive, they attract private investment, that we support entrepreneurs, SMEs, and of course we have to keep to our budgets in order to make sure that we can react in a situation of crisis. Crisis prevention is so important, because if we do not prevent a crisis, then if we enter into a crisis it’s always more difficult. Crisis brings misery to people, it brings poverty, it brings unemployment, it brings bankruptcy to companies, and we have to avoid this at any price. The second message which I would like to give is that we have to make sure that the sacrifices made by the people of Greece over the last eight years are not in vain. We have to make sure that the country stays on the right track, and for this reforms have to continue. We have to make sure that education is such that children in school are equipped with the right skills to be successful on the labour markets in Greece and internationally. We have to make sure that the public administration is efficient and equipped, populated with experts, not politically driven. These are things that we have to observe not only in Greece but also in many other Member States, but I think it’s important that we draw this conclusion in the end.  And one more thing I want to say. Over these eight years, we have learned that populism is never a solution. We have learned that populists don’t have solutions; they say one thing during the campaign and then we see that what they say during the campaign they either forget it afterwards or it does not work in practice. I know this is a drastic message but we have to say it: stay away from populists.

name: Demetris PAPADAKIS
text: Madam President, it is very positive that Greece is leaving the programme. However, the pace of reforms must be increased before the Greek state can become attractive to investment. No one can forget and celebrate, when the Greek people paid blood for this programme, a programme that was exhausting, far from any logic of Community solidarity. We must always keep this in mind when we say that we want a better Europe.  These days in Cyprus, a new economic drama is developing. The zeroing of guarantees for the Co-operative Bank of Cyprus from non-performing loans leads to a new cycle of insecurity for the Cypriot economy and Cypriot citizens are again being asked to pay the bride. Let me remind you of the 2013 robbery with the notorious bail-in, where we acted as a guinea pig. Responsibilities exist with the Cypriot government and the supervisory authorities of Cyprus which were well below the circumstances. But there are also responsibilities in the European Central Bank, because it could behave differently towards a Member State that has just begun to find its footing in the economy.

name: João FERREIRA
text: – Madam President, Mr President of the Eurogroup, Commissioner, the Greek example is, for now, the most vivid demonstration of what can happen and indeed succeeded in a country peripheral to the euro. The euro cornered the periphery between the sword and the wall: either the blackmail of speculators or the blackmail of the troika. Meanwhile, the euro continues to sour an endless skein of austerity. In the case of Portugal, pressures are renewed to reduce primary public expenditure, particularly in health, and to increase debt expenditure. Less money for health, more money for debt, came to say days ago Mr. Moscovici who sits there. This is the euro: attacks on public services, health, education, social security and wages.  Money exists but disappears into a debt that feeds on itself and what it has to tell us about it, once again the question, Mr President of the Eurogroup. Responding to the country's problems requires addressing the constraints and impositions associated with the euro, those that already exist today and those that are now preparing on the pretext of the so-called reform of the euro.  Assert sovereignty and a sovereign development project based on social progress.

name: Kostadinka KUNEVA
text: Madam President, Mr President of the Eurogroup, you said that the Greek people and the other citizens of Europe should turn the page, that August 2018 is a milestone. You said that there are now good foundations, but they cost us enormously, because we had to make significant changes at the same time. The government of SYRIZA took over a country of clients where the interconnection was in charge. The way the civil service operated was often reminiscent of the Middle Ages. Our country, Greece, and the Greeks have suffered enough: unprecedented unemployment, migration of young people, suicides, humanitarian crisis, painful pressures from lenders. That is why, as a Greek MEP, elected with SYRIZA, who has lifted all this burden of the last programme, I ask you and the Commissioner not to insist on further pension cuts. Greek pensioners who help their unemployed children can't afford any more reductions. Help with this: stabilising and increasing pensions.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Madam President, in 2009 Greece's economy was on the same level as the economies of all euro area countries and was better than many of them. But then the European Union, in cooperation with the International Monetary Fund, led by Germany, as well as with the international lenders, under the tolerance of all the Greek governments of that time until today, decided to destroy Greece's economy for two reasons. Firstly, to rescue the euro and European banks and, secondly, to seize the rich reserves of oil, gas and precious metals that exist in the undersea and subsoil of Greece.  The rest is known. With false evidence they created an illegal, abusive and unsustainable debt, subjected the Greek people to eight years of misery and applied against it a modern form of genocide. There is no doubt that this situation will continue. I end by saying that in this modern Greek tragedy the solution will not be given by the machine god. It will be given by the real god with an instrument of the Greek people, who will very soon implement and impose on the politicians who betrayed him political and legal justice.

name: Pierre MOSCOVICI
text: Member of the Commission. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, thank you for this lively debate, which makes sense as this crisis has both caused pain and passion. But I mean, here, without denying anyone the right to have another feeling, that the completion of the third economic adjustment programme must be seen for what it is, namely excellent news, both for Greece and for the euro area. It shows one thing that I believe we should all be attached to is that we are stronger when we are united than when we are divided. This is proof that responsibility and solidarity are two sides of the same coin and that they must absolutely go hand in hand. We have been able to play on both over the last few years, and certainly even more in recent months. This strategy eventually pays off. So I want to guard here from any triumphalism, but I think that a catastrophism would be very bad.  Today, the truth is not that Greece is out of the woods, because it is not out of the woods, but it is getting better, it is getting up and recovering step by step. By concluding this program, we are creating the conditions for a lasting and powerful rebound. Greece is returning to growth, and its fiscal performance is already impressive. Unemployment is falling, of course too slowly, but it is still falling. So, having said that, there is obviously a lot of work to be done to ensure that all the Greek people finally feel the positive consequences of the efforts made in recent years. I know, on returning from Greece, that the middle class and the most vulnerable still do not feel that the crisis has passed and they are right because they are still paying in their flesh and in their lives the inheritance. We must remedy this and this is the whole philosophy of the 22 June agreement, which Mario presented to you, in which the Commission has been fully involved and in which I fully recognise myself.  I am convinced, as I have said and I will repeat, that the agreement we have reached is the best possible agreement. First, because it is balanced, it responds both to the needs and interests of the Greek people and to the concerns of the partners. It offers freedom - I stress this word again - and time for Greece, which will now be able to concentrate fully on the essentials, as has been said by many of you, with different terms, of course, namely its economic recovery, the creation of strong growth. At the same time, it provides the necessary guarantees and strengthens the confidence of investors' economic partners to ensure a smooth return of Greece to the financial markets. That is what it is about after August 20.  The various arrangements in the agreement will first have to help reduce Greece's debt, which now stands at almost 180% of GDP below 100% of GDP. It is, you will agree, an ambitious approach. There must also be additional resources to make strategic investments in job-rich sectors, in favour of competitiveness, particularly the sectors that the Greeks themselves have identified in their growth strategy. I am thinking of transport, energy, agri-food, the maritime sector, the pharmaceutical sector, sustainable tourism, a whole range of subjects on which Greece has comparative advantages to assert.  Today, that is Greece's priority, it is to make a full commitment to the return of solid growth and this is the key to its full recovery. Much remains to be done. I know this and I say again here that Greece will not take on this task alone. The Europeans and the European Commission will accompany him along the way. Our success will be collective or it will not be. We will work closely with the Greeks, as has been the case for the past eight years. We will do so in the context of the European Semester, and I know the importance of the budget meetings we have in the autumn.  As the economic crisis has hit and destabilized Greece more than any other country, our agreement, it is true, provides for the establishment of enhanced surveillance. This seems to me to be a good compromise for Greece as well as for the European Commission, but you will see that this monitoring is by no means a fourth programme. I have heard the criticism, I have heard the questions and I want to emphasize this one last time. No! No, no, enhanced surveillance is not a fourth program in disguise. It serves to preserve the momentum of reform, to strengthen credibility, which will be crucial for Greece during the period after the program. This will reassure european markets, investors and partners. It will also help to contain the internal pressures that are bound to emerge over the years to influence the responsible policies that are needed. So I was accused here, as I was in Athens yesterday, of playing I don't know what political game occupied by I don't know what ambition. What I understood, in any case, in Athens yesterday, and still today, is that it is true that elections started in the heads, but not the European elections and not for me, but the elections in Greece for some. I understood that for some, criticizing, criticizing and criticizing again was part of the game. I say this here, I do not find this attitude honest, because the Commission has been with all the Greek governments, as I have. I have worked well with Antonis Samaras, the previous Prime Minister of the New Democracy party, I have worked well with his ministers, Mr Stournaras and Mr Hardouvelis and I work well with Alexis Tsipras, I also work well with Euclid Tsakalotos. I had a little more trouble with Yanis Varoufakis, not because they are from the Syrisa party, but because I love Greece and the Commission stands with Greece. So please - I say to those who indulge in facilities - political passions are what they are, and we all experience them, but they must not lead to a discrediting of a good agreement. In doing so, we are playing against his country and me, I want to play for Europe and I want to play for and with Greece.  I think once again that this agreement is not perfect, that the situation still needs to be improved many times, but that we are really in the right direction, and I would like this Parliament in its diversity to simply recognise that. It is a question of honesty and truth, and that is what has always guided me.

name: Pierre MOSCOVICI
text: President of the Eurogroup. – Madam President, after listening to all your interesting and well placed comments, concerns and questions, I am even more convinced that given its diversity, future success for Greece depends on the resilience that the current reform process can show across political and economic cycles. Respecting the hardship that the Greek people have experienced in the last eight years is crucial for the continuation of this reform process. And this is the only way that we can show that this is, and was, really not in vain.  Let me stress that reforms take time to mature. Reforms take time to have an effect. And this time that we need to provide this reform process with in a society is best given by its institutions. And in Europe this includes the European institutions, and of course the European Parliament. That is what our citizens expect from us. We need to make our institutions stronger. We need to make them work.  If we look back, we can conclude that we have come a long way and, indeed, as many of you stressed, not everything has been easy. In the past eight years, both Greece and the euro area had to overcome hardship. We were pushed to the limit very often. Together, however, I think I can say today that we have learned a lot. No doubt we were not fully prepared to deal with this crisis at its outset. Many things had to be tried and learned on the go. We all indeed paid a price for that, yet we managed to overcome the obstacles on our way.  Some of you mentioned concerns vis-à-vis the ongoing legal proceedings against the former president and senior staff of ELSTAT, and those are indeed a matter of serious concern. We have asked the institutions to monitor developments and report to us in the context of the post—programme framework. Of course it goes without saying that we fully respect the independence of the Greek judiciary, but this is a matter that we need to follow up.  Reforms are needed, continuing the process of reform is needed, and I am going to stress here a special role – some of you also mentioned this – for public administration reform, and we deem public administration reform for tax collection. That must continue to improve in Greece.  Over those concerns, I must say in any case – and this is my main message here today – that we have many reasons to be proud. Today, Greece joins Ireland, Portugal, Cyprus and Spain and prepares for the post-programme period. Greece is ready to turn over a new leaf and is well equipped for ensuring sustainable, balanced and inclusive growth.  It is not just Greece but also the euro that emerges stronger from this experience. Our single currency area has become more resilient and much wiser. It has several tools and solutions to withstand the next crisis, and we are working to strengthen it even more.  For those of you who expressed concerns over the success of the Greek programmes ahead of us, I would urge you to think of the Portuguese experience and of the subsequent waves of reforms that followed the exit of the programme in Portugal and that guaranteed a sustainable success for the exit. The Portuguese example is a good example for us to be aware of. To finalise, I would just like to say that we are committed to making sure that another eight such years will never be repeated again.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Sirpa PIETIKÄINEN
text: Written. – The third and final financial assistance scheme granted to Greece is due to expire on 20 June 2005. August. Investors' confidence in the Greek economy has strengthened sufficiently to allow the country to exit external aid to private markets. It is important that cooperation between the EU and the Greek administration continues even after the end of the adjustment programme and that Greece continues with the agreed reforms that will continue to keep the economy on a sustainable footing.  The completion of the support programme demonstrates the functioning of the EU's common economic policy. Thanks to the difficult solutions that have been taken, Greece's departure from the euro and systemic shock throughout the euro area were averted. For euro countries, the adjustment programme has meant granting emergency loans, but has saved the stability of the euro area, thereby reducing costs to taxpayers in the long term. Of the EUR 86 billion set up for the scheme, EUR 25 billion, or almost a third, remains unused. Greece's example shows that the euro area's ability to intervene in crises must be strengthened. The development of the European Monetary Fund on the basis of the stability mechanism and the completion of the Banking Union would bring the necessary predictability and promptness to crisis situations in the future.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. – The Greek example is, for now, the most vivid demonstration of what can happen, and indeed has succeeded, a peripheral country of the Euro. The Euro cornered the periphery between the sword and the wall: either the blackmail of the speculators, or the blackmail of the troika.  Meanwhile, the Euro continues to sour the endless skein of austerity. In the case of Portugal, pressures are renewed to reduce primary public expenditure, in particular in the health sector, and to increase the expenditure associated with debt payment. Less money for health, more money for debt: he told the European Commission a few days ago.  This is the euro. Attack on public services, health, education, social security and wages. Money exists, but it disappears into a debt that feeds on itself.  Responding to the country's problems requires addressing the constraints and impositions associated with the Euro – those that already exist today and those preparing on the pretext of the so-called reform of the Euro. It requires asserting national sovereignty and a sovereign development project based on social progress.

name: Elissavet VOZEMBERG-VRIONIDI
text: Writing. – Optimistic estimates of the Greek economy refer to the well-known saying "numbers prosper but the people suffer". By general admission, the Greeks in the years of crisis have been tested hard and have been subjected to great sacrifices, but they do not have the desired impact. Greece is again forced into perpetual austerity, as it is called upon to show high surpluses continuously until 2060, which is a common secret that no country in economic times has succeeded. Attempting to embellish the situation does not change the image of the real economy, with one in two taxpayers having overdue debts to the tax office and one in three being in danger or already in foreclosure. How does the expression of confidence in the Greek economy go hand in hand with the obligation to strengthen post-monumental supervision, frequent controls, a series of new tough measures and a financial cushion of EUR 24 billion? Greece needs the support of the EU and its partners but also a government that believes in reforms and especially in an investment-attractive tax environment. Only in this way will the economy escape the unattainable surplus and the bonus policy and be led on the path of sustainable dynamic growth, which will create new jobs and wealth generation.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: Writing. – Our fellow citizens cannot believe that the crisis is over, because no one is experiencing a significant improvement in their pocket, in the family budget, in their daily lives. The Greek economy will come back when society really breathes. When the real economy, small and medium-sized enterprises and family businesses are decisively strengthened, and when substantial investments are made to combat unemployment and create jobs with quality conditions and fair wages for workers. Today, when youth unemployment remains the highest, when the country says goodbye to citizens of all ages and speciality who leave abroad, no one has the right to celebrate.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: The next item is the topical debate in accordance with Rule 153a of the Rules of Procedure on the recent statement by the Italian Minister of the Interior on the Sinti and Roma population and minority rights in the EU (2018/2777(RSP)).  I would like to inform Members that, exceptionally, there is no catch-the-eye procedure in this debate and blue card questions are not accepted.

name: Marco AFFRONTE
text: Author. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it was well known that Salvini represented a party with xenophobic and racist tendencies. I have no hesitation in using these words, even if they are strong, because they are amply confirmed by a number of statements we have had over the years. What we did not know was that the League would find support to govern the Five Star Movement and that it would be able to sign a government contract in which, for example, support for free daycare services for Italian families is used, in clear contradiction to Article 3 of the Constitution, which prohibits distinctions on the basis of sex. , to race, religion, etc. It was only the beginning, because this government immediately clarified who its enemies were: the different and the minorities. The different in every sense. The Minister for The Family immediately stated that there is no family other than a father and a mother, in the face of LGBT rights. Then the migrants, who have become scapegoats for all the evils of a country that instead has very deep suffering. Finally, it was the turn of the Roma and Sinti: after a few days in office Minister Salvini decides to proclaim that he will make a census, but adding, so as not to leave any doubt as to what his ethnic contempt is, that "unfortunately the Italian ones we must keep". Imagine the indignation! No, i don't! Or certainly not enough. The problem is precisely that, unlike perhaps what would have happened a few years ago, there has been a lack of a really strong reaction. How is such an attitude possible and where does it come from? It also comes from here, from Brussels, from the European institutions and from the Heads of Government in the Council who are not in a position to decide anything; they can't give a signal! As far as they're told, they don't even have reference values. I am talking about Hungary, France and Austria, but I could go on for quite a while. It is our reference values that we have lost, because on the modalities and technical ities to deal with any type of emergency, not only that of migration or economic, we can clash or agree: but the values, those must be clear, they must be firm and they are no longer. I turn to President Tajani – I am sorry he is not here: when the Italian Minister of the Interior spoke about the Roma census, where were you? I immediately took the initiative of writing to you, involving the other political groups as well, asking you for Parliament to reaffirm one of the founding principles of our Europe: 'United in diversity', which our lemma. The European Union was born after the tragedies of the Second World War, where millions of people died as a result of supposed diversity. Consequently, the European Parliament cannot remain motionless, astonished and silent in the face of the words of hatred that we have heard in too many quarters, certainly not only from Italy, in recent years. Do you remember, Mr Tajani, when in 2009, parliament strongly opposed a similar initiative by Maroni, also from the League? I wonder why, after so many days, you have not yet done anything, nor have you responded to a letter signed by the chairmen of four political groups in this Parliament and dozens of Members, including your group, and instead continues with statements that are more like party leaders.  Another sign of the loss of the values that should found Europe in a race to those who are most hypocritical: we sign an agreement in the Council and in less than 24 hours there are so many distinctions that we have returned to a point even before the agreement. But who do we want to make fun of? How can we then be surprised that the citizens we govern and who see us behaving in this way do not do the same? We can spend years talking about standards, but first of all we must tackle the crisis of values that is gripped by Europe and, unfortunately, also by my country, Italy.

name: Karoline EDTSTADLER
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, thank you for the opportunity to speak here today. Of course, as you will understand, it is not for the Presidency to comment on public statements made by individual ministers in Member States. Instead, I would like to build on what the Bulgarian Presidency said when you discussed the situation of the Roma at your last session. Firstly, I would like to recall that equality is a core value of the European Union and that it is a value we rigidly uphold. It is part of the European pillar of social rights jointly proclaimed by Parliament, the Council and the Commission at the end of last year. In our joint proclamation, we once again committed ourselves to the principle of equal treatment and opportunity, regardless of racial or ethnic origin. We also stated that equal opportunities for under-represented groups would be fostered. Allow me to add a personal note to this discussion as I am politically responsible for the Mauthausen Memorial, the former concentration camp in Austria where approximately 100 000 people were killed during the Second World War. Most of them were Jews but there were also homosexuals, people who opposed and fought against the Nazi regime and Roma and Sinti. It is essential, especially in the commemorative year which we are celebrating in Austria in 2018, to uphold this memory but it is not less important tirelessly to seek equal rights for all these groups. We all know that many Roma in Europe face deep poverty, social exclusion and racial discrimination and we know we must do more to put this right. I am sure we all agree on one thing: a Europe that protects should especially protect those who find themselves in the most vulnerable situations. In this spirit, seven years ago, the Council, the Commission and Parliament jointly called for action across Europe to improve the situation of Roma. We successfully launched an EU framework for national Roma integration strategies. As part of this drive to improve the life chances of some of our most vulnerable citizens, the Council, like Parliament, has strongly emphasised the importance of fighting discrimination and prejudice against Roma – a specific form of racism known as anti-Gypsyism. Anti-Gypsyism is a root cause of the social exclusion of Roma. I would also like to take this opportunity to recall the Council’s position on hate speech, racism and the fight against discrimination. On several occasions the Council has invited Member States to ensure the effective transposition and implementation at national level of the Framework Decision on Combating Racism and Xenophobia, as well as other relevant hate crime laws, in order to counter the plague of hate crime. In addition, the Council has asked Member States to develop effective methods to report, and ensure the proper recording of, hate crimes. Moreover, the Council supports the ambitious plans of the Commission high-level group seeking to develop, with Member States, concrete practices and tools to improve responses to racism, xenophobia and other forms of intolerance. We also welcome and support the ongoing EU-level dialogue with major IT companies to address hate speech online. Last, but not least, we should remember and commend the remarkable work done by the Fundamental Rights Agency in this field, and concerning Roma in particular. Equal treatment is not just an ideal but a solid principle enshrined in European law. The Council has already adopted a directive that prohibits discrimination on grounds of racial or ethnic origin. This directive protects, inter alia, the rights of Roma, Europe’s largest ethnic minority. The framework we established in 2011 is due to expire in 2020. The Council stands ready to work further on this important subject. Already, in 2006, the Council called on the Commission to propose a post-2020 strategy on Roma integration. The matter is urgent: the rights and wellbeing of millions of European citizens are at stake.

name: Karoline EDTSTADLER
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, in 2011 the Commission adopted the EU framework for a national Roma integration strategy up to 2020. This came at a time when the Roma people were facing a series of threats and pressures and, in response to the Council, I can confirm that we are now working on the evaluation of this framework, with the aim of preparing the ground for the new strategy after 2020. But back to today’s reality. It is regrettable to see that, seven years later, similar issues are re-entering public discourse in some Member States. The Commission has always made it clear that the fundamental rights of EU citizens, including free movement and non-discrimination on grounds of ethnicity, must be respected. Respect for fundamental rights is a key European achievement which both promotes and gives concrete expression to mutual understanding, openness and tolerance in European societies. While all EU citizens have the right to move and reside freely within the EU, this must be done within the conditions and limitations set out in EU law. As regards stateless persons, Member States are bound by obligations under international law. In particular, the 1954 Convention Relating to the Status of Stateless Persons and the 1961 Convention on the Reduction of Statelessness. However, not all the Member States of the European Union are signatories of these conventions. Under the EU Treaties, for migration and border-control purposes, stateless people are considered as third-country nationals, and expulsion of stateless persons to third countries is possible only if carried out in line with EU law as set out in the Return Directive. This directive is applicable to all third-country nationals, for instance all persons who are not EU citizens staying illegally on the territory of an EU Member State. Where challenges arise because the presence of marginalised Roma communities is placing particular strains on some localities, the Commission supports the efforts of local authorities to improve their social inclusion by promoting good practices and also, of course, the effective use of available EU funds. In its latest assessment of the implementation of Italy’s national Roma integration strategy, the Commission emphasised that addressing the issue of camps should be carried out within an integrated approach, fully respecting individual rights and freedoms, and addressing simultaneously the challenges in the areas of education, employment and health. It is evident that Member States have to be reminded of their commitment made in 2011 when the EU framework was adopted by consensus in the Council. More importantly, it must be clear that inclusion cannot be achieved by denying people’s fundamental rights and violating human dignity. The Commission condemns all manifestations of racism and xenophobia, as these phenomena are incompatible with the values and principles on which the European Union is based. Statements associating anti-social behaviour or criminality with people of a certain ethnic origin or nationality are stigmatising and totally unacceptable. They fuel racism and xenophobia, they can contribute to the spread of intolerance in society and they are therefore very damaging. Public authorities must distance themselves from, and actively rebut, such discourses targeting Roma, and proactively fight against racist and xenophobic behaviour.

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, let me start by firmly condemning every act, speech, intention – direct or indirect – that negatively addresses my people, the Roma, and every discriminatory practice against them. In the era of fake news, we can never be 100% sure what is reality and what is overreaction or misinterpreted, so I contacted Mr Salvini’s cabinet, with the help of colleagues here in the Chamber, to learn the real plans so that I could help the Italian Government to make Roma integration in Italy a reality instead of an utter failure. According to the latest news, Mr Salvini downplayed his comments, arguing that the intention of the census proposal was to examine how European funds were being used and investigate life in the camps. The EU Roma strategy, as you said, was initiated by Parliament and endorsed by the Hungarian Presidency in 2011. It was designed significantly and swiftly to improve the situation of the Roma, but there is a lot to do and this debate can speed it up. In this regard, if the latest news in this case is true, Mr Salvini is partly right. There is an acute need to examine whether the European funds that were used for the situation of the Roma have effected change or not, for better or worse. Nowadays, every fifth European citizen is poor: more than 100 million. The next workers’ generation will come from these poor families. Less than 7% are Roma and 5% to 10% have a migrant background and came in the last 30 years. So what can be done? With this report that you are talking about, Ms Jourová, that the European Union Agency for Fundamental Rights (FRA) is preparing, you can make history and big changes. Parliament initiated this in 2010 and the Commission was not strong enough to take it on board to the Council. In the end, the Council even vetoed the monitoring. Without these mistakes that you made, we would not be debating this issue here today, so what I’m asking Mr Kurz to do is to upscale this strategy to an EUR 120 million anti-poverty strategy for all European citizens. We have the knowledge and the money to do this and I think it is the only way that this issue can be solved. We are counting on Austria especially as, in the 1980s, it became the first country to resolve persecution of the Roma after we were hit by Molotov cocktails in Oberwart and so many people died.

name: Soraya POST
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, Lívia Járóka really surprised me in a negative way; I will not comment on that anymore, but really!  Salvini has shown us what we can expect from a populist and far-right government: absolutely no respect for either national or European law. Such governments say no to people in need and leave them to die in the sea. Such governments want to register Roma people so that they can deport them. Such governments attack, criminalise and exclude those who do not fit into their racially dictated boxes.  Such governments use our democratic tools to crash our jointly-built democracy, our commonly set European values, which we have worked on together for decades. Such governments incite fear, hatred, anger, and make innocent people scapegoats and treat them as criminals. We have already seen the horrific consequences of such political groups gaining ground in Europe, but it seems that our European memory is very short.  Fellow citizens, we are at the crossroads. We have to decide if we want to keep an open, democratic society, or if we want to live in a Europe of growing intolerance and racism. The choice is yours, and it is one with far-reaching consequences. And to those politicians feeding hatred, intolerance and fear in order to get votes and gain power: what are you? I say, shame on you!  Finally, let me use this opportunity to raise my voice for those Roma people who have been targeted, injured or killed by far-right groups in Ukraine recently. Colleagues, the reality is that there are pogroms in Europe in 2018. I urge President Poroshenko and the Ukrainian Government to condemn the recent horrific acts of violence and killings, and to condemn police negligence. I demand a proper investigation of the cases, fair legal procedures, and I demand measures aiming at Roma inclusion and countering anti—Gypsyism. And to end my intervention, I ask you nationalists, the far-right, to act as human beings and to stop hunting Roma as if they were animals. (Applause)

name: Anders Primdahl VISTISEN
text: for the ECR Group. Mr President! Today's debate follows in a long and sad tradition here in the European Parliament, where every time a government is elected in a European country with which one politically disagrees, a shame game and such built-up indignation here from the hallowed halls of Europe is intended to target those voters who have expressed their dismay. , the Brussels bubble has formed a consensus on this.  It started with the condemnation of the Jörg Haider government in Austria in the late 90s, it continued with an endless stream of accusations against governments in Poland and in Hungary, in Slovakia and in Malta. And now we have reached the next country in line, namely Italy, which has chosen to elect a government that is not being dis whom is not the same here in Brussels. That is why we must now use our time in the Plenary To debate the statements of an Italian minister, a former colleague, who has been taken out of context and which can only be used to feed the indignation that is clearly felt in this city. But that indignation is an impotence! It is a powerlessness because most of the colleagues in this House are losing at the national level. You have lost the trust of your people. Europe is in fundamental crisis, and if you want to save the European project, you have to listen to the concerns of Europeans and not continue to ignore them, as we almost always do here in Brussels. I wish the new Italian Government every success in getting to grips with the Italian domestic policy situation, and I hope that more people will listen to this sense that is coming, instead of continuing the policy of stopping the ears and continuing as if nothing had happened!

name: Cecilia WIKSTRÖM
text: On the other: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Frankly, Madam President, I am frightened when I hear Mr Salvini's statement on the Roma, and I ask myself two questions. Firstly, where has his humanity gone? And secondly, where is Italy as a country going? Italy was one of the founding countries at the time of the creation of the European Union, a Union built on fundamental values of tolerance and freedom. We cannot accept Mr Salvini's statement that Roma should be recorded in illegal registers, it goes against democratic principles and brings the idea back to history, the days of fascism. That is also how the Roma Holocaust once began. We must distance ourselves from this statement here and now. Systematic discrimination, marginalisation and discrimination against Roma must be put to an end. European citizens should neither be kept in registers nor deported because of their ethnicity. I am scaremonfor giving you the fact that today we have witnessed such a limitlessly offensive statement by an Italian Minister for the Interior, who has also been a Member of this House for a number of years. The recent xenophobic, undemocratic development in Italy is a major step in the wrong direction. I would like to remind Mr Salvini and all his like-minded people on this day who threaten and excite the Roma and other minorities that every single person, regardless of who you are and where you come from, is human beings and has the right to be met with dignity and respect. It is a lesson that this House must put – literally – into those that question these rights.

name: Romeo FRANZ
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which When a minister in a European Member State calls for the inclusion of an ethnic minority, he either has no knowledge of the history of National Socialism in Europe or a national-ideological and racist attitude. Both disqualifia a European and also a minister of a democratic constitutional state. Ethnic sensing has a cruel past, as every school child learns in history lessons. Ten years ago, this House made it very clear that a roma database in Italy is contrary to fundamental rights and cannot be accepted.  Mr Salvini, I am addressing you directly, you are criminalising an entire European minority with your demand and deliberately inciting hatred and racism. Your claim violates national and international law. Do you want Ukrainian conditions in Italy, Mr Salvini? In Ukraine, pogroms against Roma took place this year, claiming many casualties, including women and children. A 24-year-old from Rome, D'vid Papp, was assassinated by Ukrainian Nazis on 23 June 2018. Mr Salvini, I ask you: do you want blood to stick to your fingers? Because your racist statements lead precisely there: to a hatred of citizens who are people with a Romno background. Mr Salvini, you attacked me personally. I, Romeo Franz, am Sinto and the son of a Holocaust survivor. I am here to tell you that there is no place in Europe for racism and national ideology. Because we've had that before. And we all know, ladies and gentlemen, what the consequences of such incitement can be. Mr Salvini, your racism blinds you and your supporters to such an extent that you do not recognise the potential of your Italian minority, let alone use it! This does not serve your country! Ladies and gentlemen, we must not allow the racists to weaken our rule of law and democracy in our country, in our Europe. We must maintain human rights and humanity as the foundations for a peaceful Europe!

name: Cornelia ERNST
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Thank you to the previous speaker. And the most important thing, however, first of all, is not enough: a small rebuke from Prime Minister Conte against his interior minister, who uses fascist strategies to promote domestic racism. What we are asking for is the resignation of Salvini. I think that is something that needs to be said. Racist incitement does not belong in a single political office, even in Italy. The registration of Roma is pure racism, because people are then distinguished by blood and race. We know from the history of the 20th century that the counting of Roma in the Hitler Empire as well as of Jews was the starting point of the practice of so-called racial disgrace, of racial law, segregation, devaluation, expulsion, extermination. The Holocaust of both minorities needed the demarcation from others, the devaluation, as a prerequisite. In Nazi Germany, there were plaques in schools where Jews and Gypsies were presented as worthless and useless, as the lowest category of all living beings. Every animal, every insect was considered more than these two minorities. This was the Third Reich, and we must never go back to that spirit.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we are tired of lies and instrumental attacks on Minister Salvini and Italy. Salvini is 100% right when he talks about clearing illegal Roma camps and he is right when he talks about the control and census of those who live in authorized Roma camps, censuses already made, in fact, very badly by left-wing administrations, such as the Municipality of Milan and the Emilia Romagna Region. And no one then ever shouted at the scandal. The state must know who lives on its territory. The state has a duty to ensure public safety and to control areas with a high rate of illegality. Read the newspapers, watch television and every day you will find avalanches of news about the problems caused by the Roma. Ask the police, the mayors, the citizens who have the misfortune to live next to the Roma camps. Italians are tired of seeing abusive Roma camps where everything happens; they are tired of knowing that Europe is giving millions of euros to the Roma for integration which, in fact, does not exist. For us, the Roma must have the same rights, but above all the same duties as the Italians. They have to comply with the law, they have to pay taxes, they have to be registered, they have to send the children to school and not to beg or steal. And don't let us say we're racist, because we're not. We only tell the truth and we want security, respect for the law and justice in Italy. That is why the citizens voted for us, and we and Minister Salvini will do this: in the face of the false good-natured people of the Italian and European left.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: Untruths are not made more accurate by repetition. I have a point of soothe d'e.g. from Soraya Post. But on a point of order, please. (Loud heckling)

name: Soraya POST
text: – (Point of Order) Madam President, I would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur on his excellent I would like the President-in-Office to record the use of discriminatory, xenophobic language. It is not allowed in this House. This is the heart of democracy in Europe, so shut up!

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: Thank you, Mrs Post. I will... (Loud heckling) Please be calm. I will report your request to the President and we will then discuss it in the appropriate bodies.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: – Madam President, Madam Minister, Commissioner, Ladies and Gentlemen, it seems that today this idea that political discourse must be inflamed and controversial, over everything and against almost everyone, and without any consideration of an ideological or ethical nature. The Italian Interior Minister is a paradigmatic example of this new way of being. Racial censuses are absolutely intolerable. They violate the most basic values and principles of our Union. They recall and are dangerously similar to other times in European history, where their darkest pages appear. We are therefore not discussing what the Union can and cannot do more to better protect and integrate the most numerous ethnic minority in Europe, whose territory has been closed for centuries. The aim of this debate is to make measures taken by the Italian Minister, which are charged with discrimination, which have no place in the European Union or any of its Member States.  He's back in the light of day, which he never hid much. The Roma community remains discriminated against and has serious integration problems. We can and must better use the means available to the Union. But let us be clear: there is no place in our Union for xenophobic policies.

name: Tanja FAJON
text: – The human count is as old as humanity. It is used for different statistics and allows for different interpretations.  As democracy, new technologies and social insights develop, such counts are becoming more and more counting of Earthlings, and less and less attention is being paid to the religious, ethical, sexual and other affiliation or orientation of people. Because in a globalised, colourful world, we really should be interested in it. Such a modern, efficient and cheaper way of censusing in the Union is used by the Netherlands, Denmark, Finland and Slovenia. And then in Italy, the utterly reactionary Matteo, in mockery of the European Union, fundamental rights, the Italian Constitution and European law, suddenly announces the censor of the Roma. He simply adds that the measure is full, with the mention of expulsion, that he will unfortunately not be able to deport the Italian Roma. Anyone who does not recognise the serious danger should review the historical textbooks. Italian history alone is telling enough. Under public pressure and after even his right-wing colleagues failed to attract him, Salvini tried to soften his statements. Too transparent an experiment! Today Roma, tomorrow disabled, then the whole world.  Dear colleagues, dear Europeans, such an announcement by a man who, on top of everything, is the interior minister of a founding member of the Union, is worth taking immediate action, because when Matteo Salvini and his clique wear black shirts, there will be no more elegance, no thucation, no thuation, no democracy, it will be too late.  On behalf of the citizens who elected us, please stop the xenophobic rhetoric reminiscent of fascism, the dark period of Italian history.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: – Dear Chairman, the new Italian Government is an expression of the free will of the Italians. We don't have to like her, but we have to work with her. It is easy to be angry with Italy today for certain statements or policies of its officials, but we must not forget how many lives were saved in Italian waters, how many of the afflicted first experienced freedom by agreeing to Italian shores and how many migrants the country has received in the past fifteen years. Entering the eurozone has brought great dissatisfaction to Italy, and has been hit hard by the economic crisis. Italy's public finances are still volatile, and citizens are clearly on the verge of patience. We should not be surprised that in such circumstances more and more people are looking at those who often and illegally use the social system rather than contribute. But any responsible authority, even if it wants to correct certain irregularities, must be careful not to aggravate the situation with its actions and to bring insurmounmental divisions among people. I call on the new Italian government to truly be held accountable.

name: Maite PAGAZAURTUNDÚA
text: – Madam President, in this Parliament we have heard insults before to Italian Roma. A friend of Salvini's did it. Some say it's just a provocation. Removing importance is an absolute mistake.  Because it cultivates sectarian language from power and its political partners have agreed to skip a red line from the European Union, to stigmatize a human collective: Italian citizens of Roma origin. Gypsies and migrants are two lightning rods to channel the hatred and frustration of Italians in order to attract votes. It's a villainy. How can you be so unashamed to talk about doing a specific census of gypsies? Have you forgotten the Italian racial laws that were enacted from 1938 to 1944? Have you read the biography of Italian Nobel laureate Rita Levi Montalcini, who suffered them? Or the family history of Natalia Ginzburg, who also suffered them? Have decades of fascism in Italy left no memory of how dangerous it is to stigmatize groups and decide who is a good citizen or a bad citizen? It does not deserve someone like this to be in a democratic government and, of course we, will certainly fight this kind of manipulation with all my might.

name: Miroslavs MITROFANOVS
text: – Madam President, the European Union is based on common values. Among them is that of respect for all nations and minorities and equal treatment for all EU residents, regardless of their origin, native language or religion. For many decades, these principles promoted the peaceful coexistence of many peoples who had been mutual enemies in their recent past. Now the atmosphere in Europe is changing. The hate speech against minorities in a number of EU countries is no longer associated with marginal political radicals, but is becoming a part of the everyday rhetoric of mainstream politicians. I see this as the main problem. The starting point for today’s discussion was some xenophobic attacks by Italian ruling politicians against the Roma minority but there are also examples of hate speech from other countries. Two months ago, Kārlis Šadurskis, the Latvian Minister for Education, appealing to the Latvian Parliament, spoke about tolerance regarding minorities and then, and I quote the Minister for Education, said: ‘Over-expressed tolerance and empathy [toward minorities] have been a threat to the Latvian state, and we have to make every effort to eliminate this.’ However, Jānis Iesalnieks, the Parliamentary Secretary for the Ministry of Justice, publicly compared Latvian residents of Russian origin to insects that are difficult to get rid of. These statements have not received any criticism either from the Latvian ruling elite or in mainstream media. This intolerant attitude towards part of the population opens the way to arrogant and aggressive behaviour against other nations and countries. I am sure, in these circumstances, the European Union must develop a centralised system of monitoring hate speech cases in the EU Member States in order, at least, to compensate for the absence of national discussion on such issues. If we are not going to eliminate the dark corners of European political life, the political monsters will multiply there, come out and destroy Europe.

name: Barbara SPINELLI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in announcing a census of the Roma, Minister Salvini said that 'the Italian roma, unfortunately, we must keep them', making it clear that Italians are unwelcome and non-Italians are at risk of expulsion, including Romanians, European citizens.  So he turned the census into an ethnic file of dark memory. It has already taken place in 2008 by another Minister of the League and the Italian Government should remember that the decision to collect data in a discriminatory manner was condemned by the Civil Court of Rome in 2012. The same happened with Paris, which was condemned by the Strasbourg Court in 2013. It should also remember that the processing of data revealing racial or ethnic origin is prohibited by Article 9 of the European Regulation on Personal Data. One question, Commissioner Jourová: the Italian Government repeats that the eviction of the camps is requested by the Union and the Commission. What condition do you ask, if you ask? Thank you for a precise answer.

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, among the many, let us say amusing, remarks that have been made against Mr Salvini's initiative, one really striking one is that of saying 'do it to seek votes'. In this way you recognize that the vast majority of citizens adhere to the concerns concretely expressed by Minister Salvini. There is a great deal of concern because you see, ladies and gentlemen, and I am addressing my colleagues of Sinti origin in particular, perhaps you do not know, not being Italian, that very often when and only in cases where some Roma or Sinti are caught by the police and the police to commit crimes, only in those cases, there is a habit of not giving their details to the police and carabinieri. So let us think of the rights of our fellow citizens, who have the right to bring crimes – and they are a minority in the minority – to be brought to justice, like all Italian citizens, and not to provide the so-called aliases, otherwise there will be discrimination against Italian citizens, including the Sinti – who are many – who do not delinquent. This is the rationale, beyond a few jokes by Minister Salvini, which can be criticized, the true rationale of this Government and this minister. If there were, if there were – but I do not think there will be – different things, then your indignation will have a foundation. But in this situation it is simple demagoguery and political propaganda. Shame on you, on the skin of the Sinti that this government will help when they deserve and where.... (Violent off-microphone exchange with Mr Syley) Viotti)

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: Thank you. Next, Mr Maullu has the floor. (Loud shouting in Italian without a microphone.) Rest please! (Continued loud shouting in Italian without a microphone.) Mr Borghezio, I ask you to stop! (Continued loud shouting in Italian without a microphone.) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, which I have just given Mr Maullu the floor for two minutes. He has the floor and no one else.

name: Stefano MAULLU
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that the debate in this House has some disconcerting, almost surreal traits, especially when we consider, a week ago, what happened, in the Council, with regard to Italy, an Italy abandoned on an epochal issue such as migration, an Italy that sees France at its borders file citizens: cars for cars, stopped, controlled and identified. , in defiance of any Schengen rule.
