So I believe that – to return to the subject that seems to me to be particularly interesting, especially for an Italy that has never been racist, but which tends to become intolerant, also because of a Europe that does not understand, that does not grasp any of the aspects that the Italian people have been suffering for too long now – I believe that talking about Roma and Sinti is useful and certainly in such a way that it is in a position to help children , which only 30% manage to attend schools, women, who in a patriarchal clan condition, are marginalized, unable to study, are cornered by a cultural condition that cannot be eradicated even because of communities that do not want to be helped. And it is impossible, in a civilised country, to still consider the camps sustainable. Well, I believe that what Salvini meant was that, on a subject such as this, the whole of Europe, as well as in the field of immigration, cannot leave Italy alone, nor let the Italian State sump to the burden of minorities in need of protection and help on its own.

name: Silvia COSTA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the new Minister of the Interior, Mr Salvini, has announced a real registration on an ethnic basis, prohibited by our Constitution but also by the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union. Why do I say that? Because, the fact that it is a discriminatory and punitive approach emerges when, precisely, he said that "the Italian Roma, unfortunately, you have to keep them at home", phrases that should not be part of the language of a representative of the government of a democratic country and known for its humanity. What is quite different, Mr Bizzotto, is the anonymous statistical and quantitative reconnaissance dossier produced by Istat a year ago with the National Anti-Racial Discrimination Office and the Association of Italian Municipalities, in collaboration with the National Roma Forum, aimed at monitoring and overcoming the presence of nomadic camps to follow European guidelines. There are around ten million citizens of Roma and Sinti origin in Europe. In Italy there are 180 thousand, 40 thousand of whom live, certainly, in housing difficulties, in formal slums, managed by local or informal administrations, a segregation that is suffered above all by half of them, minors, for repercussions on psychophysical health and schooling. We want to see progress towards overcoming the agreed camps and with a mutual pact between local communities and Roma, according to the national strategy, which takes up the European strategy of 2011, which has already allocated resources and will also provide for them in the next European Social Fund, but through processes, as Mrs Spinelli said earlier, which concern inclusion through education and health care. , employment and housing policy. There are positive but many negative experiences, especially the one that has taken place in recent months and weeks in Rome, in my city, where the junta led by the 5 Star Movement, allied at national level with Salvini, has proceeded, in recent weeks, to a brutal eviction of the most orderly camp of 420 people, with 90% of children educated , without giving alternatives, limiting themselves to perhaps promising money to rent a house, without any form of accompaniment and assistance, otherwise families will be broken up, without a shared plan, without a pact for rights and duties, abandoning de facto families, violating the dignity and rights that you, Commissioner Jourová, previously noted, with children and infants, without water and without light and refusing for months to confront their representation. That's how populists rule.

name: Bodil VALERO
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for We live in a time where fundamental international and common values are being challenged: the UN Declaration of Human Rights, the European Convention, the EU Treaty and the Charter of Fundamental Rights. Today, our common values are increasingly having to stand back for egoism, nationalism and populism. And it is a populism that has been there for a long time, which has been in the shadows, and which we have not taken seriously enough, but which in Europe in recent years has exploded in scope and found its way into governments and parliaments. But if the Union is no longer based on common values and the rule of law, what is the cohesive glue? If we allow member states' restrictions on human and minority rights to pass without anyone reacting and putting an end, our violations of international and own rules will normalise and become the new norm, and then we might as well scrap Article 2 of the Treaty. And what do we have left? And it was with great sadness that I took note of the Italian Interior Minister's statement about the Roma the other day. Citizenship does not distinguish between majority group and minority, we all have the same rights and obligations. Yet roma are particularly special is treated everywhere.  For example, Swedish police in a municipality kept a register of Roma for law enforcement purposes until it was discovered that the register registered all Roma – children, adults and old – solely on the basis that they were Roma, completely in violation of our regulations. And Salvini, unfortunately, is not the only politician either. In the Swedish Parliament today we have a deputy speaker from a right-wing party who believes that Jews and Sami people from Sweden are not Swedes. If those of us who believe in people's equal value, our common values, stand back and allow the populists to take over the democratic conversation, it looks very dark for Europe.

name: Jacques COLOMBIER
text: Madam President, I am appalled by the violence of the words of our colleagues on the left. Who are they today to give us moral lessons, when they participated in the installation of an immigration for many illegal and the peoples of Europe today refuse. The ballot boxes are proof of that. First of all, I want to assure our friend Matteo Salvini of all our support and our full solidarity. It is not the words, let alone the courageous action of the Italian Minister of the Interior, that must be called into question, certainly not in this Chamber which is a real shackle for freedom of expression and which is becoming more and more frightened as the Peoples of Europe turn their backs on the ideological diktats of Brussels, especially, of course, , on immigration. What is at issue is the policy of the globalists who are rampant here in Strasbourg or Brussels and who want to make Roma and others peoples of reference, to the detriment of the rights of the entrenched peoples of Europe. You may muzzle freedom of expression, but the right of peoples is already rightfully in your face. Matteo Salvini and the elections in Italy are proof of this. Our colleagues on the left are attacking today with incantations which, as we know, no longer convince anyone, a defender of Italian national sovereignty. I will end with the words of Victor Hugo, who in 1850 told his opponents in the rostrum of the Chamber of Deputies: "You are the nothingness waiting for chaos". Matteo Salvini, with the strength of the ballot box and the Italian people, refuses and fights chaos in his country.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: As far as I know, Victor Hugo has always spoken respectfully towards all people.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am truly appalled. The tone that this debate is taking seems to me clearly to be a part of a political, bad tone, aroused by the left, which exploits very delicate issues and the massive presence of speeches by Italians underlines that here we are exploiting the European Parliament for a national debate and this, I think, is a very bad thing, in addition to the fact that the issues that are being exploited are being exploited. , they have rightly been mentioned by both the Commission and the Council and which should, as it were, be taken for granted, and the values that have been recovered and conquered in Europe at the cost of blood, tears and sacrifices. We have pages that have been horrific and we find this a truly terrible exploitation, not least because when the People's Party asked the parties to propose a debate on these issues in April 2018, the Socialists opposed it! In 2012 the Italian Socialists stood here and said the same things: but do you not have the doubt that they do not have the doubts that they want to keep the problems instead of solving them? Why did Mr Maullu mention the figures! But we may not solve – with all the money we make to get children to school, to give their women the same opportunities as other women and men – we may not see that 40 000 people are still living in those conditions, with children who cannot go to school or who we find at the exit of the supermarket on school hours. , to take the carts and beg? Ladies and gentlemen on the left, you should be a little ashamed of these things, because you, with all your cooperatives and associations that live from these funds, do not want to solve the problem: you perpetuate and exploit it. It's a great shame!  Mrs Kyenge will also speak, which is proof that we are not racists: she was not born in Italy, she was a minister and now she sits here representing Italy. Say sometimes thanks to the country that welcomed you and made you minister! (Violent off-microphone exchange with Mr S. Kyenge, Post and Viotti) (The President takes the floor from the speaker)

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: I have a ... (Loud shouting in Italian without a microphone.) Mrs Gardini, sit down now! I have a point of order from Mrs Kyenge. But please, on a point of order.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would ask that Mr Gardini's statement be carefully considered, because you cannot afford to come here and say that we can stand you. I am a European citizen, elected by the Italian citizens! I would ask that your words be examined.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: Thank you, Mrs Kyenge. I will also pass on your request.

name: Elly SCHLEIN
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in just one month, Minister Salvini has shown the true nature of the League, immediately giving a clear imprint to the new government: cowardly and deeply discriminatory. Instead of solving problems, it uses the institutional role to continue to make propaganda, choosing a different enemy every day, echoing in an increasingly blurred way the darkest period in our common history: it threatens clashes, promises exclusions, announces retaliation. Obviously, outside all legal frameworks, as in the case of the shooting of the Roma census, in clear violation of the Constitution, the principle of equality, the European Charter of Human Rights and privacy legislation. He prefers to call it "registry to expel irregulars" but while I quote, he says "the Italian Roma you have to keep them at home", except then at the first protests – and there have been many of them – to take it all back and justify themselves with the cloying rhetoric of the good father of the family, saying that the file serves only to protect children. But what about the children you are letting die at sea, closing ports and preventing relief, with the complicity of other European governments? The Libyan Coast Guard will take care of it, you say; we saw how. It is very easy to convey people's fears and insecurities to the weakest, the latest arrivals. But why do you never point the finger up, for example to those multinationals that evade tax every year by a thousand billion, stealing fundamental resources from the citizens? And he is not only taking issue with the Roma or migrants but also with the LGBT community, lately also with Saviano, who has been under escort for years for mafia threats, threatening to take away his escort for his criticism. Not only in Italy, but in Hungary, Poland and many EU countries, the fundamental rights that we have put at the foundation of the Eu ropean Union are at risk: the European institutions must react before it is too late. Can we not allow groups of people to be discriminated against, or has history taught us nothing? The safest society, ladies and gentlemen, is the one that manages to be more inclusive and I am sorry that there is no colleague of the 5 Stars in this debate because now you too are responsible who govern with them.

name: Christelle LETARD-LECHEVALIER
text: Madam President, the truth about this debate is that you are not in control of your frustration at the return of nations to the forefront of European politics. The European Union is today seeking to teach the lesson to Matteo Salvini, elected by the Italians and sovereign in his country. She has also made this practice her main activity, a sign of her inability to solve the challenges of time.  If I want to go back to the substance of the debate, you are brandishing the defence of minorities not out of humanism, but to attack the leaders elected by the Italian people, because they do not fit into the mould of your ideology.  Mr Salvini chose to expel the Sinis and Roma and thus control the migratory flows. This is a direct consequence of the failure of your migration policies and the failure of Schengen, because your European Union is on the verge of becoming the champion of precariousness and insecurity, but understand that people do not want it.  I hear you talking about racism and fascism. No! Matteo Salvini simply loves his people and protects them. Under the guise of free movement of people, you have created the conditions of chaos. This model of society is a far cry from the model forged by centuries of European culture in terms of land use, architecture and quality of life.  Therefore, thank you for showing a little humility in view of your disastrous record. Trust the Italians and let Matteo Salvini do it on Italian domestic politics.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, what is happening is truly shameful. I ask for the respect of this House. I repeat once again: if today in Italy I am under a protection programme, with the escort every day, it is because someone uses a language of exploitation of the different to try to create a conflict, because today violence is at unacceptable levels. It is precisely on this point that the statements made by Minister Salvini on the situation of the Roma do not even deserve to be repeated in this House: they have evoked atrocious memories, they have reopened black pages of our past that we thought had been archived by decades of struggle for a democratic and inclusive society. Salvini followed the communication strategy that is proper to this new government, based on demagoguery, populism, simplification and has fomented social and ethnic hatred, causing rifts in society. Yes, because in his chilling speech, Matteo Salvini went beyond the racial census, moreover prohibited by our Constitution; it has also gone beyond expulsion, even these illegal if carried out on an ethnic basis: Minister Salvini has purposely fuelled a vicious circle in which ignorance and prejudice increase each other. Xenophobic discrimination campaigns against Roma and all ethnic minorities not only undermine fundamental rights but also produce marginalisation and ghettoisation. This senseless chase must stop; it voluntarily aims to eliminate every effort we have made. New generations born and raised in Italy are thus marginalized. This is certainly not a new attitude on the part of the League. I remember the ethnicisation of crimes, Afrophobia, where one of its exponents even evokes the supremacy of race. Dear Minister, in one of your many election spots you have sworn to apply the Italian Constitution, respecting the teaching contained in the Gospel. At this point I have the question of whether you have never read either. Well, all I have to do is wish you a good reading for the summer break.

name: Kati PIRI
text: Mr President, in the week in which David Pap was murdered in Ukraine because of his Roma origins and Salvini, the Italian Interior Minister, continued to consider carrying out his Roma census, I visited the Józsefváros district in Budapest. This central district is popularly called the Roma ghetto. Even though the problems experienced by Roma families are well known, I was again affected by the harrowing circumstances: dilapidated houses, high homelessness among all age groups and a lack of perspective for the people who live there. Instead of ensuring that the Roma have a dignified life in this district, the municipality has done everything in recent years to make the district up-and-coming. In reality, this means a law that now makes it illegal to beg on the streets, and large-scale new construction in places where many Roma families live, which are forced to move. This policy is exemplary for the exclusion of Roma in European societies.  Another sadder example of this structural exclusion is Salvini's outrageous statements. Let me be very clear about this: deportation on the basis of ethnic criteria is not only not allowed in the EU, it is an outrageous proposal that evokes associations with one of the darkest periods of European history. It's 2018! The fact that we still have to talk about serious discrimination and hate crimes against Roma today is sad.  Whether we are talking about Roma in Józsefváros in Budapest or in the Italian cities, exclusion and discrimination against the Roma must be combated in all Member States. For everything we stand for as an EU. It is high time that fundamental rights also applied to the largest minority in Europe, the 10 million Roma and Sinti, which are part of our societies.

name: Ana GOMES
text: – Madam President, since he came to power, Salvini has not stopped lying and promoting a perverse, racist and anti-European Union agenda in his country and not only, as seen in the alliance he has made with German Minister Seehofer, Prime Minister Kurz and his visegrad allies against migrants and refugees. Racial censuses and deportations towards an ethnic minority are more than illegal, they are a crime. Salvini fosters his agenda, his political narrative based on fear and xenophobia, which foster hatred and racial discrimination. It began with the persecution of refugees and immigrants, so its target was the Roma and Sinti minorities.  Who's coming next? What is italy's disgraced Interior Minister preparing? Salvini's supporters, inside and outside this Parliament, shame Europe. They dehumanize vulnerable people, they want to make scapegoats and persecute the poorest and socially disadvantaged minorities, for the collective responsibilities of all of us.  We certainly can and must do more for the full social integration of roma and sinti, who are as European as all of us – they are indeed the most representative minority in Europe. Soraya Post has warned here of the pogroms that are already underway in this Europe, in Ukraine. It is time to remember the tragic lessons of European history. The last time laws against the Roma were enacted was in Mussolini's time in 1938.  We can't regress civilizationally. Salvini must be called to justice, in Italy or within the European framework, for incitement to hatred and racial discrimination, for violation of European law and international law. Salvini was elected, but dishonors Italy. It doesn't protect her, it puts her in danger, puts the whole of Europe in danger. Fascist Salvini has to stop.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, there are two aspects that emerge from this affair. The first, to those who know Italian history, the idea of censusing and carding people on ethnic bases will not be new: just take an 80-year step back to racial laws. The second, which goes hand in hand with the first, highlights the dangerous ridge of certain violent statements and words, which describe a progressive shift in language and the gradual landslide of conduct from political action towards ruinous drifts. What Mr Gardini, for example, who is no longer here, pretends not to understand and does not want to understand, and which perhaps embarrasses the governing allies of the 5 Star Movement, who are not here today in this House. However, having rightly not underestimated and condemned the words of the Italian Minister of the Interior, it is right that politics should ask itself the question of the reasons that have led us so far, to these dark and confused times: the truth is that European policy has fallen into a vacuum where it has lost the ability to understand society, giving way to public mistrust and the conversion of politics into protest and moral devastation. I think that the best response to this drift is not only the redemocratisation of the institutions, but it is becoming increasingly essential to re-legitimize the European Union, by regaining the confidence of the citizens, which can only go from the recognition of the rights denied in recent years.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: We have had a rather lively discussion here in the European Parliament, Commissioner. I think, however, that it has also become clear that a majority of this Parliament also stands by the rule of law, which we have enshrined in the Treaties of the European Union.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: Member of the European Commission. – Madam President, I will speak in my own language, because this is an emotional point and the emotion in me speaks my native language.  In my introductory speech, I described the legislative framework and the very clear condemnation of racist and xenophobic statements and attacks, both in the real world and in the online space, nota bene particularly dangerous attacks when they come from the mouths of people who influence public opinion and the situation in society. And I deliberately spoke in general, I did not use the word Italy or Salvini at all, because I did not want to contribute to the Italian national debate. I wanted to talk about the fact that, yes, we are after values in Europe and we need to speak increasingly loudly to appeal to everyone that racism and xenophobia must not be tolerated.  I will admit that when I first heard the statement about the Roma census, i.e. the census on the principle of race, it shook me personally and I started to find out how these things happened, what can be expected next, how the next development will take place. Of course, I must also take into account and respond to a number of messages and emails I receive from people who are very concerned in Italy, and it is not only the Roma who may be affected by such statements. I have been investigating the situation, I have had a discussion with a contact person who is dealing with the strategy of Roma integration in Italy, I have had a discussion about this with a number of experts, and so far I have a reflection from practice that it was a declaration that is not going to be implemented, which is not such a strong reason for some completely complete calming, but we can see that so far it has only stayed with words. because words are as dangerous and can be as dangerous as actions.  We want good cooperation with the Italian Government, it is a government that has emerged from free elections. I think that good cooperation and dialogue and progress on Roma integration can help the Roma themselves. That it won't help them if we get into conflicts, unnecessary controversy. I'm not a follower of barking over Twitter and sending some messages and acronyms. We want a good debate with the Italian Government, we want the situation of the Roma to improve, that the principle of equality before the law and non-discrimination are fully respected. This is what we want in all countries where we have Roma citizens. 90% of Roma live in 11 countries of the European Union and I work very closely with all these countries personally. Each country has different problems, different warning signs in the context of Roma integration, and we need to apply a very individual approach. We had a good debate with Minister Di Maio at the EPSCO Council on improving conditions for women, on a better reconciliation of private and working life. I had a good feeling about the debate, so I repeat, we want dialogue with the Italian Government in order to improve the situation of the Roma.  I have to say that I deal a lot, a lot of me lies at the heart of dealing with the issue of violence online, in the online space. We have a so-called code of decency, Code of Conduct, with big internet companies. I have a very good overview of who is at that time on the list of those who are objects and victims of attacks. I must say that in some countries the Roma are gradually replacing the first place where there were refugees until recently. These are all very warning signs. We deal with it and, as I said, we work with those countries individually. Anyway, the fact that hateful content within 24 hours where it is notified, where it is detected, removed from the Internet, that I think is a great progress. And I will always fight against critical remarks to my address or to the Commission or anyone who promotes this code of decency, this Code of Conduct, because the criticism says that we are actually introducing censorship and that we are opposed to the right to free expression. I will never defend the free expression of people who send Roma and Jews into the gas, people who have absolutely disgusting comments when looking at pictures of a Czech girl who was the victim of an incendiary bomb attack. I will never protect such people and their right to free expression. And it's not about me, it's about the criminal law in every single country.  In every European country, we have a ban on incitement to violence and hatred on a racial basis in criminal law. And we want law enforcement agencies to work with IT firms to detect and effectively prosecute perpetrators and punish them. And not what we have seen recently, that the perpetrator of such an attack on Roma was fined EUR 5. I think that's totally unacceptable. It must not be cheap to attack people, whether they are Roma, whether they are other citizens of the European Union. I have to say that the police and law enforcement are facing a new situation because they are telling us, "A few years ago we were dealing with extremist organized groups." Now online violence is actually done by individuals, and according to some surveys, we find that it's not people without education, they're people educated, they're often people with college degrees, and it's very warning, actually, the wave of violence, which now gets space in the online space.  We are now updating the strategy for Roma integration, and I must say that we will continue to promote an integrated approach and a better use of European funds. It's been said here, too. An integrated approach must consist of clearly effective ways to improve housing, work, education and health conditions. And as I said on the basis of the pillar: equality before the law and non-discrimination. Ladies and gentlemen, in conclusion, I will return to the power of words. I recently studied documents relating to the Wannsee conference , which was a continuation of the practice of Nuremberg laws, which also involved the census of people of racial origin. I do not like historical parallels, but I have to say that this is where it is offered to remind ourselves that we have already had this in Europe, that we are playing with fire if we let these things run through our lives. Wherever it is in Europe, it must not happen that we relativise fundamental values, that we give way to hatred. I think it's an appeal to all of us. Please stop this in time.

name: Karoline EDTSTADLER
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, I followed this emotional debate attentively. To be honest, at first I was a bit surprised, but in the end, I am very thankful for this debate because it is obviously necessary to remind Member States of their duty to remain sensitive, to reflect history, to be careful with words and to implement both the framework established in 2011 and effective measures to ensure equality.  Whichever government a Member State of the European Union is ruled by, it is indispensable to guarantee equal rights, equal chances and the right to education to all citizens, irrespective of their origin, and to do everything to preclude any form of discrimination. This is not only the duty of the Member States of the European Union, but also of the Member States of the Council of Europe. The Council of Europe’s European Court of Human Rights is only a few metres away from here.  Regarding Ms Gomes’s comment, I know that there are many states with a very long tradition of protecting minorities and that is also the case in Austria. I myself am in regular contact with different minority groups and we do everything we can to protect them. But let me end on a positive note by once again stressing the fruitful cooperation between the three institutions in defending the rights of Europe’s Roma. Parliament has worked particularly hard to keep this topic on the agenda. I also commend the Council’s contribution and commitment. As mentioned, we have already called on the Commission to propose a post—2020 strategy on Roma integration. Keenly aware of the harmful effects of anti-gypsyism, the Council has also called on all Member States ‘to implement and enforce legal safeguards against discrimination, racism, xenophobia, hate crime and hate speech’. Fundamental rights and decent life chances belong to Roma and non-Roma alike. Let us show that this is so. Let us stay the course, stamp out discrimination and make social justice a reality.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. – Italy's interior minister continues with the xenophobic escalation that so "good" electoral return is providing to him. He has now set an end to another minority after immigrants. This time it is Roma citizens, who were warned that they are preparing a census allowing their expulsion from Italy. This is a clearly unconstitutional measure. The reality is that the idea, like the proposal to expel 500,000 immigrants he launches on a recurring basis, is not an improvised invention; already contained in the government agreement with the 5-Star Movement. It's embarrassing. We would like to denounce here the warmth and attune of the European Commission's response on the subject. There's barely a few lay warnings coming in. Much greater force requires the response to this unbearable nationalist, populist and xenophobic spiral that has seized the EU reaching its own founding core: Italy. We must denounce salvini's xenophobic and racist words with all our might and publicly unmask the clearly fascistist ideology to which they represent and we call for this EP to louden its voice in defence of the values on which our Union is based and which are currently challenged.

name: Francisco ASSIS
text: in writing. – Like other European countries, Italy has recently seen populist currents enter its government seeking to direct the discouragement and frustration of some layers of society against minorities, especially against immigrant groups, exploiting superficial feelings and territorial or identity drive.  The roma census project living in the country, enunciated by the new Interior Minister Matteo Salvini, is one of the most serious episodes of this dangerous populist vertigo, summoning terrible memories and touching deep wounds. Such a project would constitute an exercise of ethnic signage totally contrary to the most basic principles of human decency and dignity, as well as to the values of the European Union, in addition to being unconstitutional in the light of the fundamental Italian Law.  Ethnic stigmatisation cannot take place in the European Union, which has been built against such practices and on top of the rubble that has resulted from them. We cannot tolerate ethnic prejudice becoming a state policy. Such instincts must be firmly denounced and fought by the European institutions at the time they emerge, before they can spread and call into question the safety of the persons concerned and, ultimately, the European project itself.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. The indignation of the European institutions over the statements of the Italian Minister of the Interior Matteo Salvini cannot mask the abysmal record of their strategy in favour of minorities. However, all the Member States, particularly the Eastern European States, where Roma minorities are numerically important, have made considerable integration efforts.  This is the case, for example, in higher education in Romania, where there are privileged paths for students from these populations, in addition to the many legal and constitutional protections. The lack of concrete results must also be taken into account of the way of life adopted by some members of the Roma community.  Thus, schools subject to so-called school segregation are in fact obeying the wishes of the parents of pupils who, in the States concerned, often prefer to withdraw their children from the schools attended by a large number of children from the Roma community.  The Commission cannot constantly point the finger at the people of Europe and ignore the real difficulties posed by the integration of these minorities. Similarly, free movement, the fruit of the Schengen area, only postpones this problem without providing solutions.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: The next item on the agenda is the joint debate on the report by Kinga Goel on behalf of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on a European Travel Information and Authorisation System (ETIAS) and on the amendment of Regulations (EU) No 515/2014, (EU) 2016/399, (EU) 2016/794 and (EU) 2016/1624 (COM(2016)0731 - C8-0466/2016 - 2016/0357A (COD)) (A8-0322/2017 and – the report by Kinga Goel, on behalf of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU) 2016/794 for the purpose of establishing a European Travel Information and Authorisation System (ETIAS) (N8-0050/2017 - C8-0306/2017 - 2017 - 2016/0357B (COD)) (A8-0323/2017).

name: Kinga GÁL
text: Artist. - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support Every year, 30 million passengers from 59 visa-free countries arrive in the European Union and are not provided with any information by the authorities before they arrive. Tourists as well as those arriving for business purposes are welcome in Europe. However, those arriving for the purpose of committing acts of terrorism or other offences must be identified long before they enter. This is made possible by the new European Travel Information and Authorisation System.  At the moment, we do not have prior information on visa-free visitors to the Schengen external border. This lack of information is to be remedied by ETIAS, as it is currently up to border guards at the external borders of the Schengen area to take this decision, without prior evaluation. It is clear that there is not the right time at the external borders to carry out appropriate checks and cross-checks. So we needed a system that would allow for a more efficient and faster risk analysis. This will also allow for the avoidance of lengthy waiting times at the external borders.  Securing our borders and protecting our citizens is our top priority. ETIAS eliminates a lack of information by allowing us to cross-check visa-free applicants' data with our other systems. This automated system identifies security, illegal, migration and epidemiological risks for visitors who enter the Schengen area visa-free. At the same time, it is in line with human rights and data protection aspects and does not place too much burden on third-country nationals who are exempt from visas for those trying to get into the Union. It is a certainty for these travellers that, if they have an ETIAS licence, they will be able to cross the EU border without problems. This will be a simple, fast, cheap and effective tool that will in no way qualify as a visa.  By creating the simplest possible procedure, our aim was to keep Europe open to those who come with tourist and business intentions, but also to make it safer. There were three aspects to the negotiations, and I did not want to create a more complicated procedure than for visa applicants, because that would take away the very essence of the visa waiver. I have tried to maintain coherence between ETIAS, the Schengen Information System and the EES. I didn't want to overload the mechanism, make it useless.  I think they have all been achieved in the negotiations. The mandate from Parliament has been greatly enforced, and I can say with a calm heart that the functioning of the ETIAS will always take place in full respect of fundamental rights and the protection of personal data.  For this reason, I would like to thank the Commission and the Commission, but above all my shadow rapporteur colleagues, Mrs Guillaume, Mrs Stevens, Mr Deprez, Mrs Vergiat, for their constructive approach to the dossier and for their cooperation in a good atmosphere.  I would also like to thank the political advisers, Katrin Huber, from the LIBE Secretariat, as well as the assistants for their lengthy, persistent and difficult work. In a year and a half, four political trilogy and 26 technical consultations resulted in this interim agreement first under the Oct, then the final agreement under the Bulgarian Presidency, and finally we were able to close the dossier effectively. I think ETIAS is a school example of good co-legislation.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to tell you that, personally, I am very happy that we have reached this point after a lot of work together. We are now debating, and tomorrow you will vote to adopt, the European Travel Information and Authorisation System (ETIAS), a milestone in our common work.  Together with you and the Council, we jointly agreed to work together to prioritise the legislative work of initiatives where European citizens are clearly expecting us to deliver concrete results. For this, I would like to express my thanks to our rapporteur, Ms Gál, the shadow rapporteurs, and all those involved, for their hard work on this file.  Migration and security are at the very top of our citizens’ concerns, as we see in survey after survey. One of the challenges we identified was to close our information gap on visa-free travellers, while in parallel facilitating legitimate travel. ETIAS was therefore an immediate priority. Today we deliver on this priority.  Let me recall and highlight a few aspects about ETIAS and its concrete benefits. First, it will strengthen internal security and the quality of Schengen border management. Today, border guards have limited time and information when making their assessment on entry. They have no prior information on visa-exempt travellers, especially at land borders. With ETIAS they will benefit from an additional and broader security and migration risk assessment than at the border crossing point, and before the traveller arrives at the Schengen borders. With this system in place we should also see a decrease in the number of refusals of entry at the borders.  In addition to the system contributing to the reduction of migratory risks, persons that pose a security risk will be identified and denied travel authorisation before they arrive. Anyone who is denied authorisation will not waste time and money travelling to Schengen border crossing points. This will also reduce the cost of return for carriers, which will have to repatriate fewer passengers from air, sea and land borders.  Second, while enhancing border management and internal security, ETIAS will at the same time also facilitate travel for visa-exempt third country nationals. Applying for a travel application will be quick, simple and cheap and will not require more than a travel document, credit card and access to the internet. The vast majority of applicants will receive a positive reply within minutes. If additional information or documentation were to be needed, or even the need to have an interview, different possibilities will be offered, taking into account the situation of the traveller. Third, and this is a crucial point, the system will also help to safeguard our visa liberalisation policy, something which is, of course, a key component of the European Union’s external policy. Several visa liberalisation dialogues are progressing with EU neighbours. Visa liberalisation is also an important tool to promote reforms in partner countries and contribute to overall stability and good cooperation with third countries.  ETIAS is, of course, not a visa, but it will compensate in a relatively light way for the loss of information on travellers who were previously visa-required and hence present in the Visa Information System (VIS). With our Visa Information System, the proposal we made last May will ensure also that ETIAS and the VIS work smoothly together and there is no information gap leading to migratory or security risks, all in full respect of fundamental rights.  Please let me now touch upon some of the data protection aspects of the agreement – what data is collected, its retention and how it is protected. The robustness of the risk assessments to be performed by the system is, of course, related to the data collected and to the checks performed against other systems. The outcome on this point is very balanced. It will allow ETIAS to achieve its objectives and functions efficiently while at the same time minimising the data collected. The system will not require the collection of additional information other than what is strictly necessary. I appreciate Parliament’s contribution to striking a constructive agreement with the Council on this point.  As regards now data retention, the agreement is fully in line with the European Parliament’s proposal on extending the retention period only if the applicant freely and explicitly consents. In terms of data protection, the proposal was built to be fully compatible with our new data protection framework. As you know, the extensive discussions reflect a delineation between the General Data Protection Regulation and the Police Directive without affecting their scope of application. Data is protected against risk of abuse. Access is restricted to specific persons within designated competent authorities. Transfer of data to third parties is prohibited, except for exceptional cases where the entry/exit system would not already contain necessary data.  Travellers have the right to access, rectification and deletion of their personal data stored in ETIAS. Supervision is provided by the European Data Protection Supervisor and independent national supervisory authorities. The system will be built in accordance with the principles of data protection by design and by default. Moreover, the Fundamental Rights Guidance Board will, at the suggestion of you, the European Parliament, reinforce and advise the ETIAS screening board by appraising and issuing opinions on the impact on fundamental rights and of implementing ETIAS screening rules.  Today, we are ready to pursue our joint commitment to the full and continue to deliver results for the benefit of our citizens. We should rapidly start to develop ETIAS so that it is up and running in 2021. I am looking forward to the debate today, and thank you for your continued commitment to truly European initiatives which enhance our external border management, ensuring more safety for our citizens.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Budgets. Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to first congratulate Mr Kinga Gul on the remarkable work we have had to do with her. The proposal we are discussing today is important because it potentially affects 1.4 billion citizens from some 60 countries, who are exempt from the visa requirement, and it actually affects 30 to 40 million people every year who enter the European Union. The proposed system is simple: any third country national, exempt from the visa requirement, will have to have prior authorisation tomorrow before going to the EU borders. The first question is: Is such a measure necessary? In our opinion, yes. Of the 30 to 40 million people who are willing to join the EU each year, some may pose a real risk to internal security, a migration risk or a risk to public health through the spread of epidemics. ETIAS is therefore a plus for internal security, for border control, because it allows us to identify potential risks in time. It's also a plus for the travelers themselves. Do we know that there are currently almost 300,000 people who are turned back at the borders of the Union every year, even though they have already borne the cost of their journey? ETIAS will significantly reduce this number. The second question is: is this measure bureaucratically unbearable? Obviously not. Travellers will simply apply online by filling out a standard form and 95% of applicants will receive a positive response within minutes. The third question is: Is this measure excessively costly for travellers? This can be discussed, but 7 euros per person for an authorization that will be valid for 3 years does not seem excessive. For comparison, the price of a visa is 60 euros. And finally - and the Commissioner has insisted on this point - this measure respects fundamental rights. Personal data is kept only for the duration of the authorization. No sensitive issues are allowed. An ethics committee is set up to verify that risk indicators are necessary and proportionate and a right of appeal against a refusal decision is established. For all these reasons, my group will definitely vote in favour of the ETIAS project.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: On behalf of the Group of S and D- Madam President, I greet Kinga Gul and the rapporteurs, but above all I want to greet our assistants, who have participated in countless technical meetings, and to whom we really owe all due respect. Indeed, there have been intense negotiations on this issue, which has been identified as a priority by the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs and the Council, which has agreed to create this travel authorization for visa-exempt third-country nationals, following the model of the ESTA in the United States. These nationals will need to apply for ETIAS authorization online by giving information about themselves—their travel. I make a little break on the experience, I hope that the online scams to obtain ETIAS will be less numerous than for obtaining the ESTA. I close the parenthesis of lived. This system will be supposed to verify, before travellers arrive, whether or not they pose a risk to public safety, public health or irregular immigration. Today, with their only identity documents, these risks are assessed in a time frame that is sometimes constrained at the border. The Commission has therefore imagined this new system as a pre-authorization, an upstream assessment, in a way.  Put it this way, once we recognize the need for external border controls, which I do, everything looks fluid, but I still have some reservations about this system. Some may have resulted in the addition of safeguards, as is the case in some areas, others are part of the form of the European security negotiations.  Basically, like any European information system, my political group has been working with concern about these objectives, but above all about its impact on the rights of applicants and the protection of their data. Thus, through our initiative, an evaluation and referral body, an guidance board, has been added to the system, which is made up of independent experts to verify that it does not result in violations of the fundamental rights of travellers. We have also ensured that there is no systematic retention of traveller data, which is consistent with the Court of Justice's ruling on the EU-Canada PNR agreement. This tool will take the form of a database managed by the EU and its Member States. Transport companies and border guards will need to check that each passenger has an ETIAS before letting them leave or enter Europe.  This system will be colossal to implement. When we see the difficulties of a number of Member States in implementing the European NNP on time, we can cast some doubts about the operational implementation date of ETIAS.  My biggest regret about this text is the desire of the Member States to broaden the objectives of the system. ETIAS was designed as a simple travel authorization, but the Council proposed, for example, to make it a lie detector. (The President interrupts the speaker) He wanted each traveller to declare the address of their first stay and that at the border, the border guards could ask for the address where the person would go and check the system to see if it complied with what had been reported at the first online application. Fortunately, Parliament has managed to avoid this infernal machine. I conclude by stressing that these European negotiations should really focus on strategic thinking and designs to create texts that are applicable and respectful of people.

name: Helga STEVENS
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Mr President, I am pleased that the Ethias dossier will be voted on tomorrow, after months of hard work on it. It was identified in a study as an important missing link in European border control, together with the entry-exit system.  This system will hopefully screen in advance from 2021 to screen foreigners who do not need a visa to come to Europe. An automatic survey of European and international databases should give the security services a complete picture. For example, a person who is signalled through the Schengen Information System will no longer be able to travel undetected to the Schengen countries.  But the system is more than just consulting databases. It also tries to predict risks with smart algorithms and statistics. Good news for the taxpayer: the system is self-sufficient, as applicants pay EUR 7 for their electronic request. In most cases, the applicants will be given a decision within 10 minutes. After all, the system is fully automatic and only in case of possible identity confusion or a hit is the application checked manually. An admission is valid for three years.  The system should support border guards who have to make the decision on the ground at the border whether or not to admit someone. Via Ethias they can see if an admission has been issued and whether an additional check is needed.  The N-VA is very pleased that police departments and immigration authorities will also be able to consult the system within their mandate. In this way, we are closing an important gap in the surveillance of our external borders. Europe is getting a little safer again.

name: Romeo FRANZ
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which It is not only since the European Council last weekend that the alleged protection of the EU's external borders has been used for symbolic politics and smear comedies. At ETIAS, we are dealing with a symbolic policy that is at the same time dangerous, expensive and ineffective. ETIAS introduces a visa through the back door. And the applicants have to provide even more data than others for a visa application! ETIAS is expensive: even the Commission estimates development costs of EUR 212 million and an annual cost of EUR 80 million. The money is missing from proper policing and border guards. ETIAS is dangerous: in many cases, the decision as to whether someone poses a risk is left to an algorithm that works completely unclear and is not specified. This is automatic discrimination and runs counter to our report on big data and fundamental rights, which this House adopted by a large majority a year ago. Finally, ETIAS is ineffective. Comparison with databases such as the Schengen Information System is already taking place on entry. The added value of ETIAS is the additional data, which will now also be evaluated. But these come from the travellers themselves, who can happily tell the untruth. We Greens will not support such an expensive, ineffective, dangerous symbolic policy. That is why we reject ETIAS.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Madam President, ETIAS is one of the last parts of the 'Borders' package. He will complete the construction of fortress Europe, erect electronic walls in addition to the physical walls and barbed wire already put in place. Thanks to the entry and exit system, any third-country national entering the European Union will now be registered, recorded and tracked. For the time being, only those who did not need a visa were exempted from it. ETIAS corrects this by creating for them what I call a low cost visa, a visa that does not say its name, a paid travel authorization, modelled on what exists in the United States and Australia. The data provided are even more numerous or even more intrusive than for a visa, which is more intrusive in data protection, more dangerous for the risks of profiling, not to mention police cooperation with unsafe third countries. And for this, we invented a new institutional procedure consisting of giving our employees a political mandate to complete the technical negotiation for almost 6 months after the political agreement. All this would have deserved better. Definitely, these smart borders are not. The European Union continues to renounce itself, giving pledges to the extreme right at the expense of rights and freedoms, principles of necessity and proportionality, without the effectiveness of security being proven, but at an exorbitant cost that some military-security lobbies will benefit from, here and elsewhere. I am sorry, Commissioner, and for us it is not and still no.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, the Schengen area is open to all winds. The European Union is finally becoming aware of the dangers this poses, particularly in terms of security. That is why it wants to set up this ETIAS system, which will allow the obtaining of personal information on nationals of 62 states, including Saudi Arabia, which is exempt from visa to enter the Schengen area. This will affect nearly 40 million people entering the Schengen area each year. I obviously agree with this basic precautionary measure, but I am surprised that it took until 2018 to implement it. On the other hand, and above all, my approval of ETIAS does not mean that I succumb to the supposed charm of the Schengen area. ETIAS is, in my opinion, just a bad thing. The real solution to ensure the security of European states is to re-establish controls at national borders.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Madam President, the dangerous decisions of the last summit are a monument to reactivity, reinforcing the existing network of repressive mechanisms of the European Union which this report extends, both at the borders and in the hinterland of each Member State. We have so far had the freedom - so-called - of Schengen, with the envelope with all modern technological methods, fingerprints, biometric data and so on and now with ETIAS. The visa, which had been abolished for third-country travellers, comes back in the form of a permit, which even the border guard can still reject.  Until proven otherwise, people are essentially wrapped in a piece of paper, in the name of fighting terrorism, so-called illegal immigration, the deliberately hazy and arbitrary concept of radicalisation. After all, the percentages of refugees, persecuted people, who are entitled to political asylum and international protection are also being annihilated. So here and now, to abolish the terrorists and the whole of the Eu-European unpopular network of repression and repression that the SYRIZA-ANEL government in Greece is strictly adhered to.

name: Agustín DÍAZ DE MERA GARCÍA CONSUEGRA
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, the EIAS system will subject each applicant to a detailed security check to determine whether he or she is authorised to enter any country in the Schengen area. The EIAS, in addition to being used for tourism and business purposes, will also allow people to visit Schengen countries for medical or transit reasons. In addition, it will be mandatory for all countries that are exempt from the Schengen visa. Countries such as the United States or Canada have very similar systems, which have proved very useful. I'm talking about eTA or ESTA. The ultimate purpose of the EIAS is safety. The terrorism that has attacked us in recent years forces us to take measures to help identify people who may pose a risk before their arrival at union borders. This identification will be made possible by the comparison between the data collected in the EIAS and the data stored in the Europol databases. In the same sense, Europol may consult EIAS databases for use as a threat detection tool and other operations. This system, ladies and gentlemen, is going to be part of the interoperability package. The EIAS, together with the SIS, the VIS, Eurodac, the input and output system, ECRIS, Europol and Interpol. The EIAS is a fundamental part of the European search portal. This will put an end to information gaps and quickly ensure full identification of the so-called 'threat subject'. Although, on the other hand, Commissioner, Rapporteur Kinga Gál, the EIAS itself is a basic instrument for continuing improvements in border information and control systems, and also for improving its security.

name: Tanja FAJON
text: – Dear Presiding Commissioner! We have another legislative package before us aimed at security and strengthening the Union's external borders. But how effective and at whose expense, I wonder.  ETIAS will require the passenger to obtain a prior travel authorisation in return for payment, but there will be no permission to enter. The system will thus have major consequences for travel and crossing the Schengen border itself and on fundamental rights, in particular to privacy. We have been forced to take a lot of such measures in Parliament in recent years, in exchange for maintaining an open Europe and abolishing internal border controls. I wonder whether ETIAS is really necessary or what the objective is.  Many issues have not been adequately resolved in the negotiations. At present, we do not have sufficient assurances that ETIAS will not serve as a discriminatory tool to prevent many from travelling to the Union for no real reason, based on questionable algorithms. We also do not know how the system will work in practice, especially at land borders. They don't have the kind of experience, even the most security-oriented countries like the US. How will the Commission prevent the collapse at the border that we witnessed when the systematic screening of passengers in the databases at the Slovenian-Croatian borders was implemented in April last year? I myself have concerns about ETIAS, especially the consequences that the system will also bring for the Western Balkans region. In the course of my preparation, I therefore put it to the Commission to really examine all the effects and not to rush to implement such a system, which will be difficult to implement in practice.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: – Mr President, 1.4 billion people from 60 countries can enter the European Union without visas. In recent years, it has been shown that some of these people do not come to respect and do not respect European rules and values. Therefore, ETIAS was created. It is a system that will authorise their entry into the Union. In the authorisation process, the ETIAS system will determine whether the presence of that person on our territory poses a danger to the safety of citizens, to health or whether it is illegal migration – of course, and whether it is a danger to the state of legality and we do not come to criminals. ETIAS will check each application in European databases containing information on the movement of different people in and out of the European Union. It will also have access and work with European agencies precisely to help identify wanted persons, to be arrested with a view to extradition, for example, of missing persons, of minors we seek and are victims of trafficking in human beings or of persons evading judicial proceedings. I'd like to make another mention. If there are queues at borders, as we have heard – yes, they are in some countries – then it is because those states have not bought the scanners that make the flow of entry or exit from a state fluidand that check all this information in databases on a single interface. Then all things go well. If we stick with the counters, then they won't go well.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: – Mr President, Commissioner Avramopoulos, Ladies and Gentlemen, already in 2015, on the European Agenda for Security, I argued that our priority should be the three main existing Union systems: the Schengen Information System – the SIS – Eurodac and the VIS – the Visa Information System. Citizens' security, the freedom of movement of Europeans and the integrity of the Schengen area are preserved through the strengthening and better use of these systems: an improved and reformed Eurodac to reflect new challenges linked mainly to asylum, a strengthened Schengen Information System best used to reflect new security challenges and, finally, a Visa Information System , the VIS, reformed to reflect the challenges of mobility and migration. Instead of new and multiple information systems, our investment and effort should be focused on existing systems, as was clear from the Schengen assessments. Eurodac is about to see its reform completed. The reform of the Schengen information system, in which I had the honour of being your rapporteur, has just been completed. With the reform of the VIS, for which I will also have the honour of being rapporteur for this Parliament, we will close this cycle of reforms. Of course, I remain critical of the method followed and the legislative frenzy in this area, which results from the Commission's excessive reactivity to member states' requests. Despite all this, the work carried out by rapporteur Kinga Gál has been remarkable. The compromise reached reflects well the majority position of this Parliament. But let us be clear: the development and implementation of this system will pose numerous challenges, including meeting budgeted costs. The scrutiny of this system, as of the whole package of information systems, will have to be rigorous.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I welcome the group of Italian visitors who are listening to us from the gallery. The introduction of an entry system for citizens of visa-free countries was wanted by Member States to strengthen the EU's external borders, in the wake of security and immigration fears. The Commission's proposal posed serious risks of profiling non-European citizens, not in line with data processing rules and with our own fundamental rights. In the AFET Committee we also raised the issue of the impact on diplomatic relations and tourism, an issue which we consider to be underestimated and which must be taken very seriously. The text has improved, but only in part: the removal of questions about the level of education and employment and the attention to accessibility of the site for disabled people are certainly positive, as is the stronger reference to privacy rules and the establishment of an ethics committee. However, it remains worrying that it is an algorithm that has to assess the hypothetical possibility of a person committing a serious crime or deciding to immigrate irregularly.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: – Dear Chairman, if we want a Europe that is in every sense a safe environment for its citizens and all those who find refuge in it, improving IT solutions for border control and control is of great importance.  Through an advanced computing platform, the European Travel Information and Authorisation System will enable the rapid and efficient exchange of information relevant to prevent threats to citizens' safety and public health. I share the view with the rapporteur that the maximum validity of travel authorisations needs to be shortened in relation to the Commission proposal, and I consider the proposed three years to be a perfectly reasonable timeframe in the current challenging security context, where it is desirable to check passengers more frequently.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: – Mr President, the creation of a European equivalent of the US ESTA system is certainly important and in demand from my point of view. There is no similar system at European level yet, and it is a shame, because ESTA is proof that it has added value and accelerates those requests to enter the US space.  I am in support of ETIAS and I support the solution proposed by My colleague Gál, as it fits into the European strategy on security and, consequently, migration, as the Commissioner mentioned. In the light of security, migration and visa policy, this system is really needed and, given that it can also be linked to other systems in the future, such as the visa and information system or the entry-exit system or the international police database, this system is certainly important not only for travel, but is of crucial importance in the field of security. For these reasons, Mr President, I want this proposal for a regulation and its subsequent implementation to be discussed as quickly as possible. It is also important that the technical requirements for this system are discussed as quickly as possible and that this system is started. I also support the €7 fee and i really laugh at all his critics. I think the fee will be directed to the development of the system and thus increase its better development and implementation.  I think ETIAS is a very good and sustainable instrument and I think, Commissioner, the sooner this system and this regulation are implemented, the better.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Mr President, I welcome the outcome of the report as it improves the proposal to create a European Travel Information and Authorisation System (ETIAS), mimicking the Electronic System for Travel Authorisation (ESTA) system in the United States. The system will be used to determine whether travellers from visa—free countries will be allowed to enter the territory of the European Union. While Europol does not belong to the Schengen acquis and whereas ETIAS will fully belong to it, I welcome that Europol is being strengthened by extending its tasks, especially the responsibility to develop and host the ETIAS watch list. I support the call for the management board, after consulting the European Data Protection Supervisor (EDPS), to adopt guidelines further specifying the procedure for the processing of information for the purpose of the ETIAS watch list. I also share the opinion that it is important to increase institutional cooperation by ensuring that Europol shares information with ETIAS as regards any terrorist offences and ensuring direct consultation through the ETIAS National Unit of the Member States responsible in cases falling under Europol’s mandate. This is very important when it comes to fighting terrorism.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, I believe that the European System of Information and Travel Authorisation is coming to cover up the enormous mistakes and weaknesses that have been made, Mr Avraboule, as you have removed a number of countries which were obliged to obtain visas. It is a classic case of Kosovo, or other Arab countries that are suspected of terrorism. I therefore do not think that you will actually do anything special. Secondly, most of those who commit terrorist acts in Europe are citizens of the European Union and we have seen this. Thirdly, the data you will actually collect will create a huge file. Fourthly, I do not think it covers this system, since you leave out those who have been transporting on tourist buses for three years and have no obligation to cooperate.  Plus, in Samos, if there's anyone to go, they have to get that license. But by the time dozens of boats with illegal immigrants arrive, they will disembark and remain in the area by applying for asylum. So you understand the huge contradiction. Legal workers who want to come to the European Union will ask for permission and illegals will continue to come by boat to the Aegean islands. So look at the huge contradictions.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, it is needless to repeat that external borders management is at the very core of our work to enhance security and improve our management of migration. Together, we are implementing initiatives which make a clear difference in that domain. At the European External Action Service (EEAS), we promote mobility between the Schengen area and third countries, while contributing to the fight against terrorism and serious crimes and safeguarding fundamental rights. In this context, I welcome the fact that you have recently reached an agreement with the Council on eu-LISA and SIS. On SIS, one of the main priorities of the ETIAS rapporteur was to ensure coherence between SIS and ETIAS. A big effort on this was made during the negotiation on ETIAS. The Visa Information System (VIS) together with ETIAS and the recently adopted entry—exit system will together form part of a single platform for third—country nationals visiting the European Union. ETIAS will fill a significant information gap on visa exempt travellers. The VIS proposal will close the gap on long—stay document holders. Together, the three systems will allow verifications of third—country nationals crossing our external borders into the Schengen area for short and long stays. It is therefore of paramount importance that the development of the three systems is synchronised, as ETIAS provides for interoperability with our other EU information systems for borders, migration and security. It not only brings added value, in itself, but also reinforces the added value of other EU information systems. The reinforced eu-LISA will be the beating heart of our work to develop these systems, put them into effect and ensure their smooth and seamless functioning. For these reasons, I call on you to reach a swift agreement with the Council on the VIS proposal so that together we can add the last missing piece of the new EU information platform for borders and security. I am looking forward to the start of the development of ETIAS and the other information systems we have in the pipeline. You will remember that it was one of my priorities from the very first moment I was designated Commissioner responsible for security and migration. I am more than happy to share the responsibility with you and, most importantly, to share the results that we achieve. I encourage you to support these important pieces of legislation when you vote later tomorrow.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: I'm not going to do that - Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank you for your support. I thank my colleagues for their supportive contributions, and I must say to those who have expressed concern about the system that I would like to assure them that we have tried to remedy all concerns in some way during the negotiations and that Parliament has been able to pass a text that has exceeded virtually all hope. So I think we have done everything we can to take account of the interests of the Western Balkans, and I would add to Mr Marias that, no, there can be no worse situation for a citizen from a visa-free country than an illegal immigrant. But that is why legislation needs to be applied properly and in a normal way.   ETIAS will be one of the laws that the co-legislators have recently drafted in the area of security, and only through smart border control and interoperable EU information databases can we combat the ever-changing methods of criminals and terrorists. We need to know more about who is coming and with what intentions, and who is committing crimes inside and outside the Union.  Tomorrow there will be three votes along the ETIAS: one is the regulation, which had to be divided into two parts, as it confers new tasks on Europol, and therefore an amendment to the Europol Regulation has become necessary. However, we could not amend the Europol Regulation by the ETIAS Regulation because the participating States are not the same. The third vote will be on a joint declaration by the Council and Parliament, which is merely in order to speed up the process of participation of schengen associated countries in the ETIAS. For these three votes, I ask for the support of my colleagues, and I hope to receive this tomorrow. Thank you!

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow. Written statements (Article 162 of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. – Security has been a constant theme on the EU’s agenda within the last years and that is why concrete actions have to be taken in this sense. In the light of the recent challenges that the EU is currently facing, especially in terms of migration, it is clear that there is a need for a new approach regarding border security. The European Travel Information and Authorization System – a completely electronic system – will allow and keep track of visitors from countries who do not need a visa to enter Schengen. ETIAS will undergo a detailed security check of each applicant to determine whether they could be allowed to enter any Schengen country. Thus, the travel authorisation system will gather, keep track of and update necessary information regarding visitors, to determine whether it is safe for them to enter Schengen countries. I fully support the proposal and I am convinced that implementing ETIAS is another important step in protecting EU’s external borders. Moreover, I consider that this system is in the best interest of European citizens, while maintaining a balance between their safety and protection of their rights and freedom of movement.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the report of Daniele Viotti, on behalf of the Committee on Budgets, on the mandate for tripartite negotiation on the draft budget 2019 (2018/2024(BUD)) (A8-0247/2018).

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner Oettinger, when I was proposed to join the BUDG Committee four years ago – sorry to leave afar – I confess that I was very intimidated and afraid of the role because, although I had previous administrative experience, I had never addressed the issue of the budget and believed that it was a technical committee, made up only of numbers and calculations. Instead, I have been able to discover, thanks in part to the efforts and work of the colleagues with whom I have worked – I see the chairman of the committee from whom I have learned a great deal – that the BUDG Committee is in fact a very political committee and that everything is ultimately decided in the last few weeks and hours when we are going to draft the budget for the following year. Today we are beginning to get to the heart of the 2019 budget and I have to say that, despite the percentageally significant outlook on all the budget lines, the Commission's proposal, which provides for significant percentage increases on all lines, responds – mind you – not to the bizarre demands of MEMBERS of the European Parliament but to the needs of european citizens. Yesterday we heard Chancellor Kurz, who made an inspired speech and was poisoned by a Europeanism which I consider to be very sincere. Unfortunately, however, your words yesterday and also those of other Heads of State or Government that we have heard in recent weeks and days have focused mainly on the issues of immigration, security and the defence of our borders. I must put a question to the Council, to the Heads of State or Government, who are not here today: exactly what is the reason why the Council is so concerned about migrants and migration and not about the future of European citizens? Exactly, what is the reason why the Council only discusses immigration, security and the closure of the external borders when we are talking about 45 thousand people who, until 1 July this year, moved towards Europe? 45,000 out of 500 million citizens: 45 thousand people are a third of the inhabitants of Innsbruck in Tyrol, a third of Bergamo in Lombardy. If we are not able to deal with a situation like this, how can we expect to discuss the real problems that Europe has, the real problems and the real crises that are there in Europe, that live our citizens, our administrations, our companies? The issue of immigration must certainly be addressed, in a complex and comprehensive way. If we really want, all together, to prevent and tackle migratory phenomena, then we must put our hearts at peace and think that solutions will be found, but it will take years and it will take money and it will take a lot of appropriate ideas and policies: money to invest in Africa, to eradicate the reasons for migration. This is the real key point: hunger, drought, disease, wars, need, lack of freedom, education in democracy. At the same time, however, we cannot forget our obligations to the citizens of Europe; we cannot give them hope, implementing projects and programmes with high expectations, and then not equipping our budget with adequate financial instruments. We have moved from a grey Europe, dealing only with money and national budgets, austerity and cuts, to a Europe instead focused only on fear, fear of losing the fragile, very fragile prosperity that we have managed to achieve. That is why, as the European Parliament, we are calling for more investment, in order to give hope to an entire continent and, above all, to young people; that is why we need to invest in our programmes – I am thinking of Horizon, CEF, Erasmus. And I say this right now: we will not accept any cuts on this type of programme, on the programmes that are most successful among the citizens of the European Union. If we really want a Europe that is in competition with the United States and China, with the world's great economies, if we want our start-ups to compete with the existing multinationals, if we want to focus on Europe 4.0, we can only do it together, investing together. We need more Europe, not more borders. If there is an emergency on our continent, it is certainly not about immigration but about youth unemployment, which is 20%: this is an emergency! That is what we want to challenge the Member States on. We are also ready to support and increase the European Commission's commitment to the Youth Guarantee. If there is an emergency in our Europe, it is the risk of our companies losing competitiveness and we want to focus on that by investing in Horizon 2020 and research.
