If there is an emergency in Europe, it is about supporting small and medium-sized enterprises and Europe, until now, has supported Our small and medium-sized enterprises: I am thinking of what you have invested in Hungary – EUR 31 million – in what you have invested in Austria and Italy. One final final thought. We must look to our future and to that of our generations: the rhetoric of a Europe of seventy years of peace is no longer valid if we do not fill it with content and if we do not give this budget a true soul.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: Mr. The Commission. Mr President, Mr Viotti, Mr Arthuis, Chairman of the Committee, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur, Mr Viotti, for the work he has done on this report. I would like to thank Mr Viotti for a competent draft, for a preparatory work which Parliament, with its priorities, represents. And I can tell you that almost all the priorities of your report, Mr Viotti, and thus of Parliament, are in line with what the Commission wants to achieve politically with the 2019 budget. It is the sixth budget, the second last in the financial framework period and the last to be adopted by this House in November, before your European election.  There are annual worries. In a few days' time, we as the Commission will present to you how commitment to payments will become and how we – reste ' more liquid – will do everything we can to ensure that we do not repeat or even negatively exceed a comparable development in 2012, 2013, 2014 in the dimension. We have to report to you here in a few days significant and good progress results. Secondly, it is a question of us, as the Commission, wanting to support you, of wanting to do everything possible to ensure that the 2019 budget is also adopted before the end of 2018, in November of this year. This would be a clear sign of European capacity to act in difficult times and a sense of responsibility if everyone, the Council, Parliament and the Commission, becomes aware of the responsibility and makes an agreement possible through appropriate willingness to compromise. We fully support the efforts of Parliament and you, Mr Viotti, to avoid cuts under heading 1a: Erasmus+ or ErasmusPro, COSME for small and medium-sized enterprises and start-ups, the Connecting Europe Facility and, above all, our Horizon 2020 research and innovation programme. We cannot talk about the future in Sunday speeches, want to compete with Silicon Valley and China, and then cut exactly where it is easiest in terms of budget policy, but is the most stupid politically. Of course, in heading 2, in the case of heading 1b, what is paid out and what is done is fixed. But then heading 1a must not be the deanoting pillar of the European budget. That is why you have me on your side – and we can show how many applications for Horizon Europe we receive, are being cut, rejected – and you have me on your side. There would be far more added value from European research projects if the budgetary framework could be maintained and cut.  We will have to talk carefully about the Turkey-EU Facility. You will recall that a larger number of Member States initially demanded that we fully finance the second tranche with EUR 3 billion through the redeployments. Now, with a billion fresh money, we have at least achieved some relief in terms of margins in our budget on the way to the end of 2020, and everything else remains to be handed over to the trialogue.  A completely new development, which I can only discuss in a cursory way today, concerns the construction of Frontex and the strengthening of European border management. In a few days' time, we will answer your questions as to whether the figure of 10 000 – and if so, from when and with what steps – is realistic, what this means for training, what can be achieved through secondments and what it can mean in terms of salary payments and investment in material resources in the financial years 2019 – perhaps as early as 2018 – and 2020 in anticipation of the next budget framework. We are also interested in finding a good solution to the fight against youth unemployment, because this is about what the Member States can absorb, what the Member States can implement in projects and what means can be activated within the budgetary framework for reducing youth unemployment, so that we can also support this focus of Parliament. Mr Viotti was right: the issue of immigration, the issue of the number of refugees, has clearly become more and more in perspective. Nevertheless, we also want to have funds in the next financial year to provide effective support to the member states of major contact, Bulgaria, Greece, Malta, Cyprus, Italy and Spain, if necessary, in order to ensure our financial solidarity in this important task in the interests of preserving the Union. All in all, I broadly support Mr Viotti's report and proposal, thus foreseeing a very close partnership in the trialogue and in the negotiations between Parliament and the Commission in the coming months.

name: Marita ULVSKOG
text: rapporteur on the opinion of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs. Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Commissioner, I would like to thank the Rapporteur for his Thank you for giving us the opportunity to have this debate. I am also pleased that Commissioner Oettinger mentioned the issue of unemployment, particularly among young Europeans, right from the beginning. For the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, it goes without saying that this is our main concern. Young people should not end up in unemployment, and if they end up there, it should be for as short a time as possible. For us, it is about the future of all the Member States, that young people are not thrown into despair and that they are not being used and that they do not even get an education perhaps that gives them the opportunity to enter the labour market. We believe that this is something that can also be achieved with redeployments within the budget. We have a proposal that is very clear where we believe that we should, on the part of the European Union, launch an emergency plan against youth unemployment that complements other measures already in place and we want to allocate EUR 500 million to it. Every euro is counted and preferably through redeployments, not necessarily through money without priorities.

name: Morten LØKKEGAARD
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Culture and Education. Mr President! Thank you to Commissioner Oettinger for a good speech in which I attached myself to the priorities that the Commission will play out with. At the very top of the Committee on Culture is, of course, the extremely successful Erasmus programme. I am pleased to note that this was one of the first things that the Commissioner mentioned. All of us in a unanimous committee and quite a few other people in this House are counting on there to be room for a substantial boost, both in 2019 of course, so that we can honour our commitments for the existing programme, but also, of course, for the MFF if you look further into the future. This suggests that we have at least a broad consensus here, and I personally personally am very pleased about that. Otherwise, as you know, it is Creative Europe and Europe for Citizens that we are betting on in the Committee on Culture – the two major programmes, which are not as big as we have always hoped for. I have followed it for a few years and can see that the ambitions have never really been followed by the budget. There has always been too little money, these programs have been chronically underfunded. So I hope, if nothing else, that Brexit and the migrant crisis, about which we talk so much, have meant that both in this House and in the Commission you can see that you should not be saving on contact with the citizens. It is important to ensure that the European project also has a budget when it comes to contact with citizens. So we certainly give priority to it, and we hope and look forward to the Commission also helping to prioritise it.

name: Monika HOHLMEIER
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for his excellent work and for the work she has I would like to begin by thanking my colleague Daniele Viotti and also my shadow rapporteurs for their excellent cooperation and, really, for trying to ensure that we, as the European Parliament, set essential priorities for this next budget. I would also like to thank the Commission, Commissioner, for the fact that the Commission has already taken the right direction with heading 1a, which always suffers from the fact that the Member States try to talk about innovation and research, but regularly try to cut back in this sector first. I urge the Commission to support us in this way, to give innovation and research the financial leeway so that the programmes – whether coSME or the programmes that are very successful for small and medium-sized enterprises and which are very successful and essential for economic competitiveness in our Member States – are given the appropriate priorities here. We are aware that we need to set further priorities in the area of security, but also in the area of migrants and refugees. I consider the new Council decisions to be very important here. The Member States must also give answers and not only always ask us to redeploy, but also follow the decisions taken by their own heads of government, which will also have financial consequences for the European Union's budget. I would also like to thank us in the area of Interrail for continuing the programme and for pushing the Erasmus programme so that young people can exchange ideas with other Member States, that is to say, to learn and study in another country. But here too, these programmes are always at risk from the Member States. Especially when it comes to young people, we want to give them a positive voice for Europe and give them the opportunity to get to know other countries, and not just to start the red pencil in these important programmes, which affect European citizens and young people.

name: Jens GEIER
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, Commissioner Oettinger, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur, Commissioner Oettinger, for the work he has done on this report. In my short speech, I would like to mention a small but significant section of the 2019 budget, to which you have already referred, Mr Oettinger, but to congratulate my dear colleague Daniele Viotti on his excellent preparatory work. I would like to talk about the new edition of the Financial Facility for Turkey or, as it should be called correctly, the Financial Facility for the provision of refugees in Turkey, which is undoubtedly a useful and politically valuable initiative. Providing care for Syrian refugees close to home, which also means, for example, considerable efforts in the education of children, is an undertaking that is definitely worth the financial efforts of the European Union. But the Way in which the Member States deal with this money is significant. In the first financial facility, we had a situation where we were talking about EUR 1 billion that the EU had to raise and EUR 2 billion by the Member States. That, too, is no small thing in the case of a budget that pays EUR 144 billion this financial year. And now it is simply being reversed that two billion are to be raised here and only one billion by the Member States. So not about half-half, but a reversal of the conditions. And, Mr Oettinger, it is only a small consolation that it has at least been possible to prevent this from being fully covered by the European budget. Especially since the money is not lying around somewhere, but so that other tasks in foreign policy are then declared obsolete and must remain. It is this self-serving mentality that, frankly, infuriates me. That is why I warn that the Budgetary Authority of the European Union has two arms, the Council being just one of them. I recommend that my group remain very serious and very tough on this point.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take back from the ECR Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the Mr Viotti, I expressly do not share the positive view of your draft report. I believe that this draft shows once again that the budget is seen here from a completely wrong point of view. It pretends to have money. Where does this money come from? This money that is to be spent here is first being squeezed out of taxpayers, and that does not fall from the sky. We take it away from the citizens and then claim that we can achieve a better purpose here through redistribution than if we left this money to the citizens. I think that is simply wrong. We must ensure that we have a red tape. That would be a contribution to strengthening the economy. We can achieve this, but not through redistribution. Redistribution will damage the economy, because redistribution will result in more bureaucracy and distortions of competition. That is not the right way to go. Of course, it is absolutely right that we should fight against youth unemployment. However, we are creating completely false expectations here if we pretend that the EU should simply put up new programmes and then we will get to grips with youth unemployment. That is not going to happen. People will be disappointed, foreseeable. We should not do that. There are many useful things the EU can do. For example, that we are promoting the less developed regions. Spending money on it is real solidarity. That is what we stand for, and I stand for it. We can do that, but we do not need new programmes for every single problem. Then we will automatically get more bureaucracy. I appeal for less and a better EU.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Mr President, Commissioner, I am speaking to Mr Viotti first. Very good work, Mr Viotti, your initial text was excellent and you had the intelligence to incorporate the best of the amendments of the political groups, including mine, which makes it even better.  I know that you know the priorities of my group, but I want to remind them.  Firstly, we want, like you, more growth for more jobs, which means concretely stimulating investment, in particular the 2020 programme, stimulating and supporting SMEs, in particular through the COSME programme, to vigorously support - we have not talked enough about - the digitisation of European industry, which will be a factor in its future.  Secondly, we want the budget to be used to wake up, as you said, Mr Viotti, and to stir up the European dream in the youth of our countries. That is why we have proposed and support the strengthening of appropriations for Erasmus and we are asking for a real boost for an Erasmus Pro so dear to the heart of the President of our Commission, which is dedicated to the mobility of young apprentices.  Thirdly, we take seriously our commitments to combat global warming and say that climate spending must be increased in 2019 and 2020 if the EU is to meet the target of spending 20% of the budget for global warming for the period 2014-2020.  Fourthly, we are fully aware of the scale of the problem posed by the migration flows and the political pathologies that these flows are beginning to entail. We need more resources for border control, more resources for real solidarity in the reception of refugees and more means for an effective and fair return policy. But also and above all more resources, because the future of Europe is inseparable from the future of Africa and Africa needs, as you said, a real Marshall Plan to offer a real future to the 2.5 billion people that Africa will have in the next 20 or 30 years. I will end, Mr President, with a personal request. I am fighting for the creation of a financial mechanism in the EU budget to help the victims of terrorist attacks, and I thank Mr Viotti for including it in his report.

name: Indrek TARAND
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, Mr Verhofstadt said this very morning ‘I have spoken so many times about Poland, that I will use an opportunity to speak about the future of Europe’, and I shall paraphrase him: ‘I have spoken so many times about the budget, but I will certainly use this opportunity.’ Of course, the budget is about the future of Europe and I just wish to point out three figures. Ten is the number of consecutive Atlantic storms that have developed to hurricanes; 30 000 is the number of forest fires in France, Italy, Spain and Portugal in 2016; and 384 is the number of flood disasters around the world in the same year. Now, let’s multiply it by the number of migrants and you will see how climate change is related to all sorts of crises – which the budget needs to address sufficiently. Now allow me, please, to show some sympathy with our interpreters and please put on your earphones because I will switch to Estonian. Tõlkide töötingimused ei ole eelarveprobleem, sest koos härrade Sassoli, Wielandi, Welle ja Mangoldiga me leppisime kokku, et tõlkide eelarvet ei vähendata, ja nagu emalõvi võitles selle eest ka hea kolleeg Eider Cardiazabal Rubial. Loomulikult saaksime me hakkama vähemate keeltega, loomulikult võiksime vähendada oluliselt tõlkimise kulu, aga enne seda peaks meil olema julgust vähendada volinike arvu. Me ei vaja mitte midagi tegevaid arvutuid asepresidente ja ma mainin, et härra Oettingeri algatused on asepresident Ansipi käes muutunud košmaariks, mida me homme peame interneti autoriõiguste kontekstis hääletama. Selge, kuni meil pole julgust remontida barokset volinikesüsteemi, lubagem siiski ka tõlkidele niisuguseid mõnusaid töötingimusi nagu meil on.  (President katkestas kõnelejat)

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: thar ceann an GHrúpa GUE/NGL. – A Uachtaráin, mo bhuíochas leis an Uasal Viotti i gcomhair na hoibre air fad atá déanta aige.  Ba chóir an tuarascáil air shainordú idirbheartaíochta bhuiséad 2019 a bheith níos láidre agus bá chóir di aghaidh a thabhairt air na hábhair imní atá ag saoránaigh air fud na hEorpa. Táimidne ag cur roinnt leasuithe air aghaidh. Air an gcéad dul síos, táimid ag iarraidh go gcoimeádfar an tAontas Eorpach mar ghníomhaí sibhialtach.  Creidimid go n-éireoidh níos fearr le leas ár saoránach, le dí-armáil, nios mó béime ar réiteach coimhlinte agus tri shíocháin agus cobhsaíocht a chur chun cinn.  Táimid ag iarraidh air institiúidí agus comhlachtaí i dtríú tíortha a dhéanann forbairt air theicneolaíocht mhíleata a choimeád amach ó mhaoiniú taighde faoi Horizon. Cuirim fáilte roimh ghlaoch na tuarascála maidir le dlúthpháirtíocht Eorpach do dhídeanaithe, agus ní mór dóibh athbhreithniú a dhéanamh air rialachán Bhaile Átha Cliath.  Mar sin féin, táim i gcoinne na slí go bpléann sé dídeanaithe agus slándáil shaoránaigh AE i dteannta lena chéile, agus ní haon leithscéal é seo chun dul i dtreo forumsmíleata.   Ba chóir dúinn níos mó béime a chur ar shlándáil eacnamaíoch agus ar shaol na ndaoine a fheabhsú.  Táimid ag iarraidh fiorthacaíocht of FBManna; is tiománaithe an gheilleagair iad.  Tá an ionstraim airgeadais de chuid an EFSI, atá ceaptha chun cabhrú le FBManna, rochtain a fháil air mhaoiniú, ag feidhmiú den chuid is mó mar mheicníocht chun airgead poiblí a úsáid air athchaipitliú na mbanc.   Táimid tar éis leasuithe a mholadh ag iarraidh níos mó slándála ioncaim d'fheirmeoirí agus dóibh siúd atá ag obair san earnáil iascaireachta, atá buailte go dona leis an ngéarchéim eacnamaíochta.  Agus táimid ag iarraidh go nglacfar anois le plean oibre chun dul i ngleic le hardráta dífhostaíochta óige, slándáil ísealfhostaíochta agus pá marbhánta.  Agus mar sin, táim ag súil gur féidir linn brath air do thacaíocht.

name: Mike HOOKEM
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, so we have another year of budget negotiations and another year of EU budget increases. The Commission proposal, as it stands, is to increase the EU budget by 3.1%, setting it at EUR 165 billion for 2019. This is a staggering amount of money, made even more so by the fact that the Commission does not seem to care that the UK is leaving. One of the biggest contributors to the EU budget is leaving and the Commission still wants to increase the budget – which is amazing. The recent Commission statement of estimates showed that the UK will be handing over EUR 17.5 billion to the EU in 2019, which works out at about GBP 42 million a day. It is this sort of attitude which led to Brexit. The Commission does not care how taxpayers’ money is spent: a few million here, a few hundred million there, billions thrown abroad, while frontline public services are cut at home. The Tories have agreed to hand nearly GBP 40 billion over to the EU as a punishment for having a democratic decision to leave. According to the Office for Budget Responsibility, we will not have paid this GBP 40 billion off until 2064, nearly half a century after voting to leave. We could still be paying billions to Brussels thanks to ‘Theresa the Appeaser’ and the Tory Government. Let me just remind everyone here – and especially the spineless Tory negotiators – that the UK is not legally required to pay a penny to the EU once we leave. Theresa May is heading for a Norway—like option, where we are forced to abide by many EU rules without any say over them, continue giving billions in contributions without representation, and have little control over immigration rules. The Tories have had two years to come up with a position on Brexit and show us a blueprint of what an independent Britain would look like. They haven’t got a clue. They don’t have a plan. They will continue giving billions of our money to the EU and are completely split on whether to carry out the result of the referendum or not. Only UKIP will stand up for the millions of people who voted to leave, and oppose this betrayal. (The speaker declined to take a blue—card question under Rule 162(8) from Mr Zdechovský)

name: André ELISSEN
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. Mr President, the 2019 draft budget is again full of expensive Europhile ambitions, which in retrospect often turn out to be unrealistic, risky and sometimes even deception-based.  Take, for example, Professor Ashoka Mody, who recently called the introduction of the euro a huge mistake. His most shocking conclusion is that the Eurocrats knew in advance of the dangers and risks of a common currency. Yet the EU elite pushed this plan forward. As Professor Mody has now shown, the euro has therefore failed to bring us economic growth and prosperity.  The same tunnel vision applies to both the Commission's proposal and Parliament's response to it. This budget is once again costing the taxpayer extra costs, caused by regulatory drive and patronising, such as the expulsion of gas from homes, solar panels, electric cars, uncontrolled immigration, a European army, indoctrination of eu youth and propaganda. If it is up to me and my party, we will stop using the euro and the EU today.

name: Udo VOIGT
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Yes, when I look at this trialogue, I actually ask myself: where are the visions? They are completely missing here. There is a separate chapter on pilot projects, preparatory actions, but I read very little about effectively combating the causes and causes of migration, about promoting the readiness to return. I was in Aleppo three weeks ago. There, the governor told me that 786,000 refugees have returned from Turkey in 2017 and more than 240,000 this year – that's more than a million. And then I hear here that you are still planning EUR 3 billion for Turkey. Why don't you save that billion? Because if there are only two million left in Turkey and not three million, then you can give Turkey less money, and you can invest that money – here in the EU. There are also needy citizens within the EU, there are homeless people, there are unemployed young people, there are weak regions. You might need the money for all this if you do not want to help the legitimate Syrian government rebuild the country.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: – Mr President, I would like to congratulate the Commissioner and all colleagues, congratulate the Commission and the Commissioner first on his proposal, a positive proposal with clear priorities, to congratulate the rapporteur Viotti and all the shadow rapporteurs and, in particular, the rapporteur of the European People's Party, Monika Hohlmeier, for all this work. , which is an excellent job and that it too values the Commission's proposal, which is already good, of itself. The Budget of the European Union is a small budget, it corresponds to about 1 % of the Gross Domestic Product of the European Union, but being small it has an important added value and a very positive impact on the lives of every citizen of the European Union. It contributes to peace, contributes to solidarity, investment, territorial cohesion; it is a budget which, too, contributes to sustainability and inclusion, and in that sense I am absolutely convinced that if this budget were to be higher, we would have fewer problems in the European Union and we would, on the other hand, have the challenges better addressed and it would be easier to overcome them.  Youth must be a priority of the European Union and the budget must be up to the right. Erasmus+ is a very important programme, which contributes to training, mobility, which also contributes to sport in the European Union, even if these skills are national competences.  We must invest in entrepreneurship, invest in research and innovation, without ever forgetting small and medium-sized enterprises, farmers, rural development support, territorial cohesion, and a European Union in this way, in solidarity, also has the obligation to continue with external solidarity and this is one of the values we also have and, by the way, not everyone says so , we are the world's largest donors and we must also continue not only to preach but also to practice solidarity.

name: John HOWARTH
text: – Mr President, I want to talk about two specific areas that will need consideration during this year’s budget trilogue. My concerns spring from public hearings recently conducted by the Committee on Budgets. Last week, the Council made a proposal to expand the resources and staffing of Frontex for the protection of the Union’s external border. I welcome that, but when I questioned the Executive Director of Frontex on their expansion plans for the period of the next Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF), his reply made it obvious that Frontex had no detailed plans for major expansion of their staff complement. The proposals contained in Amendment 2 and the oral amendment that will be moved are helpful in this respect. I look forward to hearing from Frontex clear proposals that can be funded with confidence. To the Council we should simply say, on this matter, that this is a new initiative and new initiatives require fresh money. The Committee on Budgets also recently had a hearing on the mainstreaming of climate spending, and the evidence from the Court of Auditors revealed that the Union is far from achieving its 20% target on mainstreaming climate expenditure. It’s clear, therefore, that we need to raise our game, and again the trilogue needs to address both the mainstreaming of climate change and support for the UN’s Sustainable Development Goals through the EU budget.

name: Zbigniew KUŹMIUK
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. In this debate, I would like to draw attention to the following points: the Commission's proposal to increase commitment appropriations by more than 3%, and in particular to increase payment appropriations by only 2.7%, seems insufficient. This could mean the commission's already known problem of the accumulation of arrears in previous years. The proposed increase in funding for Horizon 2020, Erasmus Plus and the Connecting Europe Facility should be assessed positively, while the amount of funding to support small and medium-sized enterprises or programmes supporting youth employment is insufficient. The proposed increase in payment appropriations under Heading 1B is worryingly low – only by 1.1%, which could put infrastructure projects at risk. Finally, it is unacceptable to offer to reduce agricultural resources by as much as EUR 550 million, especially in the face of the ongoing turmoil in agricultural markets caused, inter alia, by numerous natural disasters and the consequences of the Russian embargo.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: Mr President, dear Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to welcome the content of the excellent mandate prepared by our rapporteur-general Daniele Viotti. From 12 July, in your presence, Commissioner, we will meet the Council and its Austrian Presidency for a trilogue to highlight our priorities, our method and our agenda. Our task will be accomplished at a time when we are already largely mobilized by the draft post-2020 financial framework. While this approach can generate a clear amount of work, it may also justify us trying to raise the 2019 budget, at least for certain actions, to the level it will have to reach as early as 2021. In this regard, I would like to mention the means devoted to the Erasmus programme, and I do so as an example and out of conviction. Erasmus, whose 30th anniversary we have just celebrated, is one of the happiest initiatives to the credit of the European Union. The mobility of young people in Europe awakens and cements European citizenship, it allows us to discover and share good practices in teaching, vocational training and learning. Unfortunately, the Erasmus programme is causing frustration, as 50% of applications are rejected each year due to a lack of funding. I am pleased that the Commission is drawing the consequences in the draft Multi-Year Financial Framework (MFF) that it made public on 2 May, as it proposes to double the volume of appropriations. Parliament, for its part, is calling for a tripling, as new expectations for apprentices and vocational trainees will have to be added to the now unsatisfied demands under the new Erasmus Pro programme. An excellent measure to effectively combat youth unemployment. In these circumstances, Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I hope that from 2019 we can bring Erasmus up to the expectations of young Europeans and their families. Let us make every effort to ensure that the 2019 budget is a harmonious anticipation of the ambitions expressed in the next multi-year financial framework for a Europe that prepares our future and protects us.

name: Jordi SOLÉ
text: – Mr President, the draft budget, as presented by the Commission, contains interesting proposals in some areas, and problems, but I see with regret that in terms of volume it proposes an even lower percentage of GNI as compared to 2010 for both commitment and payment appropriations. The content and priorities do not match today’s most pressing challenges, especially when it comes to internal and external security and climate change. A key area of the 2019 budget is migration and border management. However, I am afraid that this budget will sadly not contribute to enhance solidarity nor integration because it keeps making the link between migration and security. A final word on defence: I don’t welcome the militarisation of the EU budget through programmes such as the European Defence Industrial Development Programme as scarce resources are diverted from functioning programmes with better and more justified aims. Nevertheless, I thank the rapporteur for his work. I wish him good luck and tenacity for the upcoming negotiations.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, the budget is up by 3.1%, but it is still not enough. The Union faces major challenges, such as unemployment, ecological transition or humanitarian reception, where it seems clear that the Council will unfortunately not do anything useful, as we have seen in the weeks. But worse than being an under budget is that it's mis-oriented.  With regard to the Juncker plan, for example, now called InvestEU, it remains unclear whether it meets the ideal additionality requirements and would therefore be financing projects without risk, rather than being a real and direct public investment engine.  Youth employment programmes are not changing the situation of a problem that is structural, which is the lack of employment, especially in the countries on the periphery, which see how their population, mainly young people, has to migrate.  And what sustainable development is this budget talking about? Let's see: they reduce games for biodiversity care, research, combating climate change and increasing them in fossil fuel or defense infrastructures. Wow, wow..., it doesn't seem very sustainable to be said!  And what about increased spending on criminalizing migration and asylum with Frontex, Turkey or Libya?  By the way, heading 5 (Administration) increases by almost 3%, mainly for pensions. And, how can it not increase if you have commissioners like Cañete or former ministers such as, in Spain, Margallo, of the Popular Party, collecting pensions and salary at the same time. There they have an easy cut and that everyone is waiting for: their privileges.

name: Stanisław ŻÓŁTEK
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by It is with sadness that I see that Parliament is again fighting for a budget bigger than even proposed by the Commission and the Council, and this money is poisoned. Their distribution not only gives the Commission bureaucracy and power over countries – sharing this budget is a way to demoralise people. Agricultural subsidies or the development of entrepreneurship create nepotism and mutual hostility of people. How does a farmer work, seeing that his neighbor has more income because he is better able to fill out applications? How do I feel about an entrepreneur seeing that his cwany competitor has arranged a surcharge for the company? Everyone sees: it's not work and honesty that pays off, but cunning, begging and serenity. The idea of Schuman – a Europe of Nations, where the Union guards only the right to freedom of movement of people, goods, ideas and services, was to give Europe freedom and competitiveness in the world, and we have the collapse of the competitiveness of companies and agriculture. Let us eliminate this excessive budget, because the Union will die and the nations will not bear it.

name: Joachim ZELLER
text: Mr President, Commissioner Oettinger, I would like to thank commissioner for his work and for the work she has 2019 is the last year in the current funding period. Normally, therefore, the programmes and projects of the current multiannual financial framework would have to be on the right track in this financial year. From the point of view of the Committee on Budgetary Control, however, I would like to refer to a number of observations which give us some cause for concern with regard to the 2019 budget. For example, outstanding commitments have reached an all-time high: 266.9 billion as of 31.12.2017 – the equivalent of more than two annual payments. Delays in the implementation of projects from the 2006 to 2013 funding period resulted in the payment of cash being used almost entirely to settle commitments for the previous funding period until 2016. Only in 2017 did an acceleration in the implementation of the programmes of the current funding period start. We hope that this will be reinforced in 2019, so that the new funding period, the new MFF, will not again be burdened with significant overhangs of payments for the current funding period. The Committee on Budgetary Control regrets that the EU's financial obligations have increased in the first place through long-term guarantees, guarantees and other legal obligations. This makes careful financial management urgently necessary. This includes the launch of more and more financial instruments and the creation of trust funds, which, like the European Fund for Strategic Investments, are very unsatisfactory in their effectiveness, but which could confront the budget with risks. Current challenges, such as managing the migration of hundreds of thousands of people across the EU's external borders, have also shown that the budget is not very flexible. The Commission mobilised funds from various parts of the budget, but a reporting system which shows what funds have been used and for what purpose remains on the wish list. We strongly remind the Commission that, by 31 July of the following year, an integrated set of financial and accountability reports must be sent to Parliament with a five-year perspective on expected inflows and outflows.

name: Karine GLOANEC MAURIN
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, as we begin the debates on the multi-year financial framework, it is also up to us to decide on the trilogue mandate for the 2019 budget in line with our priorities. Intelligence, sustainability and inclusion are the leitmotif of our efforts to ensure a European budget that lives up to our ambitions. We could add commitment, audacity, solidarity and words must find echo in the deeds. Cohesion of territories, sustainable economic growth, the fight against climate change, the welcome of refugees, the fight against youth unemployment. The challenges are many and can only be effectively met through community-funded policies, without pretences. The vote in the Committee on Budgets was generally satisfactory. This budget is up from 2018 and I welcome the work of my colleague Daniele Viotti. But I want to make three points. This 2019 budget must, in a significant way, improve the funding of the youth employment initiative, as has already been said, Erasmus, it has also been said, it must be remembered, and Horizon 2020 for innovation and research. It must not contain direct budgetary links between terrorism and migration. No confusion. And finally, all new initiatives must be funded with additional funds, not at the expense of room for manoeuvre. I have the great honour of joining our Assembly since 11 June, as the budget debate begins. This debate and the conclusions of the trilogue should enable us to tell our fellow Europeans that Europe will not give up on supporting youth, cohesion policy, rural development, biodiversity, research, innovation and, as you said, Commissioner, investment in digital and energy transition. I will be attentive, in my responsibilities, to these fundamental subjects, which are the most integrated at European level.

name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
text: – Mr President, over the past few years, the European Union has made significant financial contributions to young people. As with all funding, we must look at and remember here that instead of staring at the figures, we have to look at the results. Unfortunately, with regard to the Youth Unemployment Initiative, estimates indicate that funding has not fully served its purpose at all. These things need to be talked about and we need to weigh up where the money is spent when the results have not been obtained in the way that we wanted. So we have to see if we should change the way we spend money. We have also launched a communication campaign for young people, with which the EU distributes free train tickets to Young Europeans. I believe that this is an example of action to which we should not be allocating our little money, but that this money should instead have been directed towards the Erasmus programme, which is encouraging and which is, of course, aimed at young people, with very clear results.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: – Mr President, Indeed, the issue we are discussing today is very important– on the one hand, how we will live in 2019 and how we will agree on what the priorities will be. On the other hand, 2019 is the year of Brexit, and it is a budget that still remains big enough, and the challenge is already emerging as to what the budget will be after 2020. It is a question of whether we, well, let us say, we will do the costs all the time until the 2020 problem comes, before we have a new financial perspective, or whether we need to start thinking about the budget revenue together today. Not only those incomes that the Member States are adding together, but also about the income that we should have as an independent European income, especially by taxing the digital, let us say, the area.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: – Mr President, first of all, our solidarity with the struggle of interpreters. We are currently discussing a proposal for the future Multiannual Financial Framework, but which has cuts in cohesion and the common agricultural policy. It should be said that the current framework has also had significant cuts from the previous framework and, therefore, the framework at the moment, and in particular the 2019 budget, reflects, of course, these cuts and reflects the scarcity of resources that have been allocated in particular to cohesion, i.e. a framework which has clearly insufficient means to counteract what is a generalised framework of divergence. It is also important to say that this divergence was and is a consequence of the merciless implementation of austerity policies and, therefore, what is required of this budget is that it has, in fact, a decisive bet on cohesion to compensate for the losses that have been created and caused by austerity policies that have severely affected countries such as Portugal.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, rapporteur, I would like to thank you for presenting this report. I think that this is a fairly balanced material, where, of course, one priority or the other can be taken into account more. However, as a whole, I see this material as a good basis for today's debate and I think it shows in detail that this discussion is going in a good direction. I personally have security as my top priority and I think that there is much more to discuss about security.  Commissioner, I told you that in committee. At present, there is a need to focus more on youth radicalisation, on the problems of terrorism, on the problems of financing some of the security measures that need to be done. There is a need to introduce digitisation of certain bodies or to strengthen some of the Agencies of the European Union. Everyone says that the external borders should be more secure. But what is "securing the external borders"? That's more investment in digitalisation, it's not about building more people there. Today, we have different means of stopping these people at the border, and there doesn't have to be a dog or a man with a machine gun like we know from communist times. Europol, Eurojust and other agencies also need to be strengthened. Perhaps the FRA, which deals with human rights, as well as the need to strengthen the Fund for Asylum, Migration and Integration, in order to make it more efficient to receive asylum seekers and, for example, to prevent coalitions from falling apart in Germany.  The last thing I wanted to mention, Commissioner, is the reaction here to a colleague from the ENF who said how we are wasting our budget here. Commissioner, neither I nor you nor my colleague Viotti bought champagne here. And I think that the ENF is the last one here to advise us on how to draw and manager the Budget of the European Union.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, obviously the budget is vital because without money, you can’t do too much at European level, and the more we can do at European level in an added-value sense the better it is for our citizens. I agree with the points made by the Commissioner himself in relation to the Youth Employment scheme. Employment has picked up across Europe pretty well but there are black spots, especially in relation to youth, and if we could hone in on those areas this year and next year, and show progress, we would be doing a lot for the whole European project. Also, the Erasmus+ programme has been mentioned. Again, that’s good for young people. That has to be encouraged. An area I am very much involved in myself is the whole area of climate change. We have now, more or less, almost completed the Clean Energy package and therefore we need to allocate money to make sure that we live up to our targets and our commitments in relation to Paris and the COP agreements there. So, there is a lot to be done and if the Commissioner does it I think he’d be entitled to spend a few shillings on a glass of champagne for himself. Well done.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, the debate shows that the budget resources are insufficient, because we have significant challenges to face. First of all we need to support cohesion and that needs funds. In particular, the countries that have suffered from austerity have suffered from the troika's programmes. Research and innovation of course need to be strengthened, because that is the only way we can have a competitive economy. And of course there must be funds to support, to create new jobs for our young people. The issue of the youth guarantee and from then on, of course, Erasmus + as mentioned by many. I therefore think that the procedures to support sustainable development require much more funds and, in practice, what we are seeing is that payment appropriations were 0.92% in 2018, now it is 0.9%. There is a slight decrease, although typically seen as an increase of 3.1%. We must therefore see what happens to the missing funds, particularly in the area of the common agricultural policy.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr. The Commission. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I have listened carefully to your speeches, the comments in favour, the supplementary proposals and the criticisms, and we will go into this in greater depth in the course of the trialogue and the further joint meetings with the Committee on Budgets and also the Council. I believe that your priorities are clear, and here too the vast majority of people have spoken, and that is why we note that the Viotti draft report reflects in a large majority what Parliament wants. A large majority of Members support this draft, which is the mandate for the trialogue and the further negotiations. We will do our best to meet your expectations and answer your detailed questions in depth. The first opportunity to do so at the joint meeting on 12 July will be the first.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the first word, in my case too, is one of solidarity with our interpreters. Commissioner, colleagues and shadow rapporteurs, I thank you very much for this debate. As you have heard, Commissioner, the debate is only just beginning: there are many things that we will have to talk about and I want to highlight, as other Members have done, especially the issue of the refugee instrument in Turkey. This will need to be discussed in great detail, because I want to represent the discontent that there is in this House. However, I am pleased that the priorities that the Council wants the citizens to believe have been reiterated and overturned, and it has been reiterated in this House, in your words and in the words of my fellow Members, that the agenda and that the priorities are other: it is youth unemployment that is 20%; it is the 196 million poor or poverty-risk people on our continent; it is environmental issues; they are the subject of agriculture, small and medium-sized enterprises, research.  We want and will have to work on this in the coming months. I am pleased that there is a common vision and I am pleased that we can build a climate of loyalty between the Commission and Parliament to try to achieve these objectives, and I believe that we will succeed in full. Finally, let me say two things, which fully represent what Europe must do and how we want Europe. We are living in a very strange time and season, a season in which someone is threatening to raise the borders between Austria and Italy again and, at the same time, Europe is funding the construction of the high-speed train and the tunnel under the Brenner pass to connect these two countries. It is a strange time, and I hope that Europe, which wants to build bridges and tunnels to connect and not the Europe that wants to divide, will always prevail. And finally, I am sorry that I have not heard many voices in this House and, above all, that I have not heard any intervention from the League and the 5 Stars, that is, from the new majority in power in our country.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow.  Written statements (Article 162 of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Tamás DEUTSCH

At the same time, the Hungarian People's Party delegation rejects any effort to jeopardised the migration agreement established by the Heads of State or Government of the Member States at the EU summit at the end of June through the EU budget and would weaken the protection of the external borders. Hungary not join the European Public Prosecutor's Office, the Hungarian Government considers this to be a question of sovereignty, on the basis of which the establishment of such an institution goes against the position on a Europe of nations. We strongly reject the use of the EU budget to exert pressure to enter.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – As part of the 2019 budgetary procedure, we are at a unique and significant moment in THE EU's budgetary planning. It coincides with the negotiations and proposals for new programmes under the next MFF. It will also be the last EU budget adopted during the ep's current term of office, for which we have highlighted economic growth, innovation, competitiveness and a specific focus on youth development among our key priorities. From the perspective of the Committee on Culture and Education, Erasmus+, the most important programme to support youth mobility, must undoubtedly remain one of the top priorities even at the end of the current MFF. I am therefore dissatisfied with the fact that the level of funding proposed for Erasmus+ in the draft budget for 2019 is significantly lower than Parliament expected and corresponds only to the targets of multiannual financial planning, and does not even take into account the remaining additional appropriations allocated to the programme as part of the MFF review. The same is true of creative Europe, which is crucial for supporting the EU's cultural and audiovisual sector, which is a source of employment for a large number of young people. The level of funding for the programme must be aligned with its ambitions, in particular with regard to the Culture sub-programme, which is chronically underfunded and which therefore struggles to achieve satisfactory success rates.

name: Ingeborg GRÄSSLE
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, Commissioner and the unfortunately non-existent Presidency of the Council, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has been on. Today we are going against a serious opponent of this is the summer festival in the Parliamentary Society, and that is why I am very attached to you that you have made it here to debate here today an important project, namely the so-called omnibus revision of the Financial Regulation, which is on the agenda for the first time in plenary. It is no exaggeration to say that the dossier has kept not only me, but also many of my fellow Members, you and the staff in the Committee on Budgets and the Committee on Budgetary Control on their toes for a year and a half. That is why I would like to start by thanking the co-rapporteur, Richard Ashworth, the shadow rapporteurs, the rapporteurs from other committees involved and, of course, the secretariats, the Directorate for Budgetary Affairs, the Directorate-General for Finance, the legal service and the language lawyers who have been working on the dossier, the fine-tuning, for a long time – almost half a year. I would like to thank the Commission, the Commissioner for Budgets and his team, Mr Waelbroeck and Mrs Calviso, whom we have handed over to the Spanish Government, and, of course, the Maltese Presidency and the Estonian Presidency. I would now like to thank the Austrian Presidency for its interest in the subject. The Commission's proposal came as a bit of a surprise to us in September 2016, not only in view of the timing, but also in terms of the scope of the proposed amendments. That was very surprising. Tomorrow, we will put the end of a legislative procedure which is record-breaking in a number of respects. The Commission's proposal contained not only a Financial Regulation that was completely restructured and substantially amended, but also amended to 15 sector-specific regulations – hence the name 'omnibus'. This structure led, for the first time, to the fact that, together with the Committees on Agriculture, Regional Policy, Employment, Industry and Transport, we were condemned to carry out a quasi-tailor-made extension of the Rules of Procedure in order to determine the distribution of competences. In view of the experience, I would rather advise against a repetition. In the Financial Regulation, in the budget and in the budgetary control parts, we ourselves discussed more than 750 amendments in the committees, about half of which were ultimately found in the negotiating mandate. We managed to draw up the draft report within ten weeks and then put it to the vote in the committees within ten more weeks. Last autumn, in three and a half months, we made 13 half-day trialogues, and then there was a fourteenth to clarify when the new rules would come into force. Was it worth the effort? Yes, overall, because there are many useful improvements and helpful simplifications for the beneficiaries. I believe, however, that we could have avoided some discussions and detours if we had had a simply structured proposal. The Commission's proposal, Commissioner, has contained many useful improvements. On the other hand, this was opposed by problematic proposals, including the restriction of the rights of the budgetary authority, and we could only say 'no' to that, so to speak. This is also the point on which we were able to prevail from Parliament's side, and a few others – four central ones: there are no trust funds within the EU, which would have led to less democratic control and an even greater fragmentation of the EU budget. The non-profit principle is maintained. There is no transfer of funds from the Structural Funds to the EFSI, and the powers of the Committee on Budgets are retained. On our initiative, we have achieved the rules to exacerbate conflicts of interest. For the first time, we have introduced a regulation for letterbox companies and tax havens. We have strengthened the performance idea. We have strengthened Parliament's role in setting up new thematic trust funds, we have created a single framework for financial instruments and guarantees in the EU budget. We have introduced a new article on audit committees, and we have accelerated a discharge procedure and we agree on this. Once again, the flexibility cushion and the crisis reserve failed at the Council. We believe that this is a good proposal, a good overall package, so thank you very much to all those who have contributed to it.

name: Richard ASHWORTH
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, at the outset, all parties were aiming for simplification, particularly for end users, but it is important to understand that drawing up financial regulations is inevitably a balancing act. Firstly because it is important to remember this is public money and it’s important we do not compromise monitoring and control. Secondly, because performance budgeting brings a whole new dimension to financial regulations. It will usher in a new culture to EU spending: that we welcome, but we also need to understand and recognise the potential conflict between measuring performance and achieving simplification. Overall, I would have wished to have achieved more by way of simplification, but I am happy that we made good progress establishing a performance culture, and I hope the Commission will keep up that momentum. I’d like to make a couple of points. On performance, we set requirements for internal auditors to help measure and monitor performance and we introduced concrete definitions of results and outcomes. On simplification, we streamlined the audit process, we introduced a number of procedures to make the audit burden more proportionate to the level of risk, and we also reduced the burden of multiple auditing. On modernisation, we introduced simpler regulations for blending structural funds and the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI), not only to bring greater clarification but also to ensure that there is no transfer between those systems. As rapporteur for the Committee on Budgetary Control, I am acutely aware of the need to ensure proper control of EU funds so, first, we now have greater clarity and transparency in the reporting procedures. Secondly, we’ve accelerated the discharge procedure. All parties committed to achieving N+1 in the future, and that’s important because it will make audit processes more relevant and more instructive for future budgeting. Overall, I am happy with the outcome but, with such a complex and time—consuming process, there are inevitably some regrets. One in particular was the timing of the introduction of regulations. This is an omnibus package and, bearing in mind the requirements of the different spend committees and the nature of their work, the new regulations will come into force on a number of different dates. That is not ideal. Firstly, not ideal because of the disruption and confusion arising from changing regulations part-way through the year; and, secondly, not ideal in terms of the coherence of the text. However, given the complexity of the exercise – there were 800 pages of text and 13 trilogues – and given the very tight timescale that the Commission required, we had no choice but to stagger the dates of introduction or there would have been no reform at all. I want to finish by putting on record my thanks to the many people who have been involved in this reform right from the start. First, I would mention the Estonian Presidency. Secondly, the Commission, and I particularly want to thank Commissioner Oettinger for his generous help and support. I want to thank the staff. I want to thank the opinion committees. In particular, I want to thank our shadow rapporteurs, especially Mr Maňka and Ms Ayala Sender, and Jean Arthuis, Chair of the Committee on Budgets. But my biggest thanks go to my co-rapporteur, Ingeborg Gräßle. Without her limitless appetite for detail, her patient persistence and her tireless efforts, frankly, I don’t think we would have reached such a favourable result at all. My thanks to all of them, particularly my co-rapporteur. (Applause)

name: Peter JAHR
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Agriculture. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Many thanks also to the cooperating colleagues. Commissioner! I have overwritten my introduction: agricultural policy-making is generally regarded as sensible people. There is a nice quote on this. This comes a bit from materialistic philosophy, but there is such a saying: freedom is an insight into necessity. Especially in the budget, this shows a little bit the political degrees of freedom that we have, because basic arithmetic is often not particularly sexy. As far as the agricultural budget is concerned, we can really thank the people involved, the Commissioner and also our two rapporteurs. We got away halfway unscathed, I would think. Perhaps it was also an acknowledgement of our low level of error in the agricultural sector. It is possible to argue – there is a long dispute – whether everything we do makes sense, but what we do is tamper-proof, I would almost have said. In the first pillar, we are close to the threshold of inconsistency, and in the second we have already become much, much better. And we are also grateful that we will then also receive the promised funds.  We still have reserves, and the reserves concern de-bureaucratisation, the proposals are also on the table, and that is precisely where I would say that we can continue to negotiate. I repeat: agricultural policy-making is generally regarded as sensible people.

name: Peter JAHR
text: Mr. The Commission. Madam President, rapporteurs, Mrs Gräßle and Mr Ashworth, shadow rapporteurs, honourable Members, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteurs for their excellent work and for the work they have done. In fact, an incredibly complex work that is being produced today! It was about modernising and simplifying the Financial Regulation, and it was about the sectoral basic acts for various programmes that are in the European budget. It was very ambitious to tackle everything together. But if only cohesion or agricultural or connecting Europe rules had been discussed, modernised and simplified, other programme managers would rightly have said that modernisation and simplification are also important to them. That is why I would like to pay my respects and thanks to all those who have worked deeply on the matter here over the last two years. I deliberately pass on the thanks to my Director-General and my former Director-General, Mrs Calviso, who has worked on this herself with commitment. With the new Financial Regulation, we already have a new basis from 2018. But it is just as important that the basic rules governing the various sectors and their spending programmes are the basis for the budgetary framework for the next decade. Their work will culminameine in the discussions on the 2021-2027 budgetary framework, which is why, in fact, only a very substantial preparatory work has been done here to facilitate and simplify the negotiations now under way in Parliament and the Council and between Parliament, the Council and the Commission on the budgetary framework for the next decade. It is a question of application: what data and documents does an applicant have to submit for programmes of the European budget? It is a question of the processing of applications, of questions relating to the implementation of the programme, of accounting and control of settlements. Simplification is a goal and a value in itself, but opening the doors to fraud, infidelity and corruption would be the wrong way to go. That is why you, we have all tried to strike a balance between simpler application processing, programme implementation, accounting and control on the one hand, and prevention of corruption, fraud and infidelity in the European budget on the other. We have drawn some practical insights. The question is the flexible use of different programmes: to what extent do we want to make it possible for several programmes to be used to carry out the project? Connecting Europe and Cohesion or the Juncker Plan and Cohesion are examples. As Mrs Gräßle mentioned, as tax havens, we have, I believe, brought intermediary and letterbox companies into a regulation in a very, very consistent form, which I hope will prove its worth in practice. We have made special simplifications for users of smaller-scale programmes, with a few thousand or tens of thousands of euros. We have re-introduced volunteering into the eligibility process, which is important for NGOs. I could mention a wealth of other points. I believe that, for all the complexity and also if, during the deliberations of a year ago, it was already clear that we were now struggling, and that a fundamental modernisation and simplification of our rules and the Financial Regulation through this omnibus was possible, is a worthy work which will also be positive for our Member States, regions, municipalities, researchers in the coming years. , farmers and our citizens and voters. Thank you to all those involved.

name: Lambert van NISTELROOIJ
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, I speak on behalf of this House, of course, but especially also the Committee on Regional Development. We have one third of the European budget, so we have looked with great interest in the last year at this type of debate, after the high-level group that came forward with the need to change and to have another attitude, not to have any more controls.  On control, I think we made big steps forward. It is important for our citizens, important for the beneficiaries, to make it, let me say, sometimes fun to work on European Union programmes, not just a burden, and this means it cuts costs. Easier reimbursement of payments, of the money, simpler checks. We had control on control, sometimes five times! You get weird things in this kind of a Union! Here now, those who perform well will have a lighter system of control – Member States, regions and cities – in cohesion policy.  So this is the aim. The aim is to perform better and to show it. Simpler rules, as the Commissioner said, to combine funds and this is, I think, the need for the future.  The second thing I might pinpoint is that, in fact, we debated on the system for this combination of funds. Is it necessary, if you have regional funds in the envelope of a Member State, to put the money first in the pocket of the EFSI, for instance, in order to get these guarantees later? We rejected Article 13.30a and this was agreed with the Council and I am surprised that now, looking at InvestEU, the Commission has come back with the same proposal. What happened there? We had an agreement with the legislative bodies on that. So Mr Oettinger, what went wrong there? Because the good steps that we make here should be followed.  And my last sentence is on communication: you could bring in some amendments to show our citizens what we are doing with these new methods.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: On behalf of the Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament, the floor would now belong to Bogusław Liberadzki, but I do not see Vice-President Liberadzki here.

name: Nedzhmi ALI
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, first of all I would like to congratulate our colleagues Ms Gräßle and Mr Ashworth on the enormous amount of work done during the last two years on the proposal for a regulation. Financial rules play an important role, setting out the principles and procedures governing both the revenue and expenditure parts of the European Union budget, as well as the control of EU funds. The main objectives of the Commission proposal are simplification and flexibility. We support the broad objectives put forward by the Commission, especially the major priority of simplification for recipients of EU funds. This is very important in order to ease the work of the beneficiaries, and to reduce the delays in implementation of a number of EU key programmes. In this regard, we support the Commission’s aim of creating a single rule book for recipients. In order to achieve maximum results we need to have impact assessment preceding any future substantial changes of the financial rules, as well as increasing cross-reliance on audits. Nevertheless, the Commission should maintain the right to audit if it deems it necessary. We welcome the measures on budgetary flexibility. These were needed in order to enhance the ability of the EU budget to adapt to changing circumstances and to respond to unexpected developments. However, we need to maintain a balance between flexibility, sound financial management and the rights of the budgetary authority. During the work on the proposal, the effective use of financial instruments has been improved. The financial rules will be a step towards a budget focused on results if we further embed performance into spending decisions. We support the agreement reached during the trilogues. We believe that the simplification of EU financial rules will contribute to reducing the costs and time needed to implement EU funds, as well as decreasing the level of errors. It should also increase the impact of the policies and their results in the process of practical implementation.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – I will speak as a former long-time mayor of the municipality, who has initiated a number of dozens of European-funded projects. There is a lot of talk in each financial perspective, on the one hand, about simplifying budgetary rules and, on the other hand, increasing accountability, although it is clear that these objectives are contrary to each other solely in a semantic way. Their implementation in practice is even more distant from the ambition. I am referring, first of all, to the interpretation of the general budgetary rules in the Member States, which often ends with much stricter implementing and audit rules and the result does not reduce bureaucracy, but increases. Therefore, the first thing that the implementing rules for the new financial perspective should focus on is legal certainty and clarity. It is better not quite perfect, but clear rules, than a set of obscure lozungs full of good wishes.  I would like to commend the work of the rapporteurs. They duly took due account of the Green Group's demand not to allow the use of cohesion policy funding for other purposes, in particular the transfer of them to the European Structural Investment Funds. The appropriations of the latter funds must not increase at the expense of cohesion policy. Unfortunately, this provision has not been proposed by the Commission for the first time, with very strange arguments.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, we’re told the Commission’s focus in this proposal is as follows: simplification for recipients of EU funds, cross-reliance on audit assessment for authorisation, more flexible budget management and simpler and leaner EU administration. All very laudable, but also all very laughable, when you consider point two – the cross-reliance on audit, etcetera. I have said this already in this Chamber and I’ll say it again now, and I’ll keep saying it until it gets changed: the annual audit of the entire Commission budget by the European Court of Auditors is seriously flawed. It takes a correction, which it knows has been applied only in certain areas of the budget, areas where the Commission and various Member States had made corrections from their own earlier audits, and it applies that percentage correction across the entire Commission budget, thus presenting a flawed and false figure in the final accounts. This must be changed. Commissioner, you can fool some people, but if you drill into it you won’t fool the lot of us – and you have been caught out.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all, let me thank you for very good material and a very good document that can be discussed quite well. I think that it is precisely the issue of drawing up and implementing the European Union budget that is one of the most important issues that we need to address in the structural reform of the European Union. However, there are still some problems with the implementation of the budget. We are left with surpluses, just as the various areas financed by the European Union are changing, and that is what we need to respond to when drawing up the budget. I welcome the simplification and flexibility of the budget. In my opinion, this is the right way to go, but it is very important that European finances are also used effectively. The current set of rules, both the absorption of funding and the follow-up, need to be revised. As a member of the Committee on Budgetary Control, I could tell you about this. In the long term, under-u.S. funding is also a huge problem. Thus, operators do not make enough use of the European Union's auxiliary hand. This is due to the current complicated and sometimes lengthy process of fundraising and the burden on the administration. I therefore welcome the simplification of the rules for beneficiaries of European Union funds.  But it must not happen that simplified administration will result in inefficiencies. The rules must subsequently be put into practice responsibly and monitored and controlled in order to avoid circumvention of the rules. And if that happens, there must be tough sanctions. Subsequently, we need to focus on the results, whether there will really be improvements. My concern is only that simplification will lead to abuse.

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: – Madam President, I simply wanted to say to Mr Ashworth that I have to acknowledge that Mrs Grule was thoroughly employed in the exercise of co-onence, because in the middle of the exercise you went to the PPE Group. I must say that I am now glad that I was not Mrs Grule's co-manager, because surely she would have gone on to thicken those ranks too. Such is the capacity for persuasion it has in the exercise of the revision of the Regulation. After these jokes, I would like to thank the Commission, of course, for the hard work over all these months; thank the Commissioner, of course, for his services and ours too, for our secretariats, both the CONT Commission and the groups; and, of course, will also let me pay a small tribute to the Director General, Nadia Calviño, who has become the socialist and European government of our president, Pedro Sánchez. In budgetary control, one of the principles in which errors multiply exponentially is precisely the complexity of programmes. In fact, that is precisely why this simplification exercise. In addition, we add to that the repeated complaints of all the beneficiaries of the programmes, which do not help us anything to improve the image either. Hence this comprehensive exercise, sometimes frustrating, but in the end satisfactory in the progress we have made, gives us precisely the possibility of being able to apply it to the new MFF. Of course, we are pleased that the trust fund was not extended to the internal policies of the European Union, since, although flexibility is increased, it also limits our ability to control. And yet we regret that the Council did not accept flexibility for external action and the crisis reserve. However, we are concerned that the new MFF cannot implement all the improvements to the Regulation in the new Regulations.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: – I would like to acknowledge the extremely demanding work of both rapporteurs, but also of negotiators from all the institutions. Those who use The European Union's finances have repeatedly complained that the rules are complex, constantly expanding and complicated, leading to a slowdown in implementation and higher costs. Even the bugs are bigger. If there is less bureaucracy, less paperwork, we will not discourage mayors, mayors and other beneficiaries from applying for European finances. They will draw on European finances more quickly and at a lower cost. It is a pity that the Commission has not considered from the outset what impact all its proposals will have. If we approve of something, we need to know exactly the consequences of each of our decisions. If we had an impact analysis available, the new rules could have been in place earlier and the simplifications could have been even more pronounced. I will come back with this because I have obtained half an extra minute that letterbox companies based in tax havens that do not cooperate will not be able to apply for funding from the European budget. Commissioner, there are also firms in cooperating tax havens that are equally tax-advantaged and therefore more competitive with those that are not in tax havens, and we will also have to deal with this problem in the future.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, I found this an interesting topic because I am not involved in the Committee on Budgets, but at the same time we all know that without money you cannot do much and I think that great compliments are due to the Commissioner and especially the joint rapporteurs: Ingeborg Gräßle and Richard Ashworth.  It was interesting that they put the emphasis on simplification. That is something that this Commission has been emphasising from the beginning, and they have made much progress in that regard, without – as the Commissioner pointed out – compromising in relation to making it easier for people to make fraudulent use of our funds. That would be a disaster. So, Richard said he was happy, and if Richard is happy, I am happy.  The only point I would make is that when you see MEPs like Richard, it is sad that they will be leaving the European Parliament before a year is out because of Brexit.  Finally, he also referenced EFSI and Structural Funds and as rapporteur for InvestEU, I will be taking his points there on board in relation to that.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, first of all I would like to thank the rapporteurs, Mrs Gräßle and Mr Ashworth, for the work they have done, because it has really taken a lot of effort to be able to have budgetary rules that apply to the general budget and that take into account first of all the idea of flexibility, who realise that there must be a relative adjustment when we have emergencies and who at the same time insist that good administration requires transparency. , accountability and, of course, accessibility.  Therefore, these combinations I would say are achieved to a very, very large extent. We aim to reduce red tape, increase efficiency, simplify during implementation, but also to tackle fraud, to stop the partying that takes place with certain European funds and, of course, to deal decisively with companies established in tax havens.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr. The Commission. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her In a nutshell, I can actually fully endorse The assessment of Mr Marias. If we take the various objectives – simplification, more flexibility, modernisation, learning from the experience of practice and drawing conclusions – then I believe that we have largely found the balance. I would ask all of us to work now with these new rules. They will not last for eternity. There will still be an opportunity to improve in detail in the foreseeable future. However, I think it is a good basis between Parliament's interest in shaping budgetary policy, controlling the implementation of the budget, the interest of our citizens and applicants for programmes to enter into dialogue with the European Union as easily and unbureaucratically as possible and to call up budgetary resources in the interests of our European objectives, and, thirdly, to avoid corruption, infidelity and fraud of European taxpayers' money. That is why we, as the Commission, which is, after all, primarily responsible for the implementation of the budget, are very satisfied with the result.

name: Ingeborg GRÄSSLE
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I would like to thank all my colleagues who have now sacrificed themselves this evening and who have given up on a celebration that is certainly nice. I would particularly like to respond to Mr Jahr's quote from materialism, modified with Mao: learning from farmers means learning to win.
