All I can say is that the budgetary rules that we have now presented are good, but we must monitor them in application. I am now looking at 15 years of budgetary regulation changes – every two years the Commission comes up with some draft. The great request that I would have is that it is now a good thing that we should now ensure the stability of the rules and not try again, then here and there, to get what we have not now got. We have made a decisive simplification of flat rates. You now get EUR 60 000 of taxpayers' money for very little evidence – that is a heap of money. That's an average annual salary in Germany – even more so – in other countries it is very, very much money. All I can say is that anyone who still says that it is complicated is simply malicious and does not know anything at all. So we can't give it away completely. I am concerned about the crucial simplification of the audit. I am already curious to see how we deal with Member States whose administrative and supervisory authorities are more than dubious, where the people are shouting at us: corruption and fraud with EU money, as we justify others, in other words, in the face of this population. I am sure that the Commission will again have something to think of. I would like to give you a simplification proposal on public procurement. The directive is the subject of codecision – and I spoke to your colleague, Mr Jourova this afternoon – perhaps it is time to remove procurement from the codecision procedure and to regard it as a technical basis where not everyone is allowed to write their favourite sentence. I believe that this would be an important simplification for all those involved. I would like to thank you once again for a successful legislative process.

name: Richard ASHWORTH
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, the European Union budget, as we’ve said this evening, needs to constantly adapt and change to meet new challenges, new priorities, new budgets and now a new multiannual financial framework (MFF). Behind all that, we need the constant imperative to ensure scrutiny and control. I am happy to think that these regulations, incorporating as they do simplification, performance, flexibility and modernisation, will lay foundations for the budget to meet those challenges and to ensure value for money for European taxpayers. I am proud to have been co-rapporteur and I want to thank my colleagues for their very kind comments in that respect. It is a matter of great regret to me that I shall not be here to see these processes come to fruition but I am very heartened, warmed, to know that Mr Kelly will be here keeping an eye on affairs on my behalf. My thanks to you.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow, 5 May 2008. Adopted on 17 July 2018.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: The next item is the Commission statement on the adequacy of protection provided by the EU-US Privacy Shield (2018/2645(RSP)).

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, thank you for the opportunity to discuss the EU—US Privacy Shield here today. In the wake of the recent Facebook Cambridge Analytica scandal, this motion for a resolution confirms that privacy matters are taken very seriously in Europe. I can only agree with Parliament’s concerns in this regard, as the Commission has highlighted on previous occasions.  But I would like to recall that the Privacy Shield was set up to offer a high level of protection for personal data. It provides the adequate level of protection required by EU data protection law and the EU Charter, and even though the Privacy Shield predates the entry into application of the EU’s new rules, the General Data Protection Regulation, we negotiated the Shield with the new standards in mind. The Facebook Cambridge Analytica scandal took place before the Shield existed, and it is the Shield that has introduced stricter rules for exactly those practices that seem to be at the heart of this scandal. Thanks to stricter conditions for the sharing of personal data with third parties, and more stringent rules on data retention, the data of our citizens is now better protected when it is transferred to the United States. It is of crucial importance that these rules are also properly enforced. I therefore welcome that the United States Federal Trade Commission has immediately opened an investigation in the Facebook Cambridge Analytica case, and that it is also assessing whether these companies violated their obligations under the Privacy Shield. This investigation will certainly be a test case for the enforcement action of the United States authorities.  The framework has been operational for almost two years and, as required, we are continuously monitoring its functioning. Almost 4 000 companies from Europe and the United States have signed up to the Shield. This is more than during the first 10 years of the Safe Harbour framework’s existence. This testifies to a large usefulness of the Shield, but we are all here fully aware that the functioning of the Shield could be, and should be, improved. We also expect that the United States authorities fully concentrate on the day-to-day oversight of the Privacy Shield.  I very much welcome Parliament’s insistence on the need for regular and proactive compliance monitoring. This is a message we consistently convey in our contacts with the United States. Let me also make it very clear that the Commission will not hesitate to act upon its obligations and to make use of its power to suspend the Privacy Shield. But, at this stage, a suspension is not warranted. All the elements on which our adequacy finding was based have remained in place since the new US administration took office, and we have seen some improvements and new appointments in the relevant bodies and authorities.  We also have to keep in mind that without the Privacy Shield framework, data transfers would predominantly take place on the basis of contractual safeguards between EU and US companies. In comparison, these will be costlier, in particular for smaller companies and start-ups. Moreover, a sudden suspension would affect all those individuals in the EU whose personal data would no longer benefit from the additional protections of the Privacy Shield.  At the same time we fully share the position of Parliament that there are a number of outstanding issues which have to be addressed. I have already made clear to my counterparts in the United States that I want the open issues to be resolved by the second annual review, which will be kicked off by Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross and myself in Brussels on 18 October.  Our US counterparts will need to provide answers to the challenges that we identified at last year’s annual review. I will not simply repeat the same in the second annual review. I expect the United States to stick to its commitments, including on finding a permanent solution on the Ombudsperson.  Let me also stress that the data protection supervisory authorities have been, and will be, strongly associated with the work of the Commission, including with the second annual review.  I count on your support so that ahead of the second annual review we can transmit a strong EU message of urgency to the United States, and I look forward to hearing your views on this important topic.

name: Axel VOSS
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done It is a stupid situation in which we find ourselves. On the one hand, we are convinced that the Privacy Shield is actually a good basis for transatlantic data traffic, but on the other hand, we also see the shortcomings that this still has, so to speak, in the US administration, in particular with regard to what has been agreed. In addition, Facebook and Cambridge Analytica are now appearing. So from the PPE-DE point of view, we have to say that, in principle, the agreement works well, and the idea of improving the Privacy Shield after each review and making it better is also good and right. And the PPE-DE remains convinced that this is the right way to go, including to protect the data of our citizens. That is why we will not support demands that affect or want to bring down the agreement as a whole. We do not see any point in an abuse of 2999 other companies being brought into this situation or in distress. What do we want to do once these companies have binding corporate rules? In this case, do we want to change or abolish the whole data protection law, because that is actually the sensible way of no longer becoming dependent on these political levels? So I think we really need more control. We must insist – and you are doing it right – that the administration in the United States should be told once again that this is not the case. And we should respond calmly, not emotionally.

name: Birgit SIPPEL
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her No question. Compared to the predecessor Safe Harbour, with which the Commission has already suffered shipwreck, there are improvements to the Privacy Shield. But is that enough to achieve data protection in the US that is essentially in line with EU rules? That alone is the yardstick by which Privacy Shield must be measured. Unfortunately, it does not meet this standard at the moment. The list of concerns remains long: inadequate protection against profiling, weak oversight by the ombudsman, for which there is still no permanent occupation, the independent US civil liberties watchdog is not fully quorum, important reports on the extent of intelligence surveillance are withheld from the public, it is difficult to defend against data abuse, no protection against state mass surveillance, and no protection against data abuse by companies, as the last Facebook/Cambridge analytic underlines. The risk is therefore high that the European Court of Justice will collect the Privacy Shield, as Safe Harbour did. And even today, companies that have a well-functioning legal department say they don't rely on ePrivacy as a privacy foundation, it's too uncertain for them. Some Conservative colleagues are running as supporters of the small businesses that need this protection. But what is the point of a start-up that does not offer sufficient protection and may not even exist in a year's time? That is why we are calling for the Privacy Shield to be repealed if the US Government does not finally address the existing problems. And this is not only a political demand, but is enshrined in the Data Protection Regulation. Article 45(5) states that if the Shield cannot provide an adequate level of protection, the Commission must suspend it. So there is a lot to do.

name: Daniel DALTON
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, in our rush to debate the merits and faults of the Privacy Shield, we seem to have forgotten what it was meant to do. It ensures EU protections for personal data extended beyond our borders. That means individuals have easily accessible redress mechanisms when they fear their data is not being treated properly. It makes access to US markets simpler and easier for our SMEs. It is an indispensable tool that ensures that data can flow between the EU and the US without jeopardising the standard of protections that apply. Now there are, of course, challenges with enforcement. EU data protection law itself is complex and trying to marry that with the obligations of a third country is not always easy, but this is not a reason to throw the baby out with the bathwater, especially as many EU governments themselves are struggling to implement the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR). The focus should be on how we improve enforcement and there are some very useful suggestions in this resolution that we support. However, proposing to suspend the Shield is irresponsible and driven by the false assumption that the US is some sort of regulatory Wild West, which it clearly isn’t. There are no grounds to judge the US as non—compliant, as the Commission has just said. Such a proposal would hurt Europeans. It risks going back to a contractual system with fewer protections, less clarity for consumers who want to apply their rights and more onerous paperwork and legal fees for our SMEs. The Shield deserves our full scrutiny and inspection, but there is a big difference between scrutiny and sabotage.

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, we all want to protect SMEs and businesses but isn’t this a little bit like the world on its head? We are talking about a kind of agreement here in which the USA is non-compliant. They are not implementing. This is not like in school, where you also get points for the efforts that you make. You have to be compliant: full stop. If they are not compliant then, indeed, the Commission should suspend the Privacy Shield. The point is that they have not been compliant for the past nearly two years. This is not a matter of there being some technical problems, they just don’t want to implement. The political will is not there. If they really do want to implement, then they can follow our resolution that says ‘Comply by 1 September’. They have another two months: what’s the problem? If they really want to – and this is America, they can do anything – surely they can implement the Privacy Shield? And if they cannot do that in two months, what makes us believe they can do it in three months or in a year? We are fooling our citizens here because what we’re talking about is not the presumption of compliance, it’s the pretence of compliance. In the current situation we are pretending that citizens are covered by the protection of personal data, whereas that is not the case. We have a duty to our citizens here. If anybody wants to protect businesses, and they have a right to legal protection as well, then two things should happen. The first is that we should not be talking here about a resolution, we should be talking to the Americans and telling them to get their act together and implement right now. The second thing that needs to be done is that we have to stop making bad laws and bad agreements that do not comply with the Treaties and with EU law, and which, every single time, have to be thrown out by the Court of Justice. They are doing our homework and we are doing a disservice to our citizens. So let’s get serious about data protection. We’ve been rejoicing about the General Data Protection Regulation: now let’s live up to expectations. Ensure compliance by 1 September or the Privacy Shield has to be suspended.

name: Romeo FRANZ
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which It is time to finally admit that our data is not secure in the US. The Privacy Shield does not change this. On the contrary, it allows the transfer of our data to companies and intelligence agencies in the US almost without borders. Following the Commission's initial review, EU Data Protection Supervisors identified a number of shortcomings in the Privacy Shield. They are threatening to take legal action to the European Court of Justice unless massive improvements are made. As confirmed, the revelations about the NSA's interception centers in eight central AT&T hubs came to light recently – a clear violation of the ECJ's requirements in its ruling that brought down Safe Harbour. Right now we have the best conditions. With the application of the General Data Protection Regulation since 25 May, US companies offering services in Europe must in any case comply with EU law. And since the Facebook scandal, political sentiment in the US has also moved toward data protection laws. The new Consumers Privacy Act in California is clearly modeled according to our General Data Protection Regulation, and even the White House is considering a US-wide data protection law. Suspending the Privacy Shield would therefore be an important signal, just at the right time. Please vote in favour of the text of the LIBE Committee without amendments!

name: Cornelia ERNST
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The evaluation of the Privacy Shield has shown one thing quite clearly: the Privacy Shield is not a shield for fundamental rights at all, but a fig leaf for the fair-leavers. Neither the US Ombudsman is independent – and we have criticised this from the outset – nor is there any proper oversight by the competent trade authority, and the Europeans do not really have a real remedy, an effective remedy, against the US Government. And the surveillance laws have not been changed, but have been extended. The mass data collection goes on as if nothing had happened. Perhaps the United States should first adopt a sensible data protection system, then we really would not have to do the circus that we are organising here without interruption any longer. I would remind you once again: yes, Safe Harbour was cancelled by the ECJ because of mass surveillance and not because of an unsightly name. We just call it different now. And the Americans had also made some promises to change, for example.B, FISA 702, e.B. to create legal avenues for Europeans. But not much has happened. The Privacy Shield does not provide adequate data protection, and this is not in line with the General Data Protection Regulation. If you will, that is illegal. US companies happily make billions in profits as we watch EU law being trampled underfoot every day. The Commission is the guardian of the Treaties, and we therefore call on it to suspend the Privacy Shield unless all the shortcomings are rectified by 1 September. And if the Commission does not do so, we must talk about an action for failure to act against it.  I will say it again at the end: we are really making ourselves a monkey now if we do not take our own laws seriously and do not actually protect the fundamental rights of citizens.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, I think a pragmatic approach is needed for the US Privacy Shield and the framework that it provides for the safe transfer of data between the EU and US companies. We also have to ensure that the EU reaps the maximum benefits from the Privacy Shield and that our citizens’ data is protected efficiently. Indeed, there are outstanding issues within the framework that need to be addressed in order to ensure its success; I accept that. However, revoking the Privacy Shield is not a solution. Companies’ compliance with their obligations must be monitored more effectively and frequent searches will be necessary to deal with companies that may make false claims regarding their involvement in the framework. Significantly, it enables European SMEs to work with their US trade partners, without cumbersome negotiations on data transfer for their businesses. The Privacy Shield cuts administrative burdens hugely for nearly 3 000 companies already certified. As PPE negotiator on the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) for the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, I am very conscious of the seriousness of protecting citizens’ personal data and companies’ compliance with data protection—related obligations. The Privacy Shield includes sanctions to effectively deal with violations by participating companies including, if necessary, their removal from the Privacy Shield list, which will have a deterrent effect for participant companies.  Therefore, I do not agree with those who say that we should suspend the Privacy Shield. I think the Commissioner and colleagues such as Mr Voss and Mr Dalton have said this would be a mistake. I agree with them. Efforts should be focused on improved monitoring of compliance within the framework, rather than suspending the deal altogether and definitely we should try that before we talk about suspension. After all, it took a long time to get Safe Harbour replaced by the Privacy Shield. To throw the Privacy Shield out now would not be a good idea.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her In March 2014, this House, by a large majority, allowed the Safe Harbour Agreement to be repealed. The European Court of Justice finally overturned it on 6 October 2015 – a great success without which we would not have a Privacy Shield. However, we cannot rely on this either, because even now the personal data of European citizens in the United States are not adequately protected. The data scandal surrounding Cambridge Analytica and Facebook has just shown this. Both companies were certified, and yet the transfer of personal data to third parties was and is possible without any problems. With the reintroduction of Section 702 of the FISA Act and the introduction of the CLOUD Act, it is clear that the American partner has no real interest in real improvement of the situation. Everything that happens is half-hearted, abuse is not an isolated case, but systematic, and both the European Data Protection Supervisor and the Article 29 Working Party have found that Privacy Shield does not guarantee the necessary protection of private data, as provided for in European data protection law and the EU Charter. Especially at a time when the Trump administration believes it must wage a trade war against Europe, we must not be reckless. The Privacy Shield must be suspended if the US fails to meet its obligations by September.

name: Helga STEVENS
text: Mr President, the EU-US privacy shield plays an important role in the data protection of our European citizens. More than 3,000 companies signed up to the privacy shield. These companies promised to protect data transfers between the EU and the US more strictly than what US law requires them to do. I therefore cannot support the proposal to declare the shield inadequate and possibly suspend it. Without the privacy shield, our European citizens and SMEs will be worse off. They will be the ultimate victim of such a drastic proposal. Citizens will have fewer redress rights because the ombudsperson disappears. It will be more difficult for Europe to verify that data transfers are carried out correctly. There is therefore a greater risk of misuse of European data. SmEs will also find it more difficult to compete with large multinationals because of the high cost of bilateral protection contracts. The Us implementation of the shield could indeed be better, but at the moment our citizens and SMEs are better off protecting the privacy shield than without it.

name: Nadja HIRSCH
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report, which is a very That EU U.S. Privacy Shield offers some improvements compared to the previous EU US Safe Harbour Agreement. However, it must be said quite clearly that the protection of personal data still raises a major question mark over many aspects: commercial aspects, national security, legal remedies and, indeed, law enforcement. It is necessary for the Commission to finally put more pressure on the US Government. This government is responsible for ensuring that US companies adhere to it and implement it. The Commission needs to take even more action in this. It must be our aim to have a genuine data protection agreement and to have guaranteed the General Data Protection Regulation. Large companies have the opportunity to identify their own regulations today. However, it is precisely small businesses that must be confident that in future they will have a high level of protection on which they can rely and, in fact, legal certainty. This is necessary, and the Commission really must do that.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, there has been a great deal of concern in the debate because it is a given that the protection of personal data must be at such a level as laid down in the Charter of Fundamental Rights. At the same time, we also have the judgment of the Court of Justice on the safe harbour, which sets out terms and conditions for the protection of personal data and at European Union level we have the well-known GDPR regulation.  There is therefore a framework which we must demand, within the framework of the protection shield, be respected by the United States. Because the question is, and the debate shows, that there is not enough protection provided by the privacy shield in the European Union-United States agreement. And we have to push in that direction, we have to demand it, and I think there is very specific time for the United States to comply. This must be a decisive signal and we will see from then on the practical measures that we need to take. Today, however, a clear warning to the United States.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, thank you for this very interesting discussion, from which I understand that we share the same concerns and the same dedication to ensuring strong data protection safeguards for EU citizens. As many of the speakers mentioned, there are also concerns regarding small and medium-sized European enterprises. I well remember the time after 6 October 2016 when Safe Harbour was annulled by the European Court of Justice. What we heard from the big American companies, first of all, was that yes, they would cope with the situation and would make individual arrangements as they have an army of lawyers, but I heard from small and medium-sized European companies that there was panic and a big problem of sudden legal uncertainty. That is why we worked so hard on creating the new system, fully tailored to the requirements of the European Court of Justice in the Schrems case. I came here to share with you my conviction that, with the Privacy Shield, other protection of the data of Europeans is better guaranteed, but I openly admit that the system does not work absolutely perfectly and that we need to impose continuing and increasing pressure on the US administration to fulfil all the commitments, because if they do not do so I will not hesitate to suspend the shield. But this time has not yet come. We still have to take some time before the second annual review and give them the chance to do what is necessary.  One more point of a formal nature: this is not an agreement, this is a unilateral decision of the Commission, and we are taking our responsibility very seriously. I myself was fully aware that by adopting the decision on the Privacy Shield I was becoming jointly responsible for what is happening to the data of European people on US territory, and this is a strong factor compelling me to be very vigilant and to do everything possible to achieve the goal of protection of European data in the full sense, which is essentially equivalent to what we have under the General Data Protection Regulation rules. We know where the weaknesses of the system are and, as I said, we pushed the Americans to come forward with improvements. We have seen some improvements, but there are still things to be done. Especially, I do not understand why there is still no fully fledged Ombudsperson in office, and that has to be achieved as soon as possible.  I think that if the European Union has one strong voice we will achieve much more than if we send differing signals to the USA, and I appreciate Parliament’s continuing support for having as high as possible a level protection of European people’s data overseas. Thank you for this debate and for your sustained support, and I can only repeat that the Commission is fully committed to doing everything possible in order to have better news in the second annual review. If not, we will think about the next steps.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: . – I have received one motion for a resolution pursuant to Rule 123(2) of the Rules of Procedure. The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, 5 May 2008. Adopted on 17 July 2018. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Jaromír KOHLÍČEK
text: Writing. – It is strange, but the proposal put forward addresses in a significant part of the text the problems of complementing the relevant committees and commissions on the US side. It is clear from this fact that the US side somewhat underestimates EU-US cooperation on privacy. In practice so far, our partners behind the Great Puddle have mostly taken unilateral steps before bilateral negotiations have taken place. A classic case is data relating to air passengers between the EU and the US. Another interesting feature is the lax approach of Congress, which, among other things, rejected a proposal by the Federal Commission to protect customers of broadband and other telecommunications services. In the context of the data-sharing scandal by Facebook, up to 60 different companies are taking similar steps in the EU with little understanding. By the way, facebook was found to have provided personal data to more than 2 million EU citizens for commercial use. Many servers used for broadband and other telecommunications services are located in the United States. This is also why the requirement to harmonise the terms of the Privacy Shield between the two partners is perfectly logical and understandable. There is a clear conclusion from the above, I fully support the proposed motion for a resolution.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: The next item is the debate – the oral question to the Council by Cecilia Wikström, on behalf of the Committee on Petitions, on the negative impact of the US Tax Compliance Act (FATCA) on foreign accounts on EU citizens, and in particular on 'random Americans' (O-000052/2018 - B8-0033/2018) (2018/2646(RSP))) ) and – the oral question to the Commission by Cecilia Wikström, on behalf of the Committee on Petitions, on the negative impact of the US Tax Compliance Act (FATCA) on foreign accounts on EU citizens, in particular 'random Americans' (O-000053/2018 - B8-0032/2018) (2018/2646(RSP)).

name: Cecilia WIKSTRÖM
text: author. – Madam President, in 2010, the United States, which is the only democratic country in the world to have adopted citizenship—based taxation, enacted the Foreign Account Tax Compliance Act (FATCA), which is an extraterritorial law aimed at preventing tax evasion, through offshore accounts, by US citizens and residents. As part of the global efforts to fight corruption, cross—border tax fraud and tax evasion, EU Member States have concluded bilateral intergovernmental agreements with the USA in order to implement FATCA, obliging European financial institutions to report to the US tax authorities all the holdings of their customers who are so—called ‘US persons’. I would like to emphasise that the Committee on Petitions and the Parliament strongly support tax transparency and all the efforts being made to fight tax fraud. However, more than eight years after FATCA’s adoption, while unilateralism and protectionism unfortunately appear to be the cornerstones of US foreign policy, it is now high time to assess the extraterritorial effects of FATCA on thousands and thousands of law-abiding EU citizens and their families. Therefore, in 2016, a collective of European citizens from nine different Member States submitted a petition to Parliament, to my committee, alerting us via the committee about the impact of FATCA, and its implementing intergovernmental agreements, on European citizens. They testified to the violation of various fundamental principles of EU law, including the right to respect for private life, the prohibition of discrimination, and data protection rules, as well as the EU Payment Accounts Directive. All this was brought to our attention and, to tell you the truth, it was shocking. In practice, FATCA has affected a large number of citizens in Europe, such as citizens who are nationals of both the USA and an EU Member State and, in particular, the so—called ‘accidental Americans’ who, by accident of birth, inherited US citizenship but who maintain no ties at all to the USA, never having lived, worked or studied there, and do not hold US social security numbers. They are, in many cases, completely unaware that they are US citizens. FATCA requires foreign financial institutions to search for US persons by looking at a variety of indicators, including indicators of power of attorney over the account of a US person with a US address, against which the individual is required to prove that he or she is not a US person. Because non—compliance with the requirement imposed results in heavy fines for financial institutions, many of them in the EU have responded by avoiding all commercial business with customers presenting any US connection, whether actual or not. This appears to be in breach of the Payment Accounts Directive and the right of all EU citizens to have access, without discrimination, to a payment account with basic features. In addition, financial institutions have to disclose detailed information on accounts held by presumed so—called US persons to the US Internal Revenue Service via their national governments. This – and I am eager to convey this message to the Commission this evening – could constitute a breach of EU data protection rules and EU fundamental rights and, therefore, it requires further investigation. The lives and livelihoods of thousands of citizens in the EU are at stake here. Those falling within the definition of US persons have their savings accounts frozen, they have no access to banking services, including life insurance, pensions and mortgages due to the reluctance of financial institutions to follow the FATCA reporting. Their family members are also affected. These issues need to be addressed at EU level, all together. Commissioner, it is now high time that the Commission took appropriate action to protect the rights of the European citizens affected, in particular the so-called ‘accidental Americans’. I wonder how the Commission and the Council intend to include the situation of accidental Americans in your transposition assessment of the Payment Accounts Directive. More generally, a full impact assessment of FATCA on EU citizens is badly needed now to determine whether a serious discrepancy exists between EU citizens and residents in different Member States with regard to data protection. Last, but not least, a common EU approach, and in particular an EU-US agreement on FATCA, could in fact prove to be more effective in ensuring reciprocity and upholding the fundamental principles of EU law. I very much look forward to hearing from both the Commission and the Council on the diplomatic and legislative steps that you are considering in order to protect the rights and interests of the EU citizens concerned against the effects of FATCA.

name: Karoline EDTSTADLER
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, as the honourable Member is aware, the Payment Accounts Directive is an important piece of legislation that improves access by citizens to basic banking services. A number of measures to ensure access to a basic payment account were suggested by the Commission in its recommendation of July 2011, and these measures were supported by Parliament in its resolution of 4 July 2012. In July 2014, Parliament and the Council enacted a Payment Accounts Directive, which has been in application since September 2016 and all Member States have notified transposition of the measures contained in the Directive.  However, it is for the Commission to assess the implementation of EU legislation by the Member States and in particular the correct transposition of the Payment Accounts Directive. We trust that the Commission will carefully assess whether it has been correctly implemented by all Member States and will take any appropriate measures in the case of any breach. When it comes to the US legislation on FATCA and its possible extraterritorial effects, let me state the following: it is a principle of international law that the sovereignty of each state implies that it can freely define its taxpayers. Therefore, it is not for the Council to interpret the legal provisions concerning taxpayers in specific non-EU countries. The double taxation situations which can arise from that principle are solved through bilateral agreements based on international arrangements such as the OECD ones. It is not the role of the Council either to interpret intergovernmental agreements concluded by Member States and the US, or to evaluate the impact that they may have on citizens. In light of these considerations the possibility for the negotiation of an EU-US agreement on FATCA has not been discussed by the Council. Finally, on the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR): as the honourable Member is aware, this entered into application on 25 May. The GDPR provides that processing of personal data, such as the disclosure of personal data on bank accounts, is only lawful if its processing has a legal basis such as an international agreement between an EU Member State and the US. Moreover, the GDPR applies to the processing of personal data regardless of whether the processing of the data takes place within the European Union or not.  Therefore, the same data protection rules apply to all data subjects who are in the European Union, including EU citizens and residents irrespective of which Member State they are staying in. Furthermore, the GDPR sets out harmonised rules for transfers and disclosures of personal data from the EU to non-EU countries.

name: Karoline EDTSTADLER
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, first of all, I would like to recall that the US Foreign Account Tax Compliance Act (FATCA) is implemented through intergovernmental agreements negotiated bilaterally between the US and each Member State. Member States chose not to give the Commission a mandate to negotiate an EU agreement, preferring bilateral agreements. I would also like to underline that the information exchange requirements under the Act, as such, are similar to those in our EU directive on mandatory automatic exchange of information in the field of taxation and to the OECD global Standard for Automatic Exchange of Financial Account Information, which is currently being implemented by over 100 jurisdictions.  At the same time, the Commission acknowledges that FATCA and the related intergovernmental agreements may have the unintended effect of hindering access to financial services in the EU for persons regarded by the US authorities as American citizens or tax residents. This includes ‘accidental Americans’ – people who were born in the United States or to United States parents and who may not have any other connection to the United States. As Parliament rightly states in the oral question, US tax rules are based on citizenship. As a result, anyone holding US citizenship, anyone residing mostly in the United States or entitled to permanent residence in the United States will be subject to US tax obligations. This has been acknowledged at international level and in the tax treaties signed by the US with all Member States. The Commission understands that one of the practical problems that EU financial institutions are confronted with is that they need a US tax identification or social security number to report the financial information required under FATCA to the United States tax authorities. However, customers who are subject to FATCA may not have such a number, and obtaining it seems to be cumbersome and potentially costly. Nevertheless, it should be borne in mind that similar reporting obligations are required under the Directive on Administrative Cooperation and at international level through the OECD global Standard for Automatic Exchange of Financial Information.  Concerning the possible discrimination towards consumers and their right to payment accounts, all consumers who are legally resident in the EU, including real and accidental Americans, are entitled to open a basic payment account, irrespective of their nationality or Member State of residence, under the Payment Accounts Directive. Should Member States not enforce this directive, the Commission will decide on appropriate measures, including the launching of an infringement procedure. Member States appear to have followed similar approaches to the issue. They have concluded bilateral agreements with the United States based on the same model. National legislation implementing the agreements has to be in line with the requirements of EU data protection law and the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights. When national data protection authorities analysed the issue in February 2018, they found that there had been no occasions where the processing and transfer of data to the United States under FATCA had to be prohibited.

name: Peter JAHR
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her From the point of view of the Committee on Petitions, if I summarise the statements made by the Commission and the Council, I can think of a philosophical proverb where one could say that the lie is floating in the current of truth. Of course, it is true that, as a country, you must also have the opportunity to collect your taxpayers anywhere in the world, wherever they are. That's all true. But we, as the Committee on Petitions, are dealing with a special group of people, of petitioners, who have come to American citizenship almost ignorantly or unintentionally. An example that can be presented to you: The birth of a child cannot always be determined precisely on schedule. The child is born in the United States, then the parents return to Europe with the child, and the child has American citizenship. They don't even know that. This doesn't matter until you come of age. Now one could say with a little gallows humour: By the way, they also have an advantage, they can then suddenly become American president, which is denied to the others. But of course, this has a lot of consequences in everyday life: the bad news when you try to open a bank account. You have said that this is generally possible, but the banks are doing this somewhat subcutaneously. They don't say ,you don't get a bank account" if they feel somehow, there's a risk, and they have to pass on data that they probably wouldn't like to pass on. Then they prefer to refer the customer elsewhere. It gets even worse when you apply for a loan. In the credit procedure, the creditworthiness of the person concerned must be determined. He has a risk, because he doesn't know if he has to pay taxes in America at all or not. As a rule, the safe way will be taken, and in principle they will not receive any loans. What, of course, usually annoyed us a little as a committee on petitions: normally we would have to say that this is also a question of European citizenship, and That Europe should stand together here. So we prefer European solutions. I simply ask – even if the reference comes from the Coalition Committee, I know that we are not legally competent at all – to take matters into account here, to take up the suggestions and to fight again in order to find a solution in the interests of those affected.

name: Virginie ROZIÈRE
text: On behalf of the Group of The President, we are debating this oral question this evening because the Committee on Petitions of this Parliament has been seized by several hundred European citizens known as 'accidental Americans'.  An "accidental American" is, contrary to what the name says, a European citizen whom the United States considers to be somehow related to American nationality, whether by ancestry, birth or even, in some cases, by mistake.  The consequences are dramatic for these individuals because what they are being asked to do is to comply with U.S. taxation by paying five years of back taxes in the United States. In practical terms, what does it look like? It is considered that with arrears plus legal fees, you must have at least 30,000 euros but, in some cases, this can go up to 60,000, 80,000 or even more than 100,000 euros to be paid to comply. If you do not, you are denied access to the most basic banking services. So you would think that we are dealing with marginal cases, but that is not the case at all, since a study on barely a quarter of the European Union reports more than 100,000 people involved. Therefore, one can imagine that at EU level, between 300 and 500,000 citizens may be affected. Why are we at this point? Because the Member States, in according with the FATCA Act, have agreed to sign bilateral agreements that allow the unilateral and extraterritorial application of US law on European soil.  It is high time that the European Union finally defended its citizens to put an end to this denial of rights and negotiated a European agreement that is reciprocal and in line with our fundamental rights (data protection, access to banking services) and that the European Union also opposes, finally, the extraterritorial application of American law.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Madam President, the Committee on Petitions, our committee, receives hundreds of requests and I think it is very important that, both at this meeting and at a previous meeting, we have brought issues of concern to the citizens. A classic case is the adverse effects of the American Foreign Accounts Tax Compliance Act, fatca, which essentially means an extraterritorial competence of the United States to impose taxes on those who consider themselves their own citizens. In this sense too, there is a competence to discuss this issue, since we consider that a specific European Union directive and, where appropriate, the fundamental rights of the citizens of the Union are being violated. On the other hand, let us say this: taxation is the responsibility of the Member States. In this sense, a bilateral agreement has been concluded between each State and the United States in the case of FATCA. I think there needs to be a direction for the Member States to take action to resolve these issues. Important in this area is the action of the French Government, which has contacted the United States to address this problem.

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, I have to say that I am quite dismayed to hear the Presidency say that it is not your task to evaluate the impact on citizens. If the situation of citizens is not your concern, then what are you doing here? It is our prime concern, and you know what the funny thing is, there are only two  countries in the world that have citizen-based taxation. One is the US, the other is Eritrea, and when Eritrea came here to Europe and tried to impose taxes on Eritrean citizens here, everybody reacted. Apparently, then, it was our concern. So what is different now?  So you think that international relations are more important than the interests of your own citizens. That’s funny, and the other thing that is also funny is that when I started to dig into this, six years ago, I got the same answer: ‘Oh, you know, taxation – there is nothing we can do. Americans decide on their own system; we hardly have any talks with the Americans about this’. But then I made a request for access to documents, and I got 14 000 documents: correspondence between the European Commission and the US authorities on FATCA (Foreign Account Tax Compliance Act). So why are you saying that it doesn’t concern you? What you are saying is that you consider your relationship with the American authorities more important than the rights of citizens. And we are not just talking about basic bank accounts: we are talking about getting a mortgage loan to buy a house, which I think is a fundamental right, or a business loan for an SME, which we were just talking about. So if you can tell Eritrea off, surely you can tell the United States off too. We are talking about at least 110 000 citizens in just seven countries of the European Union, so we are probably talking hundreds of thousands. You have just started your Presidency. Maybe it would be a good start, even before the summer break, to show a little more concern for the interests of European citizens. So I expect the European Council to start talks with the United States about the abolition of citizen-based taxation or, at the very least, an exemption for EU citizens, because it is your duty.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, as has been pointed out by the many petitions received, an increasing number of European citizens, including the so-called Western Americans, are experiencing significant personal problems directly related to the extraterrestrial effects of US tax legislation, called FATCA, which is applied in the Member States of the European Union as a result of bilateral intergovernmental agreements concluded with the United States. The refusal of access to banking services that are essential to these citizens, in a context marred by obvious critical issues, requires the timely elimination of all harassment, discrimination and inconsistency with a view to the protection of fundamental rights. We need a full assessment in the various Member States of the impact on EU citizens of this legislation and the extraterritorial practice of the United States concerning its own method of taxation, based on nationality. I would remind you that, in its resolution of 6 July 2016, this Parliament had already noted a significant lack of reciprocity between the United States and the European Union within the framework of the FATCA agreements. In my opinion, this must be properly addressed and resolved: full reciprocity must apply between the United States and the European Union on the scope of the information to be exchanged, obviously confirming the fight against tax evasion, corruption and money laundering, through the adoption of the highest international standards in the field of tax transparency. I agree with the appeal made by my fellow Members: this is a problem that needs to be addressed not only at European Commission level, but I call on the Council to take this problem seriously, which must be resolved urgently, and to show greater commitment to it.

name: Alex MAYER
text: – Madam President, panicked, isolated and scared: that’s how 73—year-old Cambridge pensioner Merryn Grimley says she felt when she got a threatening letter telling her she needed to pay US tax. Born to British parents, and having gone to school in Britain, worked all her life in Britain and retired in Britain, she’s now being chased down like a criminal by the USA. She didn’t even know that she was accidentally an American citizen because she was born there. I believe that we need to act. FATCA breaches the right to data privacy of the European Convention on Human Rights, and the big financial barriers to renouncing citizenship breach Article 15 of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights. It’s costing Merryn Grimley over USD 2 300 to get rid of the US citizenship she never wanted, nor knew that she had. I urge the Commission to act, and I will also be asking Theresa May to raise this subject with Donald Trump on his forthcoming visit to Britain.

name: Helga STEVENS
text: Mr President, most countries only levy taxes within their territory, but the United States also does so on the basis of nationality. In other words, Americans living abroad must file an Annual U.S. tax return. Some EU citizens were granted US citizenship, without asking, because they happened to be born in America. Facta legislation on automatic exchange of bank data with the US has meant that they may lose access to basic financial services in the EU, which may not be the intention. Every now and then I find in my mailbox a request for help from such "casual Americans". When asked by the Finance Office, it became clear that a letter had been sent, but that unfortunately it remained without an answer. That is why my question to the Council is: can you jointly take new diplomatic or legislative measures to safeguard the interests of EU citizens?

name: Pervenche BERÈS
text: Madam President, I thank the Council and the Commission for their contribution, but when I hear you I sometimes get the impression that you have not met these 'accidental Americans' or these Americans in spite of themselves. These are European citizens who find themselves in a very special situation because they are faced with a country, the United States, which has put in place a system of acquiring nationality that does not exist anywhere else, so there is no point in talking about reciprocity. There is a particular problem with the terms and conditions of acquisition of U.S. citizenship, and you must take this into account. There is also a problem with the way in which the United States has implemented its extraterritoriality, which, again, has an impact. But, Commissioner, I really invite you to meet these 'accidental Americans'. These are people who find themselves in a situation as European citizens, mainly, totally discriminated against. The logic of FATCA enforcement can lead them to become non-banked, because banks do not like to have to deal with the implementation of the FACTA Act. So you are telling us that it is not our jurisdiction. Of course, the states wanted to retain jurisdiction when it comes to negotiating a tax treaty or an agreement, but that is not the issue. What is at stake in the end is how did our banks bend and ask their states to comply with the implementation of the FACTA Act in order to continue to benefit from access to the U.S. market and not have their revenues taxed at 30%. As a result, it is really becoming a subject of negotiation between financial markets. That is why I ask you, along with Vice-President Dombrovskis, every time you travel to the United States, to address this issue so that the principle of proportionality becomes a reality. ...  (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, the three leading speakers here this evening on behalf of the institutions were three ladies, and they gave us a very good overview of this problem with the Foreign Account Tax Compliance Act (FATCA). Also complements to the Committee on Petitions (PETI), who do such wonderful work, for highlighting this issue.  My first reaction was that, if the shoe was on the other foot and it was European countries demanding tax from ‘accidental’ Europeans in the United States, President Trump would be up all night tweeting about it and threatening fire and brimstone upon us. We need to look at it from that point of view and take action.  (Applause) Secondly, I think what my colleague, Ms Wikström, said: an impact assessment needs to be done to establish the extent of this, and to find out what actually is happening in the greatest detail.  Also, you mentioned the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), which has come in in May. Is this in breach of it? If it is, it has to stop, because I think we have to ensure that our citizens are protected from FATCA being applied by the fat cats of the American Revenue Commissioners.

name: Seán KELLY
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank you again for raising this issue and making us aware of the difficulties faced by ‘accidental Americans’. Let me reiterate that the Commission was not part of the negotiations with the United States on the rules implementing FATCA in the Member States, which remain a Member State competence, but I promise I will speak to my fellow Commissioner Moscovici about a possible concerted way forward with the Member States to approach US tax authorities.

name: Karoline EDTSTADLER
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, I have followed this discussion with interest. I have heard also the input from the Commission and from the MEPs who stayed late this evening to fight for the people affected, and I fully appreciate this.  I understand some Member States have been in contact bilaterally with the US authorities over concerns linked to the implementation of FATCA. Against the background regarding the question which was raised – and I would rather say the ‘accusation’ raised by MEP in ‘t Veld several times – which is why the EU is more actively and pursuing the issue, I would like to state that the EU has not yet been called on to take collective action, since Member States have been dealing with this issue individually in close cooperation with the US. And to MEP in ‘t Veld (I see that you have changed your place – I thought you were leaving already, so I am happy that you are still here), I would prefer to be quoted correctly. I said that it is not the role of the Council to evaluate the impact of an intergovernmental agreement concluded by Member States and the US. That is not the role of the Council. And I would state that again, because what we are talking about here are bilateral agreements. Nevertheless, the Payment Account Directive contains a detailed review clause. The Commission has been requested both by the Council and by the European Parliament to submit a report three years after implementation of the Directive, accompanied by any appropriate proposals. The report will deal, in particular, with infringements to the application of the directive.  The report should also highlight the number of credit institutions offering payment accounts with basic features, the associate fees, the characteristics of the consumers who have opened payment accounts with basic features, as well as best practices for reducing consumers’ exclusion from access to payment services. However, the Presidency will of course remain available for exchanges on the subject as needed, and is ready to be in touch with the Commission.  I hope that I was able to clarify the situation, and I thank you again for your attention.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: I have received one motion for a resolution pursuant to Rule 128(5) of the Rules of Procedure. The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, 5 May 2008. Adopted on 17 July 2018.
